content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Viking themed strategy RPG. Basically its about the world is going under, much like Ragnarök foretold and the giant serpent, much like Midgårdsormen, is destroying the world.  the story is told through two diffrent parties, that later join up with each other, basically one is from the perspective of a hunter and his daughter who later lead a tribe and the other is through a bunch of Varls, giant with horns, who acts and behaves like Dwarfs. Both sides fight and flee the Dredges,  who are basically like orcs in armor that is killing everyone and destroying anything. It plays just like an ordinare SRPG with leveling, equipments,turnbased combat on grids etc but has an unique spin on breaking down armor before doing damage on enemies. This means you have to think carefully if your gonna break down someones armor fast for a fast kill, or breaking down their strenght to make sure the same enemy cant dish out a lot of damage fast. And makes you build up parties in which you make walking tanks with a lot of armor, and other weak, but hard hitting fighters. The graphic and soundtrack is amazing - def 9/10. Great viking music with insanely beautiful backrounds as you travel around in the world.Also, the caravn part where you have to handle supplies and make sure you have enough supplies for your trops is pretty fun but ... whatever choice you pick - your caravan will be "beeep" beep" beep" which fits into this ragnarök theme and the world is going under I guess...Anyway I give this game 8.5/10, it ends just when things is getting intresting :O Also, this game reminds me nothing of Sword Art Online, but It should. I love cookies, do you love me? Ps! i'm not fat irl, so calm down.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Viking themed strategy RPG. Basically its about the world is going under, much like Ragnarök foretold and the giant serpent, much like Midgårdsormen, is destroying the world.  the story is told through two diffrent parties, that later join up with each other, basically one is from the perspective of a hunter and his daughter who later lead a tribe and the other is through a bunch of Varls, giant with horns, who acts and behaves like Dwarfs. Both sides fight and flee the Dredges,  who are basically like orcs in armor that is killing everyone and destroying anything. It plays just like an ordinare SRPG with leveling, equipments,turnbased combat on grids etc but has an unique spin on breaking down armor before doing damage on enemies. This means you have to think carefully if your gonna break down someones armor fast for a fast kill, or breaking down their strenght to make sure the same enemy cant dish out a lot of damage fast. And makes you build up parties in which you make walking tanks with a lot of armor, and other weak, but hard hitting fighters. The graphic and soundtrack is amazing - def 9/10. Great viking music with insanely beautiful backrounds as you travel around in the world.Also, the caravn part where you have to handle supplies and make sure you have enough supplies for your trops is pretty fun but ... whatever choice you pick - your caravan will be "beeep" beep" beep" which fits into this ragnarök theme and the world is going under I guess...Anyway I give this game 8.5/10, it ends just when things is getting intresting :O Also, this game reminds me nothing of Sword Art Online, but It should. I love cookies, do you love me? Ps! i'm not fat irl, so calm down.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												This game is not a sandbox storytelling game like King of Dragon Pass or Crusader Kings II. It's far too linear for that, even though you can somewhat influence where the story branches at certain points. Don't expect too much control over things.This game isn't that much of a turn-based tactics battler. Sure, the combat is okayish and gives you something to do in addition to clicking through dialogue, but I never found the fights that engaging and at times it was dull and repetitive. There are way more interesting turn-based combat games out there, don't grab this if that's what you're looking for.However, this game is a pretty good visual novel! The story and characters were interesting, the world is mysterious and the art and music side is well done. If you want to experience a pretty gripping viking fantasy survival story, this game works. Well, at least until the end, when there's not enough closure and it becomes pretty obvious that this is actually The Banner Saga: Episode 1 and it's definitely building up to a sequel. At least the game doesn't over-explain things so the sense of mystery remains.Still, if you enjoy nice hand-painted visuals and very light RPG story elements and just want to be told a neat story, this is a decent experience for that. Just don't expect any sprawling larger-than-life epic, this is quite quickly over even though the world and lore probably could support a larger game in the same setting.

												I have played through this game three times, and enjoyed all of it. This is simply one of the most unique and wondrous videogames I have ever played. It has one of the best tactical battles systems I have played, and I have played almost all tactical turn based games since 2000. Its also an work of art. content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Played this game for the first few minutes, and you quickly get immersed. The music and beautiful scenery complement each other, setting the mood for this breathtaking epic. As you go along through the story, you meet new groups that travel the land and see the different areas of this vast world of Banner saga. Your groups run into interactive scenarios that change your storyline so there is a few careful choices you have to make. This game has a decent tutorial mode as you start, teaching you the units of the game, as well as placement ranges for your attacks, plus learning the perks in battle. Overall, this game has very little flaws and the story is engaging that spans for quite some hours. Definitely worth the 20$ that I have spent.Overall grade: 9.5 / 10Pros:- Breathtaking storyline- Stunning Visuals- Engaging Score, sets the mood nicely- Battles are well done, can set difficulty if it gets too hardCons:- Save states are always automatic, can't manually save and go back

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												I really really wanted to like this game. The developers have put forth a laudable effort in the aesthetic arena, and the game mechanics are surprisingly tolerable for an unadulterated turn-based scheme. While this offering is apparently only the first of a forthcoming trilogy, there is simply no exuse to end the game so abruptly. As someone who enjoys games primarily for the story, such an unsatisfying denouement taints the whole experience. The rest of the package is developed to a point that is more than satisfactory, but when a game is centred around the plot it seems rather silly to leave in such precarious shape. I won't delve into details, but a significant proportion of the interesting strands of the plot remain unresolved (or worse, unexplained to begin with) and the tale's rather clichéd conclusion fails to have any emotional impact due to the lack of character development over such a short timeline. Unfortunately for me, The Banner Saga (at this point) remains a cautionary tale of how not to deliver on a very promising premise. Again, I really wanted to like the game... but I didn't.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												This game is fantastic.  War is coming, the world is ending.  Blast the viking music as you strike down your foes.  Decide what to do on the road.  Do you take time to raid that village for supplies when the enemy is hot on your heels, do you lead the charge in battle.  Do you set a raging inferno for your enemies?  Your choices have weight, the combat is meaty, and in this game, unlike many, your decisions matter, mechanically, emotionally, it's got it all.  It is only through glory that one may enter valhalla!

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												The Banner Saga is a convoy management game with turn-based strategy fights that augment your heroes and convoy, and ultimately affects the future of your game.In terms of art direction and theme, they strike such a dischordant tone, it might actually hurt your head. Not that either the art or theme are bad. The art is good and the story seems solidly written. Except they're totally opposite. The art is colourful, vibrant and almost child-like in its presentation. The story is about death, hard decisions, starvation and single parent trying to raise a young girl in an uncontrollable apocalypse.Like a WWII history documentary as illustrated by My Little Pony.The game itself has strong central mechanics, and the turn based combat is good. The heroes level up with kills in an RPG style. The elements are solid, and if the final battle wasn't an exercise in throwing everything the game had taught you out the window, it might have recieved a thumbs up from me.It's supposed to be the start of a three part series, but they've made the mistake of not creating the first of the trilogy as a self contained story. It feels like a beginning, like you've wasted time on getting nowhere, and though it purports to be a story driven by your choices, it isn't, your decisions affect nothing but your hero roster.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Its rare when a computer game is able to convey the feelings and connection to a story that normally only a book can. Banner Saga is much a case. The game is predominantly its story and its unfolding through your own actions.I wont go into the details of the story, because it would be a shame to spoil any of it. Suffice to say that it is heavily influenced by Northern European Mythology and that it takes place in a similarly cold and "bleak" setting.The game inter-mixes tactical strategy with graphic adventure elements very well, even if the combat and character traits are somewhat simplistic. At the end of the day it doesn't really matter cause once again its all about the story. A story that is most of all, well told.It is this point that makes the game great, as the developers have managed to convey the story and a multitude of emotions that manage (in a very short time span) to tie you (emotionally) to many of the characters and their situations.Don't expect action sequences or cinematic or anything of the sort, the graphics are reminiscent of hand drawn Disney classics and the accompanying music is superb.While there are alternative paths to the end (and different endings apparently), I believe that the average person will not bother to go through a second play-through, if nothing else mostly because they will be satisfied with it enough to not want to spoil it.So at the end of the day if you like story driven games (and can enjoy a fantasy setting), don't miss this game, it is quite the experience.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												I do not recommend and am disappointed of the game because:- the core element, the fights, are very repetetive and do not offer a great variety of strategic possibilites. Also, you might have a choice not to fight, but wont be able to upgrade your characters or earn any reknown otherwise. (Yes, you can get little reknown for other good choices, but far from enough) This renders the fight necessary but boring.- the story only scratches the surface of what would have been possible. The game stops with the first real boss and shortly after all the main characters are introduced. It also leaves a big story gap in between the two main "armies".- the "choices" you can make will all end in the same story progress and actually all your choices will make everything worse, like being kind to people will almost always end in you being screwed over by these people, and you wont get any reknown. - the "armies" lack significance. It doesnt matter how big your army is. At least it didnt matter in my play-throughs. At one point i had only 3 varls in my army and could defeat the enemies army by charging in.- the atmosphere lacks depth. The pictures are beautifully painted and the army wandering the lands look great. But the characters remain static, because their depictions are static and do seldomly show emotions. I couldnt connect to any of them. Also, it seemed to me that any character you like will die anyway, no matter what you do. - the way the story is told is patchy at best. Important or emotional scences are just told as text without any visual or audial aid. Ok, videos are expensive to make, but a picture or speech would have been possible. Like the scene where you can decide weather to take the enemies child with you or not. This scene remains hollow and undetached.+The story, the music, the artwork is great, but its just not a whole game.PS: I backed this game from the beginning. Not unlike Broken Age, it feels very short and shallow.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												As a person who likes turn based strats HoMM, Disciples, KingsBounty I had high hopes for this game. After finishing it for the most part on normal difficulty I want to but I really cant reccomend people buying it. The good : Amazing visuals, animation and sountrack. Thats about it. The bad: it would be easy to say everything else but im going to elaborate.With such an amazing score and visuals the game has virtually no voicework to accompany the dialogues. Which would ok if it werent for hte fact that they are either poorly translated or just badly written. You can skip 90% of the dialogue and still be on the same page if you had been paying attention.The unitally cool and challenging combat quickly becomes boring or unfair depnding in you difficulty level. There arent many different enemies so you end fighting the same 4-5 guys for 9 hours and the strategy never evolves beyond gang up on the weak guy. The special abilities of each hero are very situational and I maybe used 3 abilities regulary. Some mechanics are downright broken. The demand for provisions to supply the caravan is completely optional since there virtually no penatly to loosing clansmen/varl. The renown points (with which the game is very stingy) are better spent on your crew and gear.  Beware some party memebers are prone to sudden death during the random encours on the road. So dont be surpised if a badass warhawk level 5 gets killed by dregeling off screen with little infleunce by the player.Despite the strong visual and audio presentation the story is moot and the characters never evolve beyond thier booring achetypes. The pampered prince, the innocent girl, the reluctant leader etc. Over all I would say stay away from this beatiful siren fo a game no matter how tempting the and song lull you to its purchase

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												I don't know where to start on this so I guess i'll just state my conclusion and work back from there:Should you buy this at the current price 24.99(usd), No. Should you buy it if it's on sale at around 75%? Hell yeah!There are many problems i have with this game but there are also some things that were done right that i found as well. Here's list of things I found and you all can be the judgePro's:Pretty cool story, when all is said and done.The whole leading the caravan part of the game, awesome, felt like i was playing the war scenes from a game of thronesAll the characters had pretty decent stories and personalitiesThe combat was pretty cool once you got the hang of it. Think tactics ogre mixed in with some wierd type of chessArt fit the feel of the game perfectlyCon's:You obviously set yourself up for a sequel. By this i mean, there are good cliff hangers that leave me thinking "oh, well what are they going to do now?" and then there's  ones that leave me saying "What the ♥♥♥♥ you spent all this ♥♥♥♥ing time mentioning these things that your not even going to tell me about? Seriously? Not even a hint?"; the later of which you did, and i'm kinda upset about that.There are bugs still in this I had it crash a couple times on me and the load times for the graphics in the game are pathetic. Borderlands 2 loads quicker than this game does for me. (check out ivrir's story background after that big thing to him happens, btw, it's bugged)Game feels rushed half way through, and heres why i say that:You just randomly stop switching between rook and what's his horned face. Just stop. You could've totally split off with him and gone off on his on journey up to the point that he regroups, but you didn't and i was kinda disappointed.You're ending is abrupt, i wasn't quite sure that i hit the end untill the credits popped up.There are 2 GAPING WIDE plot points that never really come to surface, which is too bad becuase I kind of wanted to see more of it.]The army combat parts are a little lacking. Honestly, I felt like i  could have led a charge the entire time and been better off.I would have like to actually have command of my armies as well instead of just saying how to engage. A perfect example of how i'd've liked this game to play the army scenes would be Suikoden. Do some like that with your army combat.In conclusion(again), Don't buy this game unless its on sale or the cost has gone down to around 10-15$ and you'll be much much happier. Took me about 14 hours to complete and i was a terrible leader who told every one to do what they want, which i'm sure divertered most combat situations, so i could see this game lasting at most 20 hrs on the first play through.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												If viking Oregon trail and a turn based tactics game had a baby it'd be a lot like banner saga. First thing you will notice about the banner saga is the art, rotoscoping isn't something that you see everyday let alone in a video game and the bannar saga excels at making each person, place or thing you encounter on your journey really come to life with beauty.Speaking of journey the music in this game is composed by Austin Wintory who did the music for the game Journey. The entire game sounds fantastic from the heavy beating of drums to the triumphant bellow of horns the entire sounds epic from start to finish.As I said before the game really feels like a great mix of turn based tactics and Oregon trail. Combat takes place on a grid and you and the enemy take turns bashing each other. With each character having different strengths and weaknesses and a simple yet deeping twist on how your units health works the game really makes you feel accomplished for each and ever battle you win. That is a good thing because honestly this like to give you a bad hand a lot.The other half of the game is the traveling part, as you and your viking caravan cross mountians and icy wastes you must deal with a number of issues such as "Do we have enough food?" "Can we trust these strangers we just met?" The game makes you choose and everything you do has an effect on the caravan as a whole. Letting some strangers join you might mean they steal a bunch of the food in the night and then suddenly you are in the middle of nowhere and people are starving to death right and left as you push forward. You must make tough choices often times sacrificing one resource or another while trying to keep the people and warriors you take on in good spirits.In the end the Banner saga is a deep game with rich lore and a enduring characters and it's a adventure worth taking.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												God we need more games like this one! The Banner Saga is the first part of an ambitions adventure game created by indie developers. The gameplay is quite simple but entertaining and enhanced with 3 levels of difficulty. The level design is gorgeous, it's deeply inspired by the art of Eyvind Earle but it still has it's own identity. Anyway it's the story that makes this game different from other RPG/Adventure games.First, the world is a perfect mixture between nordic mythology, fantasy and apocalyptic fiction. The story is about survival and beliefs, in this chaotic snowy and cold landscape three races try to escape the forthcoming shadows. This first part is centered on the story of Rook, a hunter, who try desperately to save his kin and his traveling companions from starvation, killing each other and from the dredge's return. The story really evolves depending of your choices, you can build strong relations with some characters and at the same time don't even meet the other ones. You can easily loose your best mates after making a mistake that seemed to be the good thing to do at the time. It makes the story really moving, mature and immersive. And personally that's why I play video games, not to kill dozens of monsters but to feel something. I'm waiting for the second part with great excitement and you should do the same !

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												A shining example of what developers can do when given the freedom to create their own product within a set budget. I simply couldn't stop playing it once I started. The story draws you in, it's written to a mature audience and each character has a real feeling of authenticity to them. Then the gameplay hits you. If you like making strategic choices that have true consequences and you aren't afraid of tough decisions, then you'll love it. What I love most about the strategy and choices in The Banner Saga is that there are multiple ways in which you are given choices, not continuously being asked whether you want to loot a village or continue on. Instead you make choices about who to side with, choices about how to manage your caravan of fighters, choices in the heat of battle, and choices about how to spend your limited resources (more supplies to keep you going or upgrading heroes through stats and items).This game lets you make those choices, and lets you deal with the consequences.Edit: Oh and how could I forget the visuals, this game is beautiful to look at, the caravan scenes are gorgeous and the character drawings are delicious.

												This game is phenomenal! The art style is gorgeous with a breathtaking soundtrack to add to the stunning visuals in the scenes. The story is interesting, following more than one character through this epic journey. Your stuck making morale choices for a whole group of people and you care about whether they live or die, even though you haven't met many of them, your characters care enough to make you show the same amount of affection for them. You feel like a leader, striving to survive against a seemly endless enemy and hopless odds. This has and is one of the most enjoyable experiences in gaming I have ever had and I highly recommend it to any and everyone!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												I'd like to preface this review with some advice for playing it: In combat, weaken your enemies to about 1-3 health before starting to kill them, because the more enemies you kill, the more turns their surviving comrades get. People not getting this and getting beaten constantly is the number one source of criticism I see - people don't like it the combat because they don't understand this. To be fair to these people, the game never explains this, you have to learn it on your own. If you learn to use this approach early you'll get a lot more out of the game.The way this game presents choices is a breath of a fresh air. To contrast with BioWare, where the major choices are all set pieces in Banner Saga they're presented much more organically. I've yet to beat the game, but already the story feels very personal based on my choices, compare this with other RPGs, where you often don't see the outcome of your decisions until the end.*Possible Spoilers Below*Something that's very interesting is the use of two protagonists. They manage to make playing as each caravan feel very different, in a good way. In one it's all about war and diplomacy, in the other it's all about desperation and survival. The different feel of playing as each is much appreciated.*End Possible Spoilers*The combat is incredibly satisfying. Normally, I prefer real time with pause combat, but Banner Saga's system is great. It's very tactical without feeling overwhelming.The music and the art are just phenomenal. I can't do them justice here.The world building is also great. It manages to draw effectively on Norse mythology and culture without feeling derivative. There's lots of familar imagery and themes but they're presented in a very fresh way. I'm playing the game as much to find out what happened in the world's past as I am to find out where the story goes. The setting is one of the game's biggest triumphs.EDIT: Having now finished the game I'd like to add some more thoughs. The game as a whole is fantastic. I can't wait for the next episode - I want to see how my choices will affect the rest of the story. More than that, after the events of this episode I'm very excited to see how certain characters develop. The character writing is very, very strong. I was surprised just how attached I became to some members of my party. There are some truly memorable personalities in this game.The major set pieces of game are also fantastic. There are a couple of situations that you face that spread over multiple in game days, where you will be forced to make a lot of hard choices in rapid succession that are truly epic. I can't say any more than that as I couldn't imagine a greater disservice than spoiling in any fashion the two events I have in mind.EDIT2: I'd like to add, if you liked The Walking Dead you'll enjoy Banner Saga. The characterisation of the protagonist and approach to choices are very similar and the stories even have some similar themes.

Posted: February 19, 2014
												Blown away by this game. Excellent decision based story. It does a great job of clearly putting a choice in front of you, without tying you down with a morality guage (light/dark side, paragon/renegade). The combat is fun and engaging, although I found myself always wishing it was over so I could further the story. Solid RPG elements, great Oregon Trail management, but last but not least gripping characters and plot. This is the old BioWare we all miss. My biggest complaint was going in I was not aware it was the first of a trilogy, so be ready for it to end with you wanting more character development and plot.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												A good game, but not amazing.  I'm rather baffled at some of the gameplay decisions the designers made for the combat.  The tactics are actually pretty flat, largely owing to completely flat battle maps and chess-like mechanics that encourage you to beat down your enemies but not finish them off.The caravan management system is nice, but much too linear for my tastes - there's a map, but not much point to it since you have little choice in destination or even route you take.  Resource management definitely could have used more balancing.  There's a single game currency - renown - that acts as both your money and your experience points.  This is designed to force you to make hard decisions between having enough supplies to keep your clansmen fed and having heroes powerful enough to beat the challenges they face.  In truth, you'll often find yourself short on both starting at around the half-way point of the game and continuing right up until the ending.I'm not sorry I kickstarted the game, but had I known the end result I probably wouldn't have given quite as much money as I did.  Like I said, a good game, but not amazing.  The most frustrating thing is that I feel like it could have been amazing with some tweaks - the writing and the art direction are definitely there.  I'd give it a 7/10.

												Really enjoyed playing this game, I got so addicted I played it through in two sittings. The Art work is beautiful, and the combat, while simple, is satisfying and it is nice to see something new being tried in relation to grid based combat systems,The story is well told, and the characters are unique and memorable. THe choices that are presented to you throughout the game also have consiqence, and I quite often found myself stopping at a decision and painfully trying to work out what the results of my actions might be.Overall I would really reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys something different and appreciates a good story! I couldnt summarise it better than another review I read, this is a mixture of Game of Thrones, Disney and classic RPG systems, and I love it! :)

												Beware, you haven't known crushing despair until you've played this.It's actually a pretty amazing game, beautifully designed with an innovative combat system.The difficult choices you make are the defining feature. It does really well at building connection with the characters, then forces you to make decisions that can have gut-wrenching consequences. The plot twists are frequent, unpredictable and unforgiving.I'd heard mixed reviews, so didn't try it out until a sale. There's some valid points made against it, but overall its a well polished game especially for the price. It's worthwhile just as a really beautifully told story, but the turn based combat is fun and challening too. I hope they add DLC or a whole new chapter.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												This game is essentially The Oregon Trail, but with a Nordic fantasy theme and a rudimentary turn-based combat system akin to Final Fantasy Tactics or X-Com (but with substantially less depth). The art style is refreshing, and the lovingly crafted world is enjoyable to immerse in for a while. Unfortunately, it is a very short while; most players will find themselves wanting more content after the final battle. Buy the game if it is on sale for less than $20 and I suspect you will feel rewarded by the purchase. In my opinion, the $25 price point is just a bit too high for the amount of gameplay you get.I sincerely hope that a sequel is in the works; one with a hundred hours of gameplay and a more robust combat system. This is a world I'd like to inhabit again.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												The game doesn't demand much from your PC/Mac but stills delivers a very nice gameplay, artstyle and music. Its pretty hardcore in that you can't do manual saves (just auto-saves) and thus forces you to live with the decisions you've made. If you want to undo a decision you made, you have to go back to the last auto-save which sometimes might involve fighting certain battles again to rereach the point when the decision was made.I feel that this gives the gameplay more dept though can lead to some frustrations especially once you made a command that leads to the death of some characters.All in all, I really enjoy playing this game. If you're a fan of turn-based startegy games like FF Tactics with added decision making, this game is highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												If you're a fan of tactical strategy games, this is more than worth your time.  The grid-based fights are different from anything else I've played in the genre, tying your remaining health to your ability to do damage, incentivizing keeping your party in good health.  There's a real emphasis on fighting against a team, as a team, and once you start to hang back and create opportunities the strategic depth really shines through.The heroes/caravan/item system strung on top of the combat is well put together and systemized in a fun way, harkening back a bit to things like the Oregon trail.  There seems to be a number of decision points strung through the story that can create some interesting divergences, resulting in losing/gaining new heroes, as well as the permanent death of major characters. The animation style of the game is fantastic, 2d artwork in the style of say, old Ralph Bakshi movies from the 70s and 80s.  It's a fairly unique look for a game in this genre.  Music is fantastic, by the always on point Austin Wintory.Definitely worth your time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												The Banner Saga is an excellent turn-based RPG, where decisions you make affect the outcome of the story and changes the lives of the games characters.  The story is engrossing and revolves around a march to save your kinsmen from danger.  You lean to care about the people in your caravan, which make some of the decisions you have to make very difficult.  Although, this also gives the game a lot of replay value, as you strive to make better decisions, and protect more people in your caravan.  Decisions are more than just choosing when to fight, or dialogue choices; when it comes down to it the entire game is a decision of how best to spend your resources.  Do you buy supplies for your caravan to help you get to the next area? OR upgrade your combat team? Or buy items to have your combat team? They each use the same resource, so you have to decide where to put your limited resource.  Even choosing how often and when to rest effects gameplay.The combat is isometric turn-based, and involves a lot of strategy, and can at times, be surprisingly challenging.  There are three game modes, to provide more or less challenge to the player.  Hard mode being very challenging indeed.Overall an enjoyable experience that will leave you wanting more.  As soon as I finished the game, I began researching if there was to be a sequel, and I was pleased to hear the play is for this game to be part of a trilogy.Definitely worth playing, and highly recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												Interesting start to a new franchise. Not perfect by any meaning, but for what its worth, I had fun, was gripped by the story and moral choices and while the ending is *SPOILERS* a HUGE cliffhanger *SPOILERS* , I hope this game gets a sequel to expand on the story and universe.The bad things:-The game is really hard. Even on the easiest difficulty. But this doesnt need to be a bad thing, since loosing characters is integrated into the storyline and can help shape the story of each playthrough new.-Its not terribly long...if you do everything right, the campaign is done in around...8-9 hours, maybe less if you are more skilled and just accept the outcome of your choice instead of save scumming because a certain event left you with a sour taste.-The story starts promising, has a huge buildup, a dramatic climax...and a really bad cliffhanger. I won't spoil much more, but lets say that unless the devs actually get a sequel done (which may or may not fail depending on their current conflict with King.com over the word Saga in their title), this will be a huge dissapointment, not unlike other promising projects like Kingdoms of Amalur or Loom.That said, its not too pricey and definitly a nice spin on the genre. So I can recommend it if you dont mind the above drawbacks and like challenging turn-based strategy rpgs.

												Firstly, this game is incomplete in terms of story. The developers have tried to make The Banner Saga complete on it's own as best as possible, but depending on the success (which has been good so far 25/01/2014), they will make Banner Saga 2 and hopefully 3 and or more.The game has beautiful art, although it is repeated throughout the game, it's still amazing to see the line work, balance of colours and Disney quality environments. content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I didn't actually beat this game yet, but it's damn good. Think the Oregon trail meets Game of Thrones meets an actually good game, and you get this one. A lot of games talk about trying to make all your decisions matter, and a lot of games say they do, but in the end it simply doesn't feel like your actions really matter. Banner Saga is probably the only game I've played where I felt like it was true. When I need to make a decision in-game and someone dies, I feel like their blood is legitimately on my hands. Sometimes the only ones that die are nameless clansmen, and, honestly, that doesn't affect the game much, but one time I made the decision of trusting the wrong guy, and one of my best combatants, a centerpiece of my offense, was just straight up killed. From what I've seen so far (because I've started playing the game twice), the main plot doesn't change, there are no grand branching paths far as I've seen, but you definitely feel the weight of responsibility as decisions constantly have you weighing morality vs. personal survival, risk vs. chance of reward, and sometimes just posing a genuine question of morality. (Choices? 10/10. Your move, AAA studios)Now, without the choices, how about the story itself? The world is nicely built, the story is compelling, the characters are interesting, and there are some really good quotes. It gets trippy as hell, though. Like I said earlier, I never beat the game, so I can't attest to the quality of the ending.(Story? 8.75/10. Worthwhile.)Now that we got this girly nonsense talk about "story" out of the way, let's talk about combat. The real men's subject. It's a grid-based, turn-based rpg system, but instead of attacking you decide whether to strike armor or strength. Each does a thing we're not getting into now. How does this effect the gameplay? Enough to distinguish itself. It definitely gives a unique feel, and the tactical question of "Should I attack strength or Armor?" rarely has an obvious answer. So it adds a layer to strategy. It's not necessarily ground-breaking, but it adds a little spice. (Combat? 8/10: can't complain; pretty good) It adds just the right amount of spice, really. A classy amount. The Banner Saga is lIke something from a fancy resturant. Just don't actually eat there because the waiter poisons people at random.Overall: 9/10 I would easilly recommend this game to any strategy player, and some non-strategy players.

												The Banner Saga is great because you develop a deep understanding of the knowledge that every situation that you're presented with in the story will result in you picking the wrong option, trying to load the game in frustration only to realise that you didn't save it soon enough, and the autosave didn't go back far enough, so then you have to leave the game entirely to break open your piggy bank, raid your mother’s jewellery box and re-mortgage your house just to find the money you need to speed down to the nearest bar, drink yourself into a bitter stupor, call everyone you know on your contact list and pour abuse at them until they swear to disown you, crawl back to your home and restart the game from the beginning. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												Turn-based combat RPG with interesting story, decision-making and combat system.The art is very crisp. Sound is good too.The combat system involves armor and health/strength. Losing health diminishes the strength of a character, and losing armor means they are more vulnerable. If strength is too low itll be hard to attack an enemy with higher armor level. First time Ive seen such a system in a game and it makes for more thoughtful and careful play. As I began figuring out the system my enjoyment of combat increased a lot as I began to make the right decisions and win more battles. For example, archers arent very strong against armored enemy, but they can plink away at armor whilst the melee character moves in - once both have broken they can both finish off the enemy quick.Also theres a practice battle option which provides random set of enemies. It doesnt improve or injure your heroes, just practice. These are usually harder than what you face in the normal game, allowing you to improve a lot and learn how to beat the odds. Playing on the hardest difficulty is essential I think otherwise you might find it too easy. If you like the game's combat is a good addition and adds a bit more to the game's challenge. You can also change how many heroes you go into the battles with so that can make it more of a challenge and make you a better player.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												The most remarkable aspect of this game is presentation. From the soundtrack to the art direction to the interface, everything is immaculate and elegant. Nothing feels rough around the edges or half-finished as far as those elements go. The gameplay is unique- a combination of choose-your-own-adventure style frequent decision-making, an Oregan Trail-like survival and travel element that involves some resource management, and the battle system itself which involves tactical strategy and some interesting components like individual health and defense bars to attack, and the Varl race of characters who take up a lot of unit space in battle but have high attack power. There are so many characters to choose from during battle- as many as 20 are encountered by game's end and even character usage involves some decision-making as characters only level up by not only actively participating, but getting in a number of kills.Now for some of the downsides- though there are such a plethora of options and routes to go on, nearly all lead toward the same end and plot points seem black and white in nature- you either picked the "right" answer leading to hidden items or a surplus in resources, or you picked the wrong one which can set you back in progress. But making wrong decisions matters little since the difficulty level is low until the end, and the initially interesting tactics-driven combat is actually quite simplified compared to other strategy RPGs. Aspects such as equipment management involve collecting numerous accessories and each character can hold just one. Character classes and stat allocation is similarly straightforward. On the bright side, that makes this title a great choice for those new to the genre and not very interested in micro-management. The storyline is interesting and involved, but there is not much clarification of the lore. While the character and plot development is nicely done, it can be vague with some side characters receiving barely a line of exposition. While I compared the decision-making to a choose-your-own-adventure novel, it has nowhere near the verbosity of visual novels or many story-driven RPGs. The writing is of an appreciably high standard of quality though and the lack of meandering over any particular element (whether it be storytelling or the various types of gameplay present here) keeps the game fast-paced. I achieved completion at around 10 hours and do feel there is some replay value here, but the general asking price ($24.99) is very high for this amount of content. I would suggest waiting for a sale of at least 30-50% off. The exception being if the subject matter is particularly riveting to you, in which case I'd say go ahead as it is likely to impress.

												Rated eleventy million out of ten.Earlier today I rushed out of my study to find my girlfriend so I could bemoan the enormity of making decisions I knew might cost the lives of many of my clansmen.  "I can't handle this responsibility! People are looking to me to lead and I'm constantly letting them down.", I wailed.For me, the hallmark of any exceptional game is that it leaves you pondering the wider story and the lives of the characters within it, even when you are far away from your computer.  The Banner Saga most certainly falls into this category. In fact, I wouldn't be surprised to find myself dreaming of Dredge and Godstones again tonight.The Banner Saga game mechanic is essentially a modern multi-choice story-driven take on The Oregon Trail, with a squad-based tactics battle engine bolted on top.With captivating writing, stunning graphics and an engrossing, mood-setting soundtrack, the twists and turns of the story have at times left me setting my jaw or blinking away tears. I have found myself incredulous, mouth agape at the narrative's brutality and unfairness.  Knowing in my gut that survival is unlikely, I grip the mouse tighter, hoping it may somehow force my starving caravan up the next desolate snowy peak...

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												The Banner Saga is an extraordinary game. Starting with the obvious, the landscapes and soundtrack are both breathtaking and plain epic. But what what really reeled me in, even more than the wonderful and immersive atmosphere, is the storyline. Twisted, and relying so very much on the player's choices. You often don't know where you're going, what to decide, whom you should trust or not, and must rely on your own judgement (often wrong !) and guts to advance. It is such a pleasure to feel like you're are actually choosing, or creating your own path rather than following the same patterns as always ; and it's not so often that a game really makes you think twice about a choice that will (maybe) haunt you until the end... The Banner Saga is really a refreshing creation, dark indeed, but beautiful nonetheless, and takes you in without mercy. I just finished it, and already want to discover all the other paths that lie ahead... I recommend it whole-heartedly !

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Świetna gra taktyczna. Wykorzystywanie skilli i odpowiednie ustawianie wroga na planszy - klucz do zwycięstwa. Chwilę zajmuje żeby to ogarnąć. Grajcie na najwyższym poziomie trudności - trzeba nieźle kombinować. Nie ma nagrywania w każdym momencie, niektóre decyzje przynoszą efekty po kilku godzinach od jej podjęcia - to wszystko sprawia,  że gra się ciurkiem i trzeba godzić się ze swoimi wyborami. Postaci giną, odchodzą, walki trzeba powtarzać aby osiągnąć optymalny efekt. Gra raczej dla starszych graczy, bo nie prowadzi za rękę. Tutorial jest ubogi. Wszystko wychodzi w praniu. Jedna rzecz, która mnie lekko zirytowała to ostatnia walka. Fabuła narzuca udział w walce postaci, której w ogóle nie rozwijałem. Trzy dni się męczyłem i nie dałem rady - musiałem wgrać stan sprzed decyzji o tym kto bierze strzałę. Przechodzę zaraz po raz drugi na pozomie normal - pierwszy raz zagrałem na hard i ani nie rozwinąłem wszystkich postaci, ani wszystkich fajnych artefaktów nie mogłem kupić. Prawie 50h zabawy, przy czym wiele walk powtarzałem. Teraz zagram dla wygody i przyjemności - zrobię sobie dream team pakerów. Polecam - każdemu kto nie lubi banalnych gier.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												Do you feel like playing an RPG that can punish or reward you for every single moral decision you ever make? Are you prepared to redefine what you consider "moral" as your mental and strategic mettle are put the the test constantly? And finally, can you handle the emotional consequences of your actions as you struggle to balance the needs of keeping yourself, your party, and the rest of your caravan alive?Banner Saga puts the questions to the test as you traverse through a gorgeous, norse mythological world...albeit on the run from dire enemies all the while. The game is fantastic overall, despite the rather monotonous and somewhat flawed battling system (e.g., an odd turn-based system that alternates your turn and the enemies every time; thus, even if you have 6 members alive and they have only 2, they still get to go multiple times while your characters only get to go once in turn). However, the real appeal is essentially the entire story itself: It is full of twists and turns, celebrations and mourning, and heart-wrenching choices through every step along the way. And the music! Oh, the music is simply some of the most aesthetically pleasing sounds you will ever hear; fitting seamlessly throughout the gameplay.This game is only part one of several (out of a total of three I believe that are in development), so pick it up now while you have the chance (and when it is on sale of course!). I believe this game cuts a well-earned 9 Varl (Viking) axes out of 10 Dredge heads. If you have any questions for me about the game, please leave a comment on this review and I will be happy to try to answer them.

Final Rating: At $5.00 or less, 10/10. At $12.00, 6/10This is a great story-driven game. Combat is easy to learn but still requires some skill/strategy on normal difficulties. Beautiful artwork and pretty good music (especially during pivotal scenes.) My only gripes are a huge diffuculty spike during one fight in the game, and that only a tiny portion of the game has voice acting. Also, some of the choices you make seem wise but may have arbitrary/unintended negative consequences. Your party will only die through story events, not combat, and it can be frustrating to have your best fighter killed in a freak yox stampede because you chose not to let the traitorous yox herdsman live a few miles back. Overall a great game if you can get it on a good sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												Banner Saga is a study in videogames as a storytelling medium. The score, the sounds, the visual style, and the writing all work together beautifully to tell the story of a merciless world falling apart. It's tense and you're always on the verge of annihilation, and the music alone could tell you so. It's gritty, and the crunches of axes breaking armor and the grunts and moans of the injured make you feel it. People are fragile and the perpetual march is exhausting, and the heavy shambling motions of bodies shows you so.  As the leader, you constantly have to arbitrate the problems of your followers, keep them optimistic, keep them fed, and keep them alive while a continent of panicking and desperate people is being overrun.  Everything harmoniously comes together to weave an atmosphere where feelings of dread and anxiety are constant. Your choice isn't whether or not people die, it's who dies now so that fewer will die later.  In every artistic regard this game is an achievement.Unfortunately it's not for everyone, though. Its roots are in the artistry, not the gameplay--people have some valid complaints about that. Only some. I didn't dislike the gameplay at all, but I was very wrapped up in every other part of the game. Play it for the experience.

Posted: February 15, 2015
												As a fan of turn based strategy games I can't say that The Banner Saga is a great game. The strategic part is very basic and isn't more complex than a game of checkers. Also the user interface is really abysmal, the worst I've ever seen in a strategic game. For example you can't inspect your team members attributes and abilities when choosing who to bring in battle. While in battle the interface isn't better and choosing the action to perform feels very cheap. Abilities are described "with text" like a game from 20 years ago, no icons and no visual aids. Very very basic.Despite all this I still recommend the game; why? Because the story is tragic and mature like it rarely happens in games lately. It is really up to Norse Myths standards... The music is a masterpiece that is alone worth the price of the game and the experience, as whole, feels like a work of love from its developers. So even if I can't fully recommend it as a game I still recommend it without hesitation as a work of "art".

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Highly recommend this game for fans of tactical RPGs, or turn-based RPG combat in general. It makes some questionable design decisions at various points, but is well worth every cent of the asking price. (If you pick it up later on during a Steam sale, congratulations, you're winning.)Selling points: this is possibly amongst the most beautiful games I have ever played. Not in terms of "graphical fidelity," of course, but the cel-shaded art style is extremely well-done all the way through and quite captivating. I would happily take games in this style over mainstream AAA titles living in the uncanny valley over and over again. My only complaint in this area is the extremely limited character animation during "cutscene" conversations; what is there simply serves to highlight how little there is. I probably wouldn't even have noticed if not for the few efforts they made on this front. (A very, VERY minor complaint, since the game is not relying on FMV-style, and even in still shots, the artwork is simply gorgeous)The tactical combat is engaging, and the mechanic which links a character's health to his damage output makes an otherwise simplistic system compelling (do I do limited damage against this enemy to lower the danger they bring, or reduce his armor to make my next turn that much more effective while risking him bringing the hurt in the interim?) and makes level-up decisions on characters agonizing. I went the route of "specializing" each character I used frequently, resulting in characters of similar class and starting stat reaching the end-game with vastly different skill sets (i.e. of the two archers I used every opportunity, one was the absolute best at knocking enemy armor out of the picture, while the other was a damage-and-willpower fiend who had my highest kill count by the last fight). Also, while I'm not huge on harping for realism in games, it has always somewhat annoyed me that characters with 1HP out of their 1,000 maximum were just as potent as at full health, and this is a nice way of remedying that.The story arc is compelling and kept me interested the whole way through without relying on many overdone tropes and archetypes, taking place in a very interesting setting I would happily p[ay to see more of. There is also quite a bit of background lore and information made easily accessible without forcing it to the forefront through excessive exposition, leaving its perusal to those willing to spend the time to enjoy it and letting those less interested mostly ignore it without detracting from the direct experience.The Renown system, which irritated me a great deal, but in a good way (as odd as that sounds). EVERYTHING in this game - level-ups, food for your tribe, items to supplement your heroes - is purchased with renown, which you gain from victory in battle as well as certain C&C moments in between. While it can be frustrating at times, after beating the game, I view it in a wholly positive light - rather than making something like EXP and Gold to be used for two separate purposes, incorporating both resource pools into one base stat increases the strategic element, and makes every expenditure that much more risky and demanding. I entered the final battle with three fully-leveled characters, and two weaker ones, simply because I had spent the renown necessary to do so along the way to ensure nobody in my caravan starved to death along the way. (Which can also say a lot about you as a person, I suppose, in terms of how you choose to spend it) At times, I would have preferred separate pools for the various resources, but only because it would have made my inherent min-maxing tendencies easier to oblige, and I cannot legitimately call out a design decision that increases complexity and the importance of a player's strategic choice.Detriments: the touted choice & consequence mechanic, while always nice to see, seems to mostly amount to extremely random and jarring consequences; each major decision seems to have one "correct" option which yields a positive outcome, and the negative consequences of "incorrect" decisions are never forewarned adequately, resulting in major impact up to and including losing substantial characters with absolutely no warning (on courses of action they themself recommend, even). Think the Witcher in terms of its unforseeability, but without the time delay or overall neutral tone which was par for the course in that game. (To be fair, there were a couple consequences - one VERY major one - which took half the game to  conclude and did have ample but not flagrant warning, so the game did this quite well in some instances, but failed in others)The combat never changes or develops in a significant way after the first battle outside of levelled-up abilities and new character classes with different special skills opening up different strategic options. What you see in the first battle is largely what you're going to get.In the combat mechanics, again, the game seems to settle in the middle; the endgame battles (especially the final boss) had me biting nails and languishing over every turn, and the beginning was not far removed, but I had comfortably established a routine throughout the middle half of the game which pretty much ensured I'd win any given battle ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥d-drunk with minimal unit injury in the process. A more level experience would be nice.A mechanic I rather like (linking health and damage output to the same attribute) has its flaw; in many situations, it is often tactically better to leave an enemy unit on the battlefield at very low HP rather than killing them outright. Due to the mechanic Il ike, their damage potential is next to nothing, but this goes against general gaming instinct and raises concerns in compliance with the point below...MIXED FEELINGS: the way the turn-based system is executed. Instead of some stat which addresses/influences initiative, the game will always go YOUR SIDE-ENEMY SIDE-YOUR SIDE-ENEMY SIDE until only one unit remains on either, at which point one side will execute all of its turns and then the other proceeds. On one hand, I like this to an extent, because it makes battles lopsided in terms of numbers not unwinnable; on the other hand, I think it's fairly backward in terms of a good mechanic; if it were kept the same throuh the last round, it would give that moment of despair when you haver one unit left against four an air of possibility, thinking if you execute well enough you can pull this situation out of the fire (or, conversely, keep you thinking your moves over in the last moments of a fight, as an enemy acting that quickly could turn your 4-1 advantage into a one-on-one exchange if you ♥♥♥♥ it up badly enough). While I do like the mechanic as a whole as opposed to the general turn-based style, it loses its punch with that particular element making the last few turns of any given fight a foregone conclusion when it could have served to bring each and every one down to the wire.ALL IN ALL: a very, very good game. I didn't catch this game's Kickstarter in time to contribute, but most likely would have, and do not at all regret spending full price for the experience once it released. I'm hoping it does well enough that multiple follow-ups/sequels are developed, so long as they equal or improve on the quality of the original. If you enjoy slower-paced games with combat more tactical and mindful than visceral and egoistic, this is a no-brain purchase that I wholeheartedly recommend. If Call of Duty is your favorite game series... 1. this is probably not for you; 2. please die as painfully as possible in a fire as soon as possible so as to possibly rectify the damage you have already done to the industry as a whole.

												The Banner Saga is a good game with very strong atmosphere and a great, dark story in a Nordic, Viking like fantasy world. Although you have to read a lot of dialogs the strategic battles are fun. The music adds a lot to the depressing atmosphere. You are permanently on the run, chased by an overwhelming foe you can not expect to defeat. The game is a narrative of your flight. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												The Banner Saga is fantastic from start to finish. Been sitting in my pile of games to play for a while, and I'm glad I finally go around to checking it out. This game combines a rich story set in a nordic mythology, turn-based combat that harkens to X-com, and survival decisions that remind me of the old Oregon Trail.Three great things about the game:- Decisions matter. They shape the way your party forms over the course of a solid 12-14 hour story.- A solid combat system that keeps action interesting- Fantastic story of the end timesIt's not without a few faults however. The surival-ESQUE gameplay is definitely in service to the story. Things like caravan supplies and army size feel inconsequential at times. Sometimes you will spend a bunch of currency on supplies for a long haul... only to have the supplies made meaningless by cutting a long journey short due to a story element. Other times you make sacrifices to keep your army numbers high, only never to fight or encounter another large army. Why? Because the story didn't call for you to run into an army yet. I would have much rather used the currency buy items or upgrade my party members. But there's no way to know when supplies and army size are actually needed, before you actually need them... making their currency system a bit of random guessworkThe story is good, so the above points are forgivable, but I would have liked to see them strike a better balance between the story, and the game-y parts.You should buy this game. You will enjoy it. Can't wait to play The Banner Saga 2.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												Oregon Trail meets Final Fantasy Tactics!-Overview-Seriously this game is very fun and has a way of drawing you in. The neatest part that will also be the most frustrating is that you cannot create save slots. So if you are at a juncture and someone dies, they stay dead in your game. Don't worry, characters that fall in combat will only be injured for an amount of days equal to how badly they got gibbed in battle (at least on normal difficulty). But sometimes people will die as a result of your actions and then they are just dead. The story is well done with some twists along the way. The setting is the real powerhouse though - it's the end of the world and you are trying to eke out some survival. It's reminiscent to zombie apocalypse games because the dredge you fight seem rather mindless. What saves it is the nordic fantasy theme and the varls. The varls are apparently a cross between human and ox, but they live for hundreds of years and are basically giants. Also they cannot reproduce anymore so the amount left is finite.-Gameplay-There are 2 main screens in the game, the traveling screen which tracks how many people, varls, and supplies you have as you trek across the landscape and the grid battle view where you fight tactical combats. Overall both of these systems work very well. I was frustrated at first by how frequently my archers and other squishies died. Now I treat them like fragile objects and play very carefully with them. It isn't worth it to run halfway across the map for a kill only to get swarmed and killed. Send the tanks in first, create a wall, then pepper them with your long-range units. Instead of getting gold and experience you acquire Renown which functions as a currency for everything in the game. Want to buy an item? Spend renown. Want to buy food supplies? Spend renown. Want to level up your army? Spend renown. Obviously you don't get enough to do it all, so you balance losing women and children with wanting to have a stronger army to fight through and save the rest of the caravan. Lots of little decisions come back later in the game too, which shows you that your choices do matter. Overall it's very fun and addicting, with a "One More Turn Style" gameplay.-Story-It just throws you into this lord of the rings inspired setting, but instead of dwarves, elves, and orcs, you get human, varl, and dredge. Along the way you start piecing together the history and relationships of the world, but rather than show a setting where the fantasy races are leaving or dying off, everything is dying off. The sun has literally stopped in the sky and people are constantly asking you what to do because its the end of the world. While this might make the whole thing seem pointless, you do get sucked into the characters and their struggle to survive through some good characterization and lots of poignant moments with your own personal choices driving the narrative.-Music-A bit halting here and there, sometimes there will be silence for a long time and then suddenly music begins! The quality of the tracks is very high though, I am usually glad when the music does come on. It's also voice-acted but I can't tell you to what extent because I prefer reading walls of texts.-Verdict-Great tactical game. If you like tactical combat and reminisce for Oregon Trail style random stuff happening then this is for you. The whole thing plods along and is very slow, so take your time with it and you will be richly rewarded. I've sat at a key decision juncture for 5 or 10 minutes trying to deduce how things will play out. Since I can't just reload and find out, it may actually get a replay out of me too. The combat is unforgiving but once you learn some tricks you'll feel unstoppable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												I absolutely loved this game, so simple and kind of reminds me of Hearthstone in the way that the Health/Armour works, although subtle differences.The artwork is pretty good although sometimes got a bit repetitive with all the snow, it made you unable to see most of the background other than the main path however when there was less snow it was beautiful atmosphere. Overall I love the cartoon feel to it.Enough of the graphics. The main thing I love about this game is the fact that the decisions you make, actually do have an effect. Not only that but it makes you think about what you want to say, Do you need another character? Do you need more suplies? What one should I choose to keep my character alive? Should I take a risk?All these questions I was asking myself as I progressed.However sometimes I felt that some decisions made no sense to me - personally - and that some were harsh as it sometimes causes some of the characters to die, it obviously has no effect on the story but it is annoying as you may have levelled that character to a high level and spent your XP points on him and then he is gone, seems like a waste.I also dislike the fact that one group of characters you get to play with are not as powerful as some of the other groups and I felt like some characters I was able to level up easier as they did more base damage, the "archer" type felt fairly useless in most circumstances as the space the "Dredge" can move is so great compared to the range of the arrows, it felt like a wasted character to me, they have low armour and low strength and it just did not gel with my preferred playstyle and also I felt like the Varl were FAR superior to the humans.However the storyline was interesting although fairly short, it also had me addicted for the 5-10 hours it lasted and I am on my second playthrough on a harder difficulty and choosing different options. It has replayability in that way.The final boss fight is extremely challenging and I enjoyed it thoroughly, with many retries, and many rages.Amazing animations in combat and although the Voice acting was scarce, it was effective when used. It could have been used more and there is A HELL OF A LOT OF READING, which I am fine with but you may not be. When speaking to people, it sometimes felt like it was drawn out and too much text but I liked it nonetheless. Requires patience.I would advise you to pick this game up, mainly if it is on sale. 100% worth $15 and less but I picked it up for $5 I think.An amazing game overall and I loved it so much while it lasted.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												Hello,I'm going to start off by saying that this is a beautiful game. By beautiful I mean soundtrack, artwork and story. It's really enjoyable and definitely worth playing. It has a very... "Authentic" feeling to it.Pros:Artwork - The artwork is beautifully drawn and everything is nicely animated. Even though a bit simple at times, even the simplicity of it all seems to blend in perfectly with everything.Music - The soundtrack is nice and gives off an appropriate vibe considering the setting, but it's not incredible. It's nice, really, but it could have been a bit more diverse.Story & Character development - The story and character development are amazing. Even though they have small flaws, everything seems somehow inevitable and most of the time you are basically doing everything to make the best out of an impossible situation. That's the real struggle. Doing the best you can - no matter how bad it is.The characters are nicely designed and some of them actually evolve in unexpected ways, even if they do scream cliché at times.Skills and attributes - These go hand to hand with their usability in combat (which I will explain below) and how much you really need to think about when you upgrade them.Combat - I assume that we've all seen this type of combat by now and its basics should come as no surprise to anyone. I like the general combat style, but what I love about it are some small touches that make it... Unique. Crippling the armour of an enemy is generally optional in games, but not here. No way. If you want to actually have a chance at slaying Dredge, then you really need to buff up your armor breaking. Also damaging an opponent will not only hurt them physically and take down their hp, but will also reduce the damage they do.I like the fact that the game forces you to weigh your decisions carefully, most of the time having to choose either damaging an opponent with a small burst for the moment or simply working your way until being able to constantly damage them for higher values.Cons:Voice acting - Although sometimes done well, a large part of the voice acting in the game could do with improving. Of course, it's understandable seeing how the actors were chosen and the fact that Stoic didn't exactly have an immense budget for this project.Decisions - This is the type of game which is, for the most part, story-driven. Generally the types of fans that play this type of game are the ones that expect their role and their decisions in the to be important. It is exactly the type of game from which fans expect every decision to be important and to have significant consequences. Don't get me wrong, they're important, obviously, but I wish that some of the decisions that ulteriorly end up with the same result to have some more depth to them. The fact that quite often anything you choose to do will lead you through the same events is not what bothers me. What bothers me is that the game is quite transparent about that and lets it off quite easily.Character leveling - I really think that they should have sticked to the standard form of leveling (Everyone who's still standing at the end of the fight will get exp), buuut they didn't. Instead you gain exp for dealing the killing blow on enemies. Normally that wouldn't be so bad, but it's just so much easier for some characters to get the kil than others, that it basically makes the process of leveling certain classes very, very difficult. There's always that one big guy, with the two-hander that comes in and beats the crap out of everything that's still standing.Equipment - Well, there's really not much I can say about the equipemnt section because it didn't actually stand out. I expected equipmented rooted into the lore of the game that can help an immense deal, but I actually got a lot of items which could situationally help... Somtimes. Some items are good, sure, but not really that much. The difference they make isn't all that noticeable if you spend your points properly.Conclusion:This is a great game, definitely worth buying if you enjoy your good ol' tacitacal turn-based. But it's more than that. It's actually a great buy if you simply enjoy a good story. Combat isn't all that difficult and it's easy to get into, even if it does, at times, get a bit tiring (I'm talking about you, people who want to try out every possible path and never want any characters to get knocked out.

												The Banner Saga is great because you develop a deep understanding of the knowledge that every situation that you're presented with in the story will result in you picking the wrong option, trying to load the game in frustration only to realise that you didn't save it soon enough, and the autosave didn't go back far enough, so then you have to leave the game entirely to break open your piggy bank, raid your mother’s jewellery box and re-mortgage your house just to find the money you need to speed down to the nearest bar, drink yourself into a bitter stupor, call everyone you know on your contact list and pour abuse at them until they swear to disown you, crawl back to your home and restart the game from the beginning. Seriously this game is the best: Concept, writing, art, music, and soul-crushing difficulty. Perfection.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												Impressive strategy RPG with beautifully hand drawn animations and travelling sequences. Choices in encounters during caravan travels add both to the story and battle strategy, introducing a population and resource management aspect which changes depending on how the player chooses to engage enemies in group battles vs using army reserves in a cautious or direct manner. The Banner Saga has turned out to be a far more charming and deeper game than I had ever expected. More and more mechanics are introduced as one gets further into the campaign. This is one of the most satisfying SRPG / adventure experiences in a long time. I had hesitated due to the price, but for the current midweek madness sale, $10 is an amazing deal. If you were holding off for any reason, now is the time to pick up this title. I see now that even the price of $14.99 or even $20 still seems very reasonable!

Posted: January 14, 2014
												Amazing art and animation. Taking inspiration from Eyvind Earle (Disney's Sleeping Beauty) gives this game a classic Disney feel. The writing is a bit slow and drawn out, borderline amateur. But overall I'm pretty happy with the game so far. The battle system is simple and well explained. It's a bit slow overall so if you're one of those "need it done now" type of people this game may not be for you. Wish there were voice acting but I shouldn't expect much from a Kickstarter game. You play multiple perspectives from the different main characters each chapter. Overall it's a very Sleeping Beauty mixed with Game of Thrones story and vibe with a heavy Viking mythology sway. Overall a pretty cool experience and one of those games you'll play and be in awe of the art direction. I hope the story pans out a little better as I progress through the story.As it stands I have NOT FINISHED the game. But from this point I'd give the game a nice clean 8/10. Mostly due to the art direction and battle system.

												Having just beaten The Banner Saga, I can now say that it will remain one of my favorites games for many years to come. The story/lore was superb, the soundtrack was fantastic ( I highly recommend getting the edition with the soundtrack), and I found myself protective of the games main characters Rook and his daughter Allete. The meat of the game revolves around balancing the level progression of your characters while also providing resources for your caravhan, which both use the same resource to manage. It can be a struggle depending on what difficulty you're playing on, but if you're just looking to enjoy the story it is very possible without sacrificing any fun. I highly recommend this game if you are a fan of turn based strategies, deep emotional stories, and worlds that are rich in lore.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												Raise your banners it's the saga... The Banner Saga.This game... There aren't a lot of fantasy settings that really get me, but this one was one of the few. It's a kind of desolate, nordic setting with some focus on a few political aspects. Love it.The game has a special art style which wasn't really my thing, but nevertheless very thorough and unique, it has a strong focus on story, but not in your typical fashion, and has a strategic HOMM/XCOM-like battle system with RPG features, like individual character levels, skills and Items.If you want about 8-12 hours of story-driven gameplay with a pretty good but not amazing combat system, this is a really good choice and the release price wasn't extremely expensive. My biggest complaints are the length and that I want a sequel to delve further into this fantasy world.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												If you're a fan of tactical strategy games, this is more than worth your time.  The grid-based fights are different from anything else I've played in the genre, tying your remaining health to your ability to do damage, incentivizing keeping your party in good health.  There's a real emphasis on fighting against a team, as a team, and once you start to hang back and create opportunities the strategic depth really shines through.The heroes/caravan/item system strung on top of the combat is well put together and systemized in a fun way, harkening back a bit to things like the Oregon trail.  There seems to be a number of decision points strung through the story that can create some interesting divergences, resulting in losing/gaining new heroes, as well as the permanent death of major characters. The animation style of the game is fantastic, 2d artwork in the style of say, old Ralph Bakshi movies from the 70s and 80s.  It's a fairly unique look for a game in this genre.  Music is fantastic, by the always on point Austin Wintory.Definitely worth your time.
