content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												I just want to say I'm completely enchanted by this game...I love the story and the lore, the thought that was put into crafting this story. I find the artwork beautiful, and the combat fun. I love the fact that my choices have consequences, even if some of the consequences are painful...when something bad happens I just consider what I might do on another play through. I find the combat interesting and somewhat complex...it is taking me a little time to figure out what each characters' strengths are and how to best use them (and I'm sure I haven't got it all sorted just yet, but I like the challenge). I'm not in a rush to finish, and am enjoying every moment. The only thing "bad" I can say is that I've read there is only about 9 hours of gameplay...I would have preferred to pay $50 and gotten a full game if that is the case. But that being said I am really loving this game and wanted to provide a different perspective to some of the naysayers. Someone said that the outcome of choices weren't "transparent" enough, lol yes, that's kind of the point I think. What fun would it be if you knew exactly what would happen with each choice you make? I like the uncertainty, I like that bad (and good!) things happen unexpectedly based on what you do. I like this game in general, and applause the devs for creating something so unique. I know that you can't please everyone, but consider me one of the pleased! Thanks! And can't wait for more <3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												The Banner Saga is probably one of the best games I've played in recent memory; the cast is made of characters who are dynamic enough to be difficult to explain in one sentence or trope, the aesthetics are a marvel for the eyes, and Austin Wintory's score for the game compliments the desolate nature of the game quite well.It's also quite nice to see a strategy game where--for the most part--turns go back and forth, almost like a game of chess, instead of moving your entire army and dominating in one turn. Many of the choices presented to you throughout the story are legitimately hard decisions to make, and the possibility of losing party members or forsaking rewards makes you think about your options, and makes each run of this game a little more unique.I do have my gripes with it though: some of the classes don't feel too unique from each other, special attacks aside, and for the most part, the story doesn't really branch out much. Your decisions do indeed affect immediate events, but you're still locked on the story progression the game wants you to take.Don't let that be a turn-off, however. I've poured nearly 12 hours into this game, and I've enjoyed each one of them.FINAL GRADE: A-Highly recommended, but there's considerable room for improvement.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												The Banner Saga is an extraordinary game. Starting with the obvious, the landscapes and soundtrack are both breathtaking and plain epic. But what what really reeled me in, even more than the wonderful and immersive atmosphere, is the storyline. Twisted, and relying so very much on the player's choices. You often don't know where you're going, what to decide, whom you should trust or not, and must rely on your own judgement (often wrong !) and guts to advance. It is such a pleasure to feel like you're are actually choosing, or creating your own path rather than following the same patterns as always ; and it's not so often that a game really makes you think twice about a choice that will (maybe) haunt you until the end... The Banner Saga is really a refreshing creation, dark indeed, but beautiful nonetheless, and takes you in without mercy. I just finished it, and already want to discover all the other paths that lie ahead... I recommend it whole-heartedly !

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Świetna gra taktyczna. Wykorzystywanie skilli i odpowiednie ustawianie wroga na planszy - klucz do zwycięstwa. Chwilę zajmuje żeby to ogarnąć. Grajcie na najwyższym poziomie trudności - trzeba nieźle kombinować. Nie ma nagrywania w każdym momencie, niektóre decyzje przynoszą efekty po kilku godzinach od jej podjęcia - to wszystko sprawia,  że gra się ciurkiem i trzeba godzić się ze swoimi wyborami. Postaci giną, odchodzą, walki trzeba powtarzać aby osiągnąć optymalny efekt. Gra raczej dla starszych graczy, bo nie prowadzi za rękę. Tutorial jest ubogi. Wszystko wychodzi w praniu. Jedna rzecz, która mnie lekko zirytowała to ostatnia walka. Fabuła narzuca udział w walce postaci, której w ogóle nie rozwijałem. Trzy dni się męczyłem i nie dałem rady - musiałem wgrać stan sprzed decyzji o tym kto bierze strzałę. Przechodzę zaraz po raz drugi na pozomie normal - pierwszy raz zagrałem na hard i ani nie rozwinąłem wszystkich postaci, ani wszystkich fajnych artefaktów nie mogłem kupić. Prawie 50h zabawy, przy czym wiele walk powtarzałem. Teraz zagram dla wygody i przyjemności - zrobię sobie dream team pakerów. Polecam - każdemu kto nie lubi banalnych gier.

Posted: June 19, 2016
												First of all, this is such a beautiful game. The art direction is fantastic and very memorable. I have played many games where developers claim that 'your decisions affect the overall game'. This is a very bold statement and most games never truly live up to it. The Banner Saga more than lives up to this statement. The story is brutal and the gameplay can be unforgiving (in a good way), which only adds to its charm. In a time where developers will often play it safe and produce what is sure to sell, The Banner Saga is an absolute breath of fresh air. What I found most interesting about this game was the world, lore and its characters. It's deep and very well structured. It truly feels like an epic journey and when tragedy does strike it's often a very powerful moment. I can't wait to experience more games within this saga. 100% recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Three things make The Banner Saga excellent:First, the setting is well done.  The plot is interesting even if, in a general sense, it is unoriginal.  It really shines in the details and nuances (especially how the plot and characters interact) and the feeling of desperation and struggle really comes through as the game progresses.  The music is exceptional.  It's epic when it needs to be without being over the top and subtle when it needs to be without being unnoticeable.  The visuals and sound effects are also solid, and I especially enjoyed the animation style that Stoic used for this game.Second, the choices.  Your choices really drive this game in a way I haven't seen in many others.  Sure you have games where you're faced with a choice that may have implications later, but they're usually easy choices that are morally unambiguous and where the repercussions easy to predict.  In the Banner Saga choices are not so easy.  Choices that seem to be clear and easily made result in unexpected consequences sometimes immediately, sometimes not until much later in the game.  Other choices are just difficult.  The consequences of your choices can be serious as well.  For example, one plot choice I made early in the game resulted in the death of two of my characters much later in the game.  There's also the constant choice of what to do with your primary resource in the game.  It's very limited and you have to decide if you are going to use it to make your characters more powerful or make sure your party can eat for another few days.  You'll be sitting there, sometimes agonizing over your choices and wishing the game were more obvious but loving the fact that it isn't.Finally, the combat.  I like the system a lot.  If you've played turn-based, party-focused combat games before, the basic mechanics are essentially the same.  But there's enough thrown in there to change how you fight and make things interesting.  For example, a unit's health and damage potential are linked (same stat) so the more a character is wounded the less damage that character can do to another character's health.  This alone is an interesting element but you also have another factor with armor mitigating damage to the point where, if a character's armor is high enough, you may not be able to damage that character at all.  This forces you to figure out if it's better to inflict less health damage on an enemy, making him weaker but keeping him in the fight, or if it's better to risk that same enemy being able to do higher damage to your party while you soften him up for a death blow.  Add to that special abilities that are varied and can take some clever playing to set up for maximum effectiveness and you have a combat system that is both consistent enough to get the hang of and become proficient at, but also varied enough to keep things interesting.But there is a bit of bad with the good:First, the game is pretty short.  I was actually surprised when I beat it, and for $20 I think this game could have included a bit more content.  I didn't time myself but it probably took me between 12 and 15 hours to beat the game.  There's some replayability with the fact that there are so many choices to be made and you could spend hours exploring them all but, being so plot-driven, once you've experienced the plot, repeated playthroughs become more mechanical than anything else.Second, this game could have benefitted greatly from a skirmish mode.  There is something of a skirmish mode with the Training Tent, but the only variables you control there are the party you bring and this is limited by where you are in the game, who you have in your party, what their levels are, and what items you've obtained.  A separate skirmish mode where you could set up your own custom battles would have been perfect and enhanced the replayability of the game by giving the player the opportunity to explore all the aspects of the combat system they're interested in, or just hop in and smash some skulls for fun.All in all, I really enjoyed this game and am excited for the sequel.  If an excellent setting and interesting plot are your thing, this game has them.  If you're interested in a game where your choices can have a serious impact on how your game plays, this game does that.  If you're even just into turn-based combat RPGs, this is one worthy of your time.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Don't get me wrong - I am not dissing the game. Let me say that this game is pretty cute, it has a nice story and a few intuitive dilemmas... but more non-intuitve or at least not intuitive and a lot of random in the effects. All in all the choices you make doesn't really influence the story at all.A game that claimed that choices matter is the walking dead games. The graphic there is more advanced so I kind of realized that wouldn't work. The bragging of my choices being important turned out to be m00t to the point I felt it was dishonest as it never mattered who I saved, or even if i made smart choices. The only thing that changed was a few lines of text or audio about other peoples attitude.Ok, back on topic. The banner saga doesn't brag itself to death, but have the same marketing and consequence issues. It really doesn't matter much what I do, the game will end the same and mostly it will play out the same. As someone else pointed out, not caring about the caravan doesn't really matter either. This makes me get bored in conversations AND mostly in dilemmas as it really doesn't matter for my success. Now, success isn't the only thing that is fun... but to me asking me to make choices that are purely or 95% cosmetical makes me think that they could have skipped it and showed me a movie instead.Another thing that annoys me is when the game makes me feel that I have failed due to random events. I spend renownd to level people that simply just die on me 8lr leave like Elof). Not because I made the wrong decision, but because the movie ..ehrm.. the game I *cough* is scripted that way. So I end up losing hordes of renown and cannot level the character the game arbitrary let me keep because the developers choose to kill off character in the story.I have nothing against the story telling aspect of killing off characters... but then I shouldn't lose because I choose to level those characters and not others. That is just... random. The same issue goes with new characters. To be able to use them I should not have leveled the others so much. The point of having many to choose from is m00t as you cannot leve everyone so you are better of sticking with the generally best characters (that you guess won't die or replay after you know which will) and optimize from there. That makes the game poorer from a tacical and diversity stand point.The game is (again) a nice story telling game, with feeling. Too much time sinks for me and unfortunately too little consequence of my actions that make me care enough to read the conversations. I would give it a 6/10 (well not compared to normal judgin where people seem to always give 9 or 10 if they like something. I use the full scale) for those who cares about my opinion. I don't regret buying it, but I am not longing for a sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												Be aware that you are going to play this game for about 8 hours and absolutely love it, and then you'll be left dumbfounded by the direction it suddenly takes. As I said, you'll love it; that is if you like the idea of a role-playing turn-based strategy game in which almost every character has their own unique abilities, and thus worth to a battle. Characters level up like in typical RPGs and you can equip them with stat-enhancing gear (only one though, and the highest level is 5). You'll quickly decide your front 6 and rarely deviate from it.You will also learn that this game outright hates you, dealing you pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cards when you are called upon to make a decision. Not always ♥♥♥♥♥♥, however - some lead almost nowhere. But this where the story is primarily told, and because of these infrequent horrible decisions, and the occasional story-affecting choices, the saga feels like it's yours. I'm quite confident that someone out there has done precisely the same things as I did in this game, but, whilst I was playing it, it didn't feel that way.The art style is pretty. Think 50's-80's Disney style stationary art with basic movements programmed in for battles, but with the minimal, yet highly appreciated, foreground and background falling snow to give it an easy 3D effect. Nice all around.My only beef with this game is it's story, particularly the ending. It just ends to soon to put it plainly. Any self-respecting storywriter (who knows or does not know that they may be writing a trilogy) would not have ended it in this way. So many great and interesting angles are left unexplored and hardly explained! The Gods are dead (not much of a spoiler as it's right at the beginning of the game) and yet no explanation is offered. The sun has stopped moving (again, beginning) and no explanation is offered. The (apparent) main boss is introduced 2/3 of the way through without any previous hinting of how significant he's going to be. Why? Because his significance is paired with his existence. Very poor. And it's not even like he's a good main boss: there is a literal earth-shatterer that would have made for a killer main boss!The storywriters need firing for this one. Actually, just fire the ones who argued that it should end in this way because they need to go back to junior school. I don't care if a trilogy had been in the plan the whole time, a good story does not introduce a key aspect of the storyline and then just do nothing with it.I do recommend this though. It's a great game. The tone is excellent and it really feels like your saga. When you finish in a day (if your dedicated enough) you'll see what I mean by just how ♥♥♥♥ing disgraceful the ending is.

												I found this to be a challenging and enjoyable strategy/rpg game, which storywise managed to capture the feel of the old nordic myths. content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Basically, the game has three things about it that make it great:1: The visuals2: The soundtrack3: The storyAll of these things on their own are amazing, but its how they work together that really make this game shine. Throughout the game you're travelling through these vast, beautiful landscapes that make you want to hope in and explore them yourself. The soundtrack however, really drives home this bleak feeling of foreboding which contrasts with the visuals spectacularly. The story is filled with twists, turns, decisions which are going to pull at your heartstrings and characters who you care about. You're taking this long, ardous journey through this beautiful world, but you're being followed by something that won't stop until it has destroyed you. You're going to be making decisions for a lot of people and some of them are going to get hurt. When you combine these three things together, you're left with a game that you won't forget anytime soon.I'm really, really looking forward to what the next chapter will bring.

content:
Posted: April 7
												One of the best games in my library!I actually prefer the story line of this game to the second - there are so many powerful and dramatic moments, and it keeps it relatively simple, which in a way is what makes it so touching. The actual fighting mechanics are great, and have some very interesting features to play around, but I didn't find it to be the main selling point of the game.The aesthetic to this game is a work of art (so many overwhelming backgrounds), massive amounts of replayability due to all of the different paths to choose from, but most of all a soundtrack that defies the genre. Austin Wintory must have been so inspired to produce such an imaginative and engaging score, and a very wide variety of colourful motifs. The score to both this game and the sequel are some of Austin's greatest game scores to date, possibly only beaten by his score for Abzu, which is some of the most descriptive and moving music written for games, and perhaps ever (although my laptop could never run the game, so I couldn't really review the actual game).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												One part tactical combat, one part RPG, one part Oregon Trail. The game has an intense storyline that makes the player really feel the urgency of the characters. Part of this is due to the way "renown," or the game's version of XP works. Renown can either be spent leveling up your characters OR on supplies to keep people alive -- and there's never quite enough renown to go around. The use of scarce resources works really well into the storyline and even more into the player's decisions of what to do. I'm not really much of a tactical combat fan so I was surprised by how much I really enjoyed the game. The best part, however, are the really amazing visuals (outside of cutscenes). I plan on playing through the game a second time just so I can screencap some of the scenes. And even better than the graphics? The music. Really the only thing I could complain about is that the end of the game doesn't really feel like an ending. It's more of a resolution to the current situation than a resolution to the entire storyline. Of course, this may mean a sequel in the future!

												This game is a combination of beautiful artwork, wonderful music and sound stimulation, and several different gaming style compiled into one. it successfully combines the tactical, almost chess-like gameplay that other games such as Fire Emblem are known to use in one way or another, as well as the caluclating numbers games that have been a staple to the gaming world for ages. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												Be aware that you are going to play this game for about 8 hours and absolutely love it, and then you'll be left dumbfounded by the direction it suddenly takes. As I said, you'll love it; that is if you like the idea of a role-playing turn-based strategy game in which almost every character has their own unique abilities, and thus worth to a battle. Characters level up like in typical RPGs and you can equip them with stat-enhancing gear (only one though, and the highest level is 5). You'll quickly decide your front 6 and rarely deviate from it.You will also learn that this game outright hates you, dealing you pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cards when you are called upon to make a decision. Not always ♥♥♥♥♥♥, however - some lead almost nowhere. But this where the story is primarily told, and because of these infrequent horrible decisions, and the occasional story-affecting choices, the saga feels like it's yours. I'm quite confident that someone out there has done precisely the same things as I did in this game, but, whilst I was playing it, it didn't feel that way.The art style is pretty. Think 50's-80's Disney style stationary art with basic movements programmed in for battles, but with the minimal, yet highly appreciated, foreground and background falling snow to give it an easy 3D effect. Nice all around.My only beef with this game is it's story, particularly the ending. It just ends to soon to put it plainly. Any self-respecting storywriter (who knows or does not know that they may be writing a trilogy) would not have ended it in this way. So many great and interesting angles are left unexplored and hardly explained! The Gods are dead (not much of a spoiler as it's right at the beginning of the game) and yet no explanation is offered. The sun has stopped moving (again, beginning) and no explanation is offered. The (apparent) main boss is introduced 2/3 of the way through without any previous hinting of how significant he's going to be. Why? Because his significance is paired with his existence. Very poor. And it's not even like he's a good main boss: there is a literal earth-shatterer that would have made for a killer main boss!The storywriters need firing for this one. Actually, just fire the ones who argued that it should end in this way because they need to go back to junior school. I don't care if a trilogy had been in the plan the whole time, a good story does not introduce a key aspect of the storyline and then just do nothing with it.I do recommend this though. It's a great game. The tone is excellent and it really feels like your saga. When you finish in a day (if your dedicated enough) you'll see what I mean by just how ♥♥♥♥ing disgraceful the ending is.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												[+] Interesting blend of convoy management, adventure game dialogue choices & turn-based tactical combat[+] Beautiful art & animation via rotoscoping[+] Expansive lore, spent a while poking around the immense map of the world[+] New take of tactical combat with concept of health & armor as well as bigger-sized units[-] 2D art style prevents rotation of scene, often resulting in smaller units and enemy traps being obfuscated[-] Convoy management meta-game seemed pointless[-] Lack of quality-of-life features such as inventory management before battles & enemy team movement/combat range during combat[-] Frustrating difficulty spike in final battle that resulted me lowering the difficulty to complete the gameDespite what seems like a mixed bag, the game, which I bought initially to support Stoic's stance against King.com, hooked me in for hours of fun. I'm still looking forward to the next part of the Banner Saga.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												There is so much that made me want to love this game. However, the strength system is horribly unbalanced heavily favoring units like warhawks while units like archers have little recourse once an enemy is upon them. Couple this with the fact that units you invest in can very abruptly die via text menu decisions and you've laid the path for a brutally unlikable experience. I'm also not terribly fond of the inability to move after issuing a command nor am I fond of chain battles when there isn't any sort of healing. Not being able to move through my own units was also not well thought out.While you can advance units by spending Renown on them it quickly becomes expensive and the stat points you're allowed to allocate are sparse at best. Couple this with the fact that a unit can leave or die at any time and I have to wonder why anyone would bother. As well, the save system is janky as hell. Want to save and come back whenever you like? Too bad - you're back at the start of the chapter. I guess now you can maybe stop that party member from abruptly dying. Sloppy decisions. It's a shame - the game is beautiful.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Verdict: Many of the reviews on Steam do this game a massive disservice. I understand, I do. It's not what they were expecting. Like most gamers, they want to feel empowered, feel like they are affecting the outcome in meaningful and tangible ways. This is not that kind of game. This game is about disempowerment and despair, accepting consequences you cannot change, and showing resilience in the face of the end of the world. Most of the choices are between outcomes that are bad or worse, and you will feel like you have chosen poorly very, very often. But therein lies the magic of this game; when you fail 9/10 times, the 10th time brings incredible pathos when you miraculously succeed against terrible odds, when a comrade unexpectedly returns, when you find that timely cache of supplies to sustain your march just one more day. It is an emotional antidote to the automatic success meted out by most video games these days. I can't recommend the Banner Saga enough. It is one of the most engaging and affecting experiences I have had in a game. 10/10Story: This game is driven far less by the story as defined by specific plot elements, and far more so by the general feeling it engenders through its overall presentation. Information is seldom just handed out; as the player you have to infer a great deal from subtle hints. Characters are elusive and rarely forthcoming but, even if their role is brief, most hint at significant hidden depth. Many things are left open and unexplained in the end, and that is exactly how it should be. 9/10Gameplay:  There are two main elements to the gameplay: the simulation element where you manage resources and make decisions for your followers, and the turn-based (and sometimes punishing) tactical battles. The simulation part is simple, but wrenching. There are never enough resources to go around, and never a simple choice. Consequences are unforeseen and permanent. The tactical part is standard but given added depth by the armour-break system. Some players will be frustrated by the criminally short range of archers and other distance fighters, but it feels right that there is no hiding on the battlefield. Battles often feel unfair, but that fits the game perfectly. It’s one of the first games where, when a hero dies, I accept and mourn the loss rather than reloading an earlier save. 8/10Graphics: The art and presentation is the soul of this game, and it would not feel the same without it. Everything is rendered in a beautiful, hand-drawn style, with layered backgrounds to add a sense of depth and distance. 10/10Sound/Music: The sound and music are both excellent, and the soundtrack is worth downloading. The ambiance in every scene is incredibly atmospheric and immersive, despite its simplicity. Less is more in this game, and sometimes there is nothing more solemn than a winter wind.  10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Don't get me wrong - I am not dissing the game. Let me say that this game is pretty cute, it has a nice story and a few intuitive dilemmas... but more non-intuitve or at least not intuitive and a lot of random in the effects. All in all the choices you make doesn't really influence the story at all.A game that claimed that choices matter is the walking dead games. The graphic there is more advanced so I kind of realized that wouldn't work. The bragging of my choices being important turned out to be m00t to the point I felt it was dishonest as it never mattered who I saved, or even if i made smart choices. The only thing that changed was a few lines of text or audio about other peoples attitude.Ok, back on topic. The banner saga doesn't brag itself to death, but have the same marketing and consequence issues. It really doesn't matter much what I do, the game will end the same and mostly it will play out the same. As someone else pointed out, not caring about the caravan doesn't really matter either. This makes me get bored in conversations AND mostly in dilemmas as it really doesn't matter for my success. Now, success isn't the only thing that is fun... but to me asking me to make choices that are purely or 95% cosmetical makes me think that they could have skipped it and showed me a movie instead.Another thing that annoys me is when the game makes me feel that I have failed due to random events. I spend renownd to level people that simply just die on me 8lr leave like Elof). Not because I made the wrong decision, but because the movie ..ehrm.. the game I *cough* is scripted that way. So I end up losing hordes of renown and cannot level the character the game arbitrary let me keep because the developers choose to kill off character in the story.I have nothing against the story telling aspect of killing off characters... but then I shouldn't lose because I choose to level those characters and not others. That is just... random. The same issue goes with new characters. To be able to use them I should not have leveled the others so much. The point of having many to choose from is m00t as you cannot leve everyone so you are better of sticking with the generally best characters (that you guess won't die or replay after you know which will) and optimize from there. That makes the game poorer from a tacical and diversity stand point.The game is (again) a nice story telling game, with feeling. Too much time sinks for me and unfortunately too little consequence of my actions that make me care enough to read the conversations. I would give it a 6/10 (well not compared to normal judgin where people seem to always give 9 or 10 if they like something. I use the full scale) for those who cares about my opinion. I don't regret buying it, but I am not longing for a sequel.

												One part tactical combat, one part RPG, one part Oregon Trail. The game has an intense storyline that makes the player really feel the urgency of the characters. Part of this is due to the way "renown," or the game's version of XP works. Renown can either be spent leveling up your characters OR on supplies to keep people alive -- and there's never quite enough renown to go around. The use of scarce resources works really well into the storyline and even more into the player's decisions of what to do. I'm not really much of a tactical combat fan so I was surprised by how much I really enjoyed the game. The best part, however, are the really amazing visuals (outside of cutscenes). I plan on playing through the game a second time just so I can screencap some of the scenes. And even better than the graphics? The music. Really the only thing I could complain about is that the end of the game doesn't really feel like an ending. It's more of a resolution to the current situation than a resolution to the entire storyline. Of course, this may mean a sequel in the future!

content:
Posted: April 7
												One of the best games in my library!I actually prefer the story line of this game to the second - there are so many powerful and dramatic moments, and it keeps it relatively simple, which in a way is what makes it so touching. The actual fighting mechanics are great, and have some very interesting features to play around, but I didn't find it to be the main selling point of the game.The aesthetic to this game is a work of art (so many overwhelming backgrounds), massive amounts of replayability due to all of the different paths to choose from, but most of all a soundtrack that defies the genre. Austin Wintory must have been so inspired to produce such an imaginative and engaging score, and a very wide variety of colourful motifs. The score to both this game and the sequel are some of Austin's greatest game scores to date, possibly only beaten by his score for Abzu, which is some of the most descriptive and moving music written for games, and perhaps ever (although my laptop could never run the game, so I couldn't really review the actual game).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Well.First things first: it's short, it's part of a trilogy so this is merely chapter one. Kind of irks me that the price for a single chapter is the better part of $25 but I also hope they're going to offer the following chapters as DLC. Otherwise this is a massive cash-grab.That being said - wow. An amazingly well-constructed world and lore out the wazoo. Grammatical errors and switching from second- and third-person narratives willy-nilly aside, the story was also very well written. My skin crawled and shivered several times during the playthrough.I had moments where I wanted to throw my keyboard at the game. I wanted to quit, to uninstall it and leave it to rot in my basement where I would keep it until such a time where I had forgotten the injustice it had done to me and I would allow it a glimmer of sunlight once more. But I didn't. I decided it wasn't the game, it was me. I felt like a victim of household abuse. If the companions I had fought so hard to keep alive suddenly died because of a wrong decision by me, then it's my fault. Mine and mine alone. I learned to live with my regrets, learned to cope with them and keep going; by far, the best thing the creators of the game could have done was not have a savegame feature. You live with the consequences of your choices - and more often than not, there's always a second side to the story. The story ended just as it had begun to make a small portion of sense, though by asking more questions than answering them. I went back to the title screen and was about to hit "Restart" when a message popped up - "If you restart the game, all your previous decisions will be overwritten". I stopped. Yes, I can go back and play the game and know what to expect now, and probably make a lot less of a fool of myself by making better decisions. But then, it wouldn't be the experience it was meant to be. The experience of putting you in a world that is dying, possibly already dead, where your only hope is to survive; to save a few lives on the way is a bonus, but hard decisions will need to be made. Hard decisions that will stick with you, long after you've finished playing the game. So I didn't restart it, and my ill-conceived decisions are going to sit there until Chapter 2, where I can relive them again. And I will miss some characters dearly, while others I will not bat an eyelid to. This is what a great game is meant to encourage. In a bleak world where the hopelesness and fear seem to be the only constant, where even mountains can be torn asunder, you cling on to the fact that though you may have sacrificed a few men, you survived. And that's all that matters.Because don't you know, the Gods are dead?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												I want more! Thank you to everyone who "Kickstarted" this beautiful gem. The art, story and music completely pulls you in to this dark and wintery world full of beared humans and horned giants struggling to survive. Getting use to the combat takes a bit of trial and error, but there is something about the mechanics that i prefer over other grid based games. There are minimum dice rolls, so it feels much more like chess where positioning of units are vital.The game does have some flaws though. Keeping your caravan alive and well fed while leveling up your units is a pain.. yet there is little consequence other than low morale when you start losing clansmen due to no supplies. I also felt like the Dredge should have had more unit variety in combat.Overall "The Banner Saga" has made it into my top 10 favorite games and i will eagerly await the next chapter of this saga.

												Amazing art, soundtrack, story, and characters. Fun combat. Harsh choices, though wish there were more of them with not so many just related to losing battles. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												The Banner Saga is by far one of the greatest games I have ever played. The combat is engaging and challenging and once you get a feel for it you waste no time in placing your units exactly where you want them to go. The story is gripping, if a little sad; It allows to you connect to the characters through the main protagonist, Rook, and then takes away some of them who you had come to rely on. The most difficult thing I fould were the different choices you had to make, because no matter which one you ended up choosing you ended up taking the consequences, good or bad, for your actions. One thing I didn't like was the way you had to choose the difficulty of the game. Choosing the difficulty of the game is never an easy thing to do especially when you haven't had any experience in the game, and choosing easy feels like the short road out. Normal mode challenges you a fair bit, while hard mode I've never beaten and would recommend only those who are willing to invest a very serious amount of time into it. Aside from the difficulty the mechanics, story, and overall theme of the game make this a great experience for any who enjoy tactical rpg games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												There are not many games that can boast being remotely as beautiful, challenging, and atmospheric as The Banner Saga.The Banner Saga is, at its core, a turn-based RPG. The turn-based combat is conducted on a "game board" with square spaces for your units to occupy. Truthfully, The Banner Saga's combat works well enough, but it's not anything special - there's nothing innovative or exceptional about it. It serves its purpose well enough, is fun, and offers some challenge. What makes The Banner Saga so wonderful is just about everything else about it.It's difficult to summarize all of the aspects The Banner Saga does really well. Right off the bat however, you'll probably notice both the art and audio of the game are fantastic. It's rare to find a game that creates a unique artistic vision and implements it so well, while still managing to include a great, effective soundtrack. It's probably fair to say a lot of games struggle with nailing either one of these, let alone both. But, The Banner Saga creates a beautiful, deeply atmospheric experience with its classically inspired animation visuals and moving soundtrack. Of course, this could be all for nothing if it's being used to prop-up a weak story; fortunately, it isn't.If I'm being honest, I don't think I could name another game that comes close to creating such an oppressive story and atmosphere. The pacing of The Banner Saga is excellent; there's a true feeling of dread and desperation constantly building from chapter to chapter as you try to make (what you think are) the best decisions for your caravan, while fighting through seemingly impossible odds. This is a game full of choices - who to accept into your caravan, who to help, when and where to camp, who to take with you into battle - there are many, often tough, decisions that you'll have to make. All of these decisions are presented well, and all of them have consequences, some dire. This makes each playthrough potentially unique.In The Banner Saga, the world is crashing down around you, and you're left facing insurmountable odds. It will be up to you to lead men, women, and varl. You'll make many decisions, some of which you may come to regret. The world of The Banner Saga is bleak and grim. It's hard not to look at this game with a sense of both wonder and despair, and for that it's impossible for me not to recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												Be aware that you are going to play this game for about 8 hours and absolutely love it, and then you'll be left dumbfounded by the direction it suddenly takes. As I said, you'll love it; that is if you like the idea of a role-playing turn-based strategy game in which almost every character has their own unique abilities, and thus worth to a battle. Characters level up like in typical RPGs and you can equip them with stat-enhancing gear (only one though, and the highest level is 5). You'll quickly decide your front 6 and rarely deviate from it.You will also learn that this game outright hates you, dealing you pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cards when you are called upon to make a decision. Not always ♥♥♥♥♥♥, however - some lead almost nowhere. But this where the story is primarily told, and because of these infrequent horrible decisions, and the occasional story-affecting choices, the saga feels like it's yours. I'm quite confident that someone out there has done precisely the same things as I did in this game, but, whilst I was playing it, it didn't feel that way.The art style is pretty. Think 50's-80's Disney style stationary art with basic movements programmed in for battles, but with the minimal, yet highly appreciated, foreground and background falling snow to give it an easy 3D effect. Nice all around.My only beef with this game is it's story, particularly the ending. It just ends to soon to put it plainly. Any self-respecting storywriter (who knows or does not know that they may be writing a trilogy) would not have ended it in this way. So many great and interesting angles are left unexplored and hardly explained! The Gods are dead (not much of a spoiler as it's right at the beginning of the game) and yet no explanation is offered. The sun has stopped moving (again, beginning) and no explanation is offered. The (apparent) main boss is introduced 2/3 of the way through without any previous hinting of how significant he's going to be. Why? Because his significance is paired with his existence. Very poor. And it's not even like he's a good main boss: there is a literal earth-shatterer that would have made for a killer main boss!The storywriters need firing for this one. Actually, just fire the ones who argued that it should end in this way because they need to go back to junior school. I don't care if a trilogy had been in the plan the whole time, a good story does not introduce a key aspect of the storyline and then just do nothing with it.I do recommend this though. It's a great game. The tone is excellent and it really feels like your saga. When you finish in a day (if your dedicated enough) you'll see what I mean by just how ♥♥♥♥ing disgraceful the ending is.

												If you like a good story, some moving moments, interesting characters and excellent strategy (much like chess), this is for you!It is not sandbox, but your choices will change the character roster and they will make a difference in several battles you'll fight. The art is... how can I put it? It's beautiful in its simplicity. Not style-beautiful, universally beautiful. Go on, take a peek. You deserve it. You owe this to yourself. Man, this game kept me going, and kept me hooked!Totally recommended!P.S.: going through TBS 2 now. Where's 3, guys? C'moooon! ;)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												This is a great game to grab if you own a macbook pro or an air. I play it on PC too with no problems. It runs great, plays very well with other apps, slipping in and out of full screen nicely (at least on OS X Mavericks). It's also gorgeous. And hard... very hard. There are few games I've dropped back to easy mode on but I was getting so frustrated with not being able to progress in the story that I did. And it has still been challenging. Lots of branches in the story and different characters to level so the replayability looks very good. Did I mention it's gorgeous? Maybe it's because I'm a father with a daughter of my own, but I also found the storyline between Rook and Alette to be quite touching. There is little actual spoken dialogue but what there is makes me wish they had been able to do more, especially for some of the characters, not just the narrator. I think the only thing that bothers me a little sometimes is the isometric view can get a bit mucky in big fights with a lot of characters and I would love to be able to see things easier. I think that is the only gripe I can think of. I hope the people that made this game keep making more. Best money I've spent for some time.

content:
Posted: April 22
												It's a gorgeous game, in every possible way.At first I was pretty skeptical, as the art style reminded me of something out of the old Rankin/Bass cartoons - but I warmed up to it really quickly when the game began. There's a really elegant way things look, move, and even sound in the game that contributes to a rock-solid 'gestalt'.The tactical elements of combat aren't crazy deep, but engaging enough to hold you in between the real highlights- the phenomenal story bits. There a lot of story and lore going in the game that doesn't come across as ham-fisted at all, and there's a distressingly real sense of permanence with each choice you come across in your journey. Wither its a short term hit or boon to your stats- or a huge branch in the story that occurs 9 hours of playing later, everything feels like part of a bigger picture.Very cool game that left me hungry for the sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Game of Thrones meets Oregon Trail. In the short amount of time it takes you to play through this game (my hours are inflated due to leaving the game on pause) you’ll grow attached to many of the characters and be crushed when they’re maimed or die. The Banner Saga’s art is very well done, it reminded me a little bit of the Asterix comics I would read as a kid, and the storyline is solid. I don’t mind the degree of randomness inherent in this game - you are after all playing as a group of refugees fleeing for survival - but the combat is a real drawback. It’s supposed to be turn-based strategy, but even after beating the game on normal I only vaguely understand how you're meant to play. Not that it seems to matter that much. The one time I lost a battle my party kept marching along regardless.The Banner Saga is definitely worth playing, just buy it on sale, it’s not quite worth the $20 asking price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												I waited to review the game after completing it. I loved playing it from start to finish. In order to give you a sense of what this game is about I will use keywords that describe the game.- Tactical gameplay: Final Fantasy tactics / XCOM style (turn based moves)- Choices matter: throughout the game you need to make choices which will have consequences in situations- The game is difficult, played it on normal and found it challenging.- RPG: you level up, can gear your units (limited, but enough imo).- You can clear the campaign in estimated 15 hours (normal mode, might take longer if its difficult),- Amazing and unique art and music. Loved every second of it.- Story rich: the story is solid. Loved it and it was very interesting.- Alot of reading texts and making decisions based on themThe developers put alot of effort into the game and it is visible. From the story to the art to the music, it was all in line. The game has some minor flaws, but which game doesn't? What is important is that the game has an amazing and heartfelt story with enjoying gameplay. Funny thing is: the game was brought to live through kickstarter, which makes the entire game more amazing. If the keywords earlier spark your interest, I would suggest you buy the game. You will not regret! P.S. There will be a sequal (announced on E3)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												Background: It is in the realm of games like Fire Emblem and Final Fantasy Tactics.Replayability: Some story changes can allow you to bypass or experience new things but overall the game shines in its Storyline.  Low Replayability.Combat Mechanics:  Standard Grid based, range oriented, simplified stat mechanical battles. Each character has a specific set of abilities and death and failure are very easy to attain even on Easy Mode. Not much Class overlap as the cast of characters is Small but this makes them memorable as you progress through the 10-15 hour story.Social Mechanics: Social interaction plays a big part in who you recruit, battles you fight, who dies...sorry for the minor spoiler, but look you're humans running from an unstoppable horde of shadow soldiers and its dead Winter.  People are gonna die from swords and starvation.Notable Notes: Oh my gosh the Artwork in this game is RIDICULOUS. Like I got distracted by the look at feel of the paintings. Even the Combat Grid and atmosphere is just a thrill ride of pure unadulterated Artistic Expression.  It reminds me of the same feeling I had when I first picked up Okami back in the day.Final Thoughts: Those of us old guys from the 90s who have fond memories on the GameBoy Advance slugging through the massive influx of Grid based JRPGs will find a ray of light in the Banner Saga. <3 Play well my friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												Rating: 8/10Budget: It's a fairly short game, so get it on sale. Length: Very short I think. Replayability: Moderate to low. This game is actually incredibly good, I personally think. The combat system is nice, the travel and dialogue system is also cool. I like the "choices=consequences" sub-genre, and this is a shining example. Unfortunately, the game suffers from a majority of extremely annoying setbacks, such as practically no background info on the extremely weird world you play in, a tutorial that quite simply DOESN'T explain in detail how to play this game properly and finally that it sort of just ends right when it was getting exciting. It seems cheap to me, to end the game where it ends. Like they sold me half a game, and now expect me to buy the sequel. Which I probably will, so of course, there is nothing wrong with their marketing tactics... You're expected to make educated choices without having ANYTHING to base those choices on. You. first of all. do not know anything about this fantasy world, you try to plan trips but you're not really informed how many times you can expect to be able to resupply on your trips. Someone in your group of people, must necessarily have been somewhere and have a clue that a village is coming up in the next 3 days or something, right? Alas no! Everytime you come to a village, it's like it's the first time that village has ever been discovered, even though you're somehow leading the people along a road you're familiar with. To get back to what I like about the game, the consequences are severe and brutal. Very harsh. You can, like in Mass Effect 2, essentially get pretty much everyone killed. The story goes on - it just gets sadder. I really didn't like one of the main characters, so I just sort of.. Got rid of that character. My entire game experience was improved as a result. Win! All in all - This game is very good, but expect to have to do a test run of the game. Sit down, play for a full hour and call it a tutorial - Don't ever load/save. Just play. Then, restart the game now that you get it, and have SO much more fun with it, than you otherwise would.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												Prior to playing this, I didn't really know what to expect from "The Banner Saga". All I had seen was TotalBiscuit's "WTF is..." video and I knew it was something of a Tactical RPG... with a lot of story involved.Now, after have played the game from beginning to end, I don't regret buying it. Not a single bit. I love storydriven games and this game has got a GREAT story that keeps the player engaged in the characters and the world the game takes place in. The story is mostly told through text so it is somewhat of a visual novel at times, but that didn't bother me just because of the great... yeah, you get it.Often do you run into enemies who wants to kill you and you have to take part in turn based combat. I read that some players found the system in the game to be bad, but I found it to be pretty good and kept the tactical aspect of the game alive, it never came down to a battle being TOO easy or anything like that.The graphics are hand drawn and looks A-M-A-Z-I-N-G! I LOVE IT! The soundtrack is great as well, the voice acting (the little there is) is great. Nothing to complain about here. Well... maybe we could ask for some more animations in the dialogue scenes but hey, you can't have everything, right?I've heard there will be a "The Banner Saga 2" this or the next year... I'm so looking forward to that and I will totally pre-order that game so I won't miss the continuation of this dramatic story. I truly do recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												I recommend for fans of the tactics/RPG genre.+Good story/lore, solid combat+Turn-based tactics with RPG elements as characters level+Varying difficulty levels to choose from, battles require some strategy+Fair number of choices in-game on managing your caravan with definite consequences-Flash-based makes for some limitations - no options for resolution, few in-game A/V options at all, some stutter-Save system needs work; no manual saves, it saves on exit and at checkpoints but doesn't tell you when-Animation decent overall but notably sparse and lacking detail at times-Fairly short in length, ~15hrs or so

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1
												The Banner Saga's art style is what initially drew me to the game. I loved the beautiful hand drawn backrounds and 80's cartoon style cutscenes. However few and far between they were.  The characters in The Banner Saga are also all hand drawn and look fantastic, With slight movements to give each of  them some life and characteristics. The only frustration I have with the art style would be that I wanted more. More animation. More cartoon style cut scenes,. I guess wanting more is a good thing.There is not much to say about The Banner Saga's music exept that it is incredible. A perfect soundtrack.  If you really like the music on offer the soundtrack is avaliable to purchase alongside the game.The Banner Saga's story is one of doom and glome. A dying world under siege. You will play as aViking leader in charge of a caravan. Trying to outrun or defeat the drege menace, who has begun to poor across the world (again). It will be your decisions that decide the fate of the 100's of people in you company. including main story characters who can die perminatly and will not show up in future Banner Saga games.From the first moments of the game you will notice that Banner Saga's overall story is pretty weak, The overall narative it is trying to tell is fuzzy at best. leaving to many unanswered questions and plot points that pop up out of nowhere.  That said, the game regains most of its glory in its character stories. Making you care at least a little about the people your are in charge of. Watching one of the main chracters charge head long into certain death. Axe at the ready. Was one of the best feelings I had in the game. It's  the decision making and tense moments between life and death of a chracter that will keep the story intresting.The games ifficulty settings can make The Banner Saga a brezze. Or an absolute chore. On easy difficulty the game is basicly story mode. Allowing players to march through the various battles and challanges without having many wounded characters. On Hard mode however the games difficulty ramps up so much so that the game can feel unfair at times. In my playthrough for example. I had so many playable characters, that I couldn't level them all effectivly. Leaving four or five of them far to weak to help in combat. This is a small gripe considering that you can simply prioritize a few characters, but it would have been nice to see some of the other bad♥♥♥♥♥vikings swinging thier axes in battle.That brings us to the combat . On offer here is a Tactical Turn Based system. In which the player,  alternates moving or attacking with one of thier characters, then the enemy takes a turn,. Moving and fighting this way until the battle is over.  Combat uses some unique mechanics I will not delve into here, but veterans of turn based games will pick them up quickly and new comers to tactics games will learn durning early few battles.Now Don't get me wrong combat in The Banner Saga is fun and most of the time engaging and tactical, but some of that is taken away toward the middle and end half of the game. I played The Banner Saga on hard Difficulty, and boy was it ever a challange. I lost so many seemingly unbeatable fights that I 'll admit I Iowered the difficulty a few times just so I wouldn't have to play some battle for the 30th time. This could just be my lack of game knowledge or not leveling my characters effectivly, but it was an annoyance that got old fast. I would suggest playing the game on medium difficulty. It's a nice mix of strategy and forgivness that makes you think without punishing you for minor mistakes.I  very much enjoyed my time with The Banner Saga. It's characters were odd, unique and badass. IIs world was bright, beautiful and engaging. And although the game can be frustrating at times,  I think the reason I like The Banner Saga the  most is becuase it's  somthing diffrent. And for  only 20$ The Banner Saga is a must own .

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Awesome game. :)I backed this, during its Kickstarter run, primarily because of the art style. I'm very, very happy with the end result. The visual style in-game is amazing. The vista while the caravan is travelling is just a treat to see, and there are so many portions which could stand alone as works of art in themselves. The character designs and combat animations are all great, IMHO. The only thing that could, perhaps, make it "better", would be if they had millions of dollars to spend on full animation and voiced dialogue...but from what I've seen and played through, that wouldn't really be necessary, and may even detract from the experience. It took me around 12 hours to finish. Normal Difficulty.I enjoyed the gameplay, overall, particularly the story choices (and, well, the story itself). The management of the "resource" you can earn and spend, Renown, keeps things interesting: do I use it to level up my characters? to buy my characters items to buff them? or do I spend it all on supplies for my caravan?Combat itself is quite well done. It seems relatively simple, at first glance, but turn order, unit placement (both during setup and combat) and target prioritization soon become quite important and can make for some very engaging and even stressful fights.The armor and strength stats mechanic is also an interesting feature: Each character has an armor and strength value, with armor reducing damage, and strength acting as both health and damage capability, with the latter decreasing as strength is damaged.Taking all that into account, along with each combatant's innate/passive ability plus their activated abilities, along with the willpower mechanic (which boosts damage, or movement, or pays for ability use)...and it may not seem so simple anymore. Which isn't a bad thing. :)The soundtrack's great. I loved Austin Wintory's work on "Journey" (I wish it'd get ported to PC; I'd gladly buy it a second time if it came out for PC). From the softer, somber tones of some of the caravan marching tracks, to the faster and heavy beats of the combat track...all great. I love the tracks with the strong vocals in them, and the last piece in the game was amazing (the credits song/music, too). I'd definitely recommend getting the Soundtrack.Bugs? Glitches? I had one freeze after several hours of play, but I was alt+tab'ing a lot and had stuff running in the background. I also had one combat glitch that required me to load a game, but it was a one time thing.Complaints? There's only one save "track". If you start a new game, it'll overwrite your previous saves. It's an autosave system that saves at key points (like entering/leaving a town, after an encounter, etc.), which may also be a problem for some. I'm fine with it being autosave-only (since it keeps every autosave point), but the lack of extra save "tracks" or profiles is kinda annoying, esp. since I'm now thinking of a new playthrough and, this being the 1st chapter (of an intended trilogy? still fuzzy on that. I should re-read my backer emails...), saves could carry over and other stuff like that.Volume control. There isn't one. It's either you have music/sounds on, or you have them off. There are also no subtitles. It's not really that important, as the voiceover parts are few, but it'd still be nice to have 'em.TL;DR:I loved the game. I'm looking forward to the next installment. Amazing art (waiting for my digital art book) and soundtrack (if you're going to get it: get the one w/ the Soundtrack), and engaging combat and gameplay. I'm very glad that I backed this game's Kickstarter. :)

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												This game was so much fun when I played it. I actually played it twice to see some alternative choice consequences and both time I got engaged in the game so much. You  must keep in mind that this is NOT a fairy tale RPG. The advertisement slogan for the BS2 applies just as much to the first installment. You can lose heroes you got attached to not because a battle went wrong but because you made a wrong choice during the storytelling sequence. Sometimes it can get you down but all in all it’s still a great entertainment.I think adult players will have more fun with the game just because they can see the second bottom to the story and the message of the game better than younger audience. This being said I think all players that enjoy difficult (!) turn based strategies will enjoy this game.Game mechanics are fairly easy to learn and flexible enough that you can replace any fallen hero (in battle or outside of it). Thou incorporating a new class to the battlegroup might force some tactics adjustments.All in all I enjoyed this game very much. The story is sad and a bit emotionally heavy if you engage heavily into such things (as I do) but hey – it’s just like life. Not pretty all the time ;)

Posted: October 11, 2015
												What a pleasant surprise that was. After forcing myself to finish some AAA titles lately, just because I've already put some hours in, it was nice to get sucked into a game and dragged all the way to the finish line for a change. The presentation might be simple, but what it lacks in budget it more than makes up in style, coherence, and genuine heart. Interesting story, great combat system, and a really dense, end-of-the-world atmosphere. Must play for any fans of tactical combat, narrative-heavy games, or anyone looking for a well-made, creative title. Aside from ridiculous difficulty spike in the final battle, there's nothing here to complain about.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												The Banner Saga - A Viking Tale of Tragedy and Survival----PROS-----Art. The art is the most striking part of this game. It shows you the beauty of hand drawn creations coming alive in what one could only assume is a painful effort to create wonderful animations that flow well. The backdrops show you snowy mountains and barren wastelands to ravaged villages and burning cities, all colored in to show the intense to the calming.-Music. Wonderful pieces that fit each scene quite well. Loud drums and deep bellowing for combat, and soft orchestra-styled music for traveling and such.-Story. It's difficult to find a game where your choices truly make a diffrence. In the Banner Saga, you could make the choice to invite more people into your caravan only for your food to run out in a wasteland and have so many starve. Choose to have your heroes charge head first into the stony masses of your enemies and end up being dragged back on the backs of your friends wathcing the rest of the battle fail.-Characters. From the proud Varl, a group of horned giants who have no women or children to hold them back in battle to the Dredge, a mysterious horde of stone men that never cease in their equally enigmatic plight, every race, character, and hero is wonderfully written.-Troop Management. Ah, the troop management. Keeping your caravan alive in this masterpiece is... unique, for lack of a better word. Your troops have to be promoted (leveled) by killing troops, however each soldier requires renown (the game's universal currency) to level up. This means you must choose between promoting your heroes, buying life-sustaining supplies, or purchasing trinkets that could keep the battle going in your favor.-Good Combat. The combat feels like a mix between chess and final fantasy tactics advanced (thats the only ff I played). The player must use each hero's special abilities to break through an enemy's armor (a seperate health bar) to get to their strength (or health and hitting power), creating a nice style of combat that forces players to use armorbreakers alongside tank and dps units.-Length. Yeah, it's a good sized game.-Flow Between Games. Your save carries over into the next like Mass Effect. I like that alot.----CONS-----Bad Combat. Yeah, I had to split it into two groups. The combat gets unwieldy as you kill enemies. Say the enemy has 5 units and you have 5 units: each player swaps off every time they "use" a hero (ie moving and attacking). Now say you killed the ♥♥♥♥ out of two of their units (5 to 3): they still get to move every other turn, meaning they get more movement per hero. This could be considered good, which I can definitely see, but it causes alot of problems. I see this as a neutral, but alot of people tell me they think it corrupts the rest of their experience. I decided to put this in the cons as a warning for those who would like to avoid this. For these people, I suggest easy mode which strips the need to let your heroes heal up after battle.----Summary----This game is clearly a work of art. I have personally introduced this game to many people (some of which think video games are a nonsensical hobby) and all have said it is breath-taking. This game is beautiful in so many more ways than one. I hope you enjoy your adventures as much as I have. See you in Abberang, my viking amigos. My Final rating: 9.7/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												I backed the Kickstarter, donating twice the value of the retail game (fifty dollars), because even at that early stage it was clear that this was a game with two of the ingredients required for greatness: a story worth telling and the people capable of telling it. All they lacked were the funds to bring it into being.So, what did I get for my money? Was it worth paying double? In a word, yes. The Banner Saga is clearly influenced by Bioware's golden age of games in the social aspects with your followers (Knights of the Old Republic, Mass Effect), as well as the Oregon Trail, oddly enough,  but for the most part it is its own being. The art and music are achingly beautiful. The characters are written robustly, so that we get to know them slowly, over this chapter of the saga. I was actually surprised at how much I cared about them, and how much more I wanted to know. The combat, once you get the hang of it (I jumped right in since I played a lot of the multiplayer) is fun, and the addition of magic items that allow you to tweak your characters is welcome. The choices you make along the journey, whether to rout or regroup, how much food to buy, when to train your followers, have definite consequences, made all the more dear by the fact that you cannot jump back to old saves if something goes disasterously wrong.Having already finished the game on normal nut the climax on easy, I am now going to play it again, which is, you'll agree, the test of great game. I want more! The developers have created a new world of in gaming, populated with their own unique population of giants, men, and magic. I very much hope that this is the first of many chapters in the Banner Saga, and that future iterations with expand and enrich the spectacle and vibrance of the world they have created with voice actors and longer sagas.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												The Banner Saga pulls you in immediately with its perfect illustrations, then plunges you into a world of heavy responsibility and grey melancholy. But this is a good thing - it pushes the story along and keeps you wanting to make things work out for the poor Norsemen in your caravan. To top things off, The Banner Saga has one of the best strategic combat systems I've ever played with. Combat keeps you on your toes, as there is not a single round to waste. Every decision you make is crucial in this game, both in combat and out of it.The soundtrack is also riveting. It is so earthy and yet so grandiose, and to add to the Norse flavor of the game, the lyrics are in Icelandic. Buy it. It is one of the few games ever made that is a unique experience rather than just another color of the same thing that's been done a million times. It's definitely worth your money.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												If you are in storytelling and turn-based combat this game is just perfect for you. At the beginning I was a bit sceptical because of the few animations during conversations and the very slow soundtrack at the first hour... but later I was so much into the story and the soundtrack changed that i did not care. The art in this game is drawn with love. But the thing that impressed me most was the handling of saving in the game... you cant choose where to save or just reload the game when you made a desicion and you did not like it's outcome. You just go on with that bad feeling that you lost one of your favorite. You have to handle the results. Even if you lose a battle, the is no rewind button. You have to live with it and it's results, which infulence your caravan, your supplies and the life or death of your clanmen and heroes!The story unfolds with time and you reveal the secrets of your partymember with some time (if they survive). The story waits with some unexpected changes and outcomes.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												I backed this game on Kickstarter back in 2012 and it's one of the few projects I donated to that I feel lived up to my hopes. It's a beautiful game and a memorable experience, and you can easily forget what a small budget it was developed on. The combat is not what you'd get from an AAA title, but the beauty of the game's aesthetics and the experience of the story were a  truly fresh experience to me after 25 years of gaming. I especially loved the feeling of responsibility and the weight of the decisions you have to make. So many games these days play up war as a glorious and fun adventure, which is fine, but so much of what people experience in times of conflict is glossed over. The uncertainty and the dread out in full force in this game. I see some people complaining about the very limited saving system, but really I feel like you're only cheating yourself if you try to redo everything in this game to get the optimal outcomes. It's an experience, and part of that experience is spoiled if you don't feel any real danger, risk, or consequences. I recommend this game to people looking for an amazing story, beautiful aesthetics, a gripping experience, and something entirely novel. If you're only looking for combat, you probably won't appreciate it, but it's really your loss.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Banner Saga...A cold wind blows across your face as you survey the battle-hardened warriors and their kin huddled around a hastily prepared bonfire. There are fewer of them now, a product of your leadership, though, you are resolute in knowing that your courage and pragmatism saved many of them. Despite the hardship you have endured, you can hear laughter and merriment in the distance, dancing and joyful music. A smile graces your chapped lips.Your daughter stands besides you, clinging to your tunic, and with a gentle word she speaks looking on with you,"I think it's time, Father."With a bellow from your lips the camp is broken down, and once again you find yourself on the road headed toward adventure, your banner, telling the story of your people all the way back to the beginning, flapping defiantly in the wind. This is your time. Banner Saga is a game about the burden of leadership in the face of adversity. The tale is told from many points of view and unlike other games, I have yet to find a game over screen. Your choices are permanent & resounding. Failure sticks and has consequences. If you're familiar with X-Com, this is Ironman. If you're interested in a great norse inspired story of men, beasts, and giants, in a time where the gods are thought dead, then this is the game for you. You won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												I just completed the game and I have to say, that it was a beautiful experience.The plus points of this game:- Rich and Vibrant 2D graphic-novel style artwork.- Haunting and Melodic Musical Soundtrack.- Well-written dialogue with pretty well rounded characters.- Combat reminiscent of old-school games like Vandal Hearts (set number of unique characters instead of armies).However there were a few things that I did not enjoy, so please take these into account (these are just more wordy... not that I think the bad outweighs the good!):- Very Short Game; I have no idea why the game ended where it did. The Store doesn't say it's an episodic game or anything like that, so I've no clue why through the story you're characters are talking about doing something... then the game ends before that even happens. I'd like to think either DLC or a second chapter will be coming at some point.- Heraldry; on the game menu there's an option to choose your banner, but it doesn't really go into detail. I see that it's for the multiplayer called "Factions" but I see no way to access that through the game menus. Has to be installed seperately.- Difficulty; not too easy, not too hard. Until the final fight, where it's like "Well I'm putting this on easy, hell with that...". Aside from that, perfect difficulty until the end (so this is a mixed point), may even try it on hard.So to sum up... play it. I don't know why you're still reading this. Go on, hit play!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												This game was amazing for me, quite clearly something that needs to be in line with your personal tastes, but for what I wanted out of the game my only real complaint is like anything good I want even more. With a sequel on the way I'll get my  wish eventually though.This game is pretty story driven, it would have made a fantastic free roam rogue-like (or rogue-lite, honestly the original term has expanded it's scope just like rpg has over the years, get over it) but I'll take a story driven game when the story at least for me was this good. I've seen some criticism about the choices you make not mattering. I can't say for certain yet, I've just now played through once on hard forbidding myself from reloading to change my choices. As such I can't comment on how much the choices actually mattered HOWEVER, the 'illusion' of choice presented here at least made it feel like so much could have gone differently, my bad choices seemed to kind of snowball on me towards the end ramping up the difficulty quite a bit. It made me ache for the version of this game that could have been like FTL but better.Bottom line:+The art is great, I absolutely love games that go so far to present a unique visual style such as this.+The combat seems super simple at first, but has surprising depth, appealing to the part of me that grew up playing final fantasy tactics. (No real character customization with classes or anything like that though.)+The oregon trail inspired travel from place to place is not only so much better and more immersive than how similar games simply move your little dot along the lines on a map, it lends itself toward making the world and the things in it feel massive. You will probably feel tiny by the end of this.+The story struck a chord with me at least, I got very attached to some of the characters and seemingly through my own mistakes lost a few of them. I found myself spending time reading about the locations I might be headed to on the map when I got the chance. I feel it was very good.-They use the same character shots on different backgrounds while flashing between them during dialogue portions of the game. It oddly works pretty well and isn't too jarring, but full animation or cutscenes would have been very welcome. I fully understand why they couldn't or didn't, but I kinda wanted to see the character's body language a bit, and see some of the scenes described actually shown.-I almost would rather they released a series of expansions to the game rather than a sequel. It really feels like even more could be done with what's here.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												The Banner Saga pulls you in immediately with its perfect illustrations, then plunges you into a world of heavy responsibility and grey melancholy. But this is a good thing - it pushes the story along and keeps you wanting to make things work out for the poor Norsemen in your caravan. To top things off, The Banner Saga has one of the best strategic combat systems I've ever played with. Combat keeps you on your toes, as there is not a single round to waste. Every decision you make is crucial in this game, both in combat and out of it.The soundtrack is also riveting. It is so earthy and yet so grandiose, and to add to the Norse flavor of the game, the lyrics are in Icelandic. Buy it. It is one of the few games ever made that is a unique experience rather than just another color of the same thing that's been done a million times. It's definitely worth your money.
