number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												I knew nothing about this game until its Steam release. The intro art made me think this was a game about the Male and Female on the intro, seems interesting I thought. Maybe an RPG spin on The Last of Us or something.What did I get, Giants... wait what? Who are they and why do I care? Instant turn off. Ok, Ill play along surely this is just a temporary thing. The screen at the start said the game might switch between characters, but surely It will get to the ones I can relate to soon... nope!Ok now I am looking at the city from the outside, and... waiting. Is this a loading screen? Oh look moving the mouse makes the screen move left and right. So this is a bug or something, wait nope I just highlighted a building...Ok so now I have to point and click on some buildings, and then talk to some guys inside. Done, now what?Oh click on another building and fight some people.Seriously this is not what I signed up for, when do I get off the rail road?This game to me is not an RPG, it is an interactive story book with Turn based combat in between to make you feel like you are having some input.Despite all the positive comments about the combat, I really disliked it. The whole I am going to stand here while you hit me thing never went over well with me, but this take seems to make it worse. The special moves, make it just plain awful.See Southpark Stick of truth for how it should be done.What I liked about the game.- Great artWhat I disliked about the game.- Intro that tells me I have no choice over which characters I play. So not an RPG then?- Long, uninteresting intro sequence... Why do these guys have horns?- Incoherent intro sequence, who what... where? I am chasing some guys because some guy told me too? Ummm ok.- Characters I don't care about, when do I get to the character creation screen? This is an RPG right? RIGHT?- Where are the girl and man from intro they look interesting?- Music to make you sleep.- Unbelievable (in the bad sense) combat.- Advertised as an RPG/Strategy when it is a point and click story driven adventure. Seriously, RPG is Role Playing Game, not Fantasy Game. And Strategy, any game where the player has input in the combat should be classified as a strategy if this game is any indication.Very Disappointed.

No fast forwarding during story & combat. No ( Zooming ) which i would have found it very useful sometimes if it existed.the animation when you're in combat is meh.. the archer is pointing totally in a different direction you would love to see some great action with their animation and abilities they have the animated cartoonic style yet they didn't do anything about it to put a variety of a fighting styles and techniques. content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												TLDR: I work >60 hours every week and want a relaxing game that doesn't feel annoying. I think I'm not going to find that in the Banner Saga.Pro:--Graphic design is pleasing.Neither pro or con but you might want to know:--Story based on Norse mythology, which I personally consider a cliche but that is purely personal experience.Numeric system is simple without much room for tweaks.Con:--Unforgiving towards mistakes. Does not provide save at anytime - only autosave, which makes mistakes even more unforgiving, as to remedy one mistake you need to put up with extra long lead-up time as autosaves are not done at beginning of combat, or load an autosave several battles earlier and redo all the chores. The game seem to be following a "force player to accept mistakes they made" philosophy, which I consider sadly mistaken.Does not provide audio for most conversations, which forces gamer to read subtitles, which is taxing for someone who uses eye for work.

												Ok, the art is beautiful. I love stylized work like this - Charles Vess, et al. And the music is wonderful as well. What limited story is there is well written. This game however is supremely frustrating by the lack of a save game mechanic. If you screw up in a fight - and you will - then you'll have to go back a good ways - often scroll through tons of dialogue and animation just to get back to the fight. This is game design 101 folks. You don't do that. Never. Ever. But because decisions affect how a fight starts then you'd need two saves - with the latter being at the beginning of the actual fight itself so you don't have to go back  through all the extraneous stuff simply to reload the fight.That and there are some other little niggling issues like only being able to move once as opposed to having move points - which is hella more strategic. So if you screw up and move to the wrong spot you're screwed. And it sucks that you have to count squares before moving your archers to figure out if they'll be in range or not after they move. No interrupts, no saving move points to adjust position, etc. means it's all pretty bare bones strategy that gets boring and frustrating fast. A million other games have done this a million times better so it boggles the mind that the designer wouldn't have learned that by now. Maybe it was the budget limitations, I don't know, but it's a royal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥and a disservice to an otherwise beauttiful game.Don't forgoe it completely however, just jump in at the $5 mark and that's fair enough.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												This game is really really really beautiful with amazing animation, richly detailed background landscapes, and an impressive soundtrack. That is pretty much the good points of this game in a nutshell. I want to like this game so much but it falls so flat. A lot of it stems from the game's garbled mess of a story with no character development and no clear plot direction. It is hard to become invested in characters that do not seem to matter. The game's mechanics are dubious as well with no real consequences for elements such as low morale in your party, lost battles, and even the choices you make on the road simply do not matter. The dialog trees are incredibly dull, barely move the plot along, and offers no insight into character motivations, which is inherently the entire point of having dialog trees in the first place.The turn based battles are mildly engaging but are hampered by leveling system where each individual character only gains experience based on the number of kills. This system favors the already strong characters but leaves the weaker characters who are lucky if they even get one kill, let alone survive a battle, as weak characters who never level up.I was initially excited about this game but after watching the game's characters wander around aimlessly for several hours with no advancement in the storyline I lost interest and could not bring myself to finish the game. Consequently I cannot reccomend this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 15 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												The game looks great. The animations are great. I like the subtle animations on the screen. I like the battle animations. The story so far is okay (I'm only 4 hours into it at this point). I will admit that when I saw the first line "The gods are dead" I rolled my eyes and thought great, it's a cliche in the first line of the game.The combat is different. Having armor and strength, having to make a decision as to which attack to make -- break armor to reduce the armor and allow subsequent attacks to do more damage or attack strength which in turn lowers the amount of damage they can do on their strength attack. Break armor attacks however are unaffected by strength, so those almost dead enemies can still pose a risk. There's a disadvantage in eliminating low health enemies while there are strong enemies still on the board.The willpower attribute is interesting in that you have a limited amount of points that can be used in strengthening attacks or moving further. Characters are limited in how much willpower they can expend, which also can be raised. This pool is limited but willpower can be gained when an enemy is killed and there are some characters that can add willpower to other characters through abilities. Here's what I don't like... the slow moving caravan moves slowly. The world looks great, but I really don't like waiting minutes for the caravan to crawl across the screen to the next destination. I get it, it's probably for effect or immersiveness, but please... can I just fast forward please? The caravan leaves... moving slowly... moving... then an event pops up. Read through it, resolve, hopefully a battle, then back to the slowly... moving... caravan. *sigh*After 4 hours I got up from playing the game and went to look at the time, thinking surely it was hours later than it was. I was surprised it was only 4 hours. It felt much longer. If this was non-stop action, that would be a good thing.  For this, not so much.With that said, I like the game so far. I don't regret the pre-order, but I'd be hardpressed to recommend it to someone at $25 unless I was really sure they'd like it. My recommendation is to find the free to play multiplayer "Banner Saga: Factions" and give it a shot. If you're okay with the combat system, then maybe consider the singleplayer version.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												I grabbed this game during a sale and, honestly, didn't expect too much from it. I was just bored and wanted to try something new, and while I love games with multiple choices, I had never played a turn-based RPG before. This kind of combat always scared me away for some reason - dungeon crawlers with awful graphics, annoying camera ancles and a constant bird's-eye view came to mind, in short, games from the last century which can only be valued by nostalgics. I am sure more people out there have such prejudices, and I highly encourage them to try out this game. This whole "chessboard" combat turned out to be incredibly fun. The art style and graphics are great, the story is interesting and the music is very beautiful. Most of the dialogues aren't voiced, but I even welcomed that. Some say the combat is unfairly hard, but there are 3 difficulty levels which you can change at any point in the game. Of course, there are some downsides, too. Mostly the short duration of the game (finished it in 7-8 hours), and watching your caravan travel in snail pace can become a bit boring at times. As always, the decisions made in-game don't really have such a big impact in the end, but that's the case with all choice-based games, from Fallout to Telltale Games to Life is Strange. But it surely has replayability, and the greatest feature is, that the game doesn't end, when you fail in combat. It just carries on with your failure and you'll have to live with the consequences. (Of course, you can reload if you wish to do so).This game is really interesting and unique, and I think everybody should give it a try.

number of helpful: 4 of 21 people (19%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												I've spent countless hours on a variety of RPGs over the years so I figured I'd give this one a try but I sadly regret doing so...I spent 20 hours trying to like this game, but I just can't get into it.The Banner Saga is a rather unique square grid turn based RPG with good music and sound effects (though lacking a volume slider for some reason), good controls, and it features a very unique art style.That's all that's good in my opinion.This game offers you very little control, as you move along automatically on a linear path, stopping here and there as the story takes you from places of interest and battles. You are constantly asked to answer multiple choice questions that affect various events and cause battles to trigger. When you get in a battle you move a single character, your opponent moves a single character, and this process continues until the end.You will generally be fighting the same enemies and slightly different versions of them throughout at least the first 20 hours of the game.Personally, When I play an RPG I desire the ability to explore the world but this game does not allow this.I don't find it fun to have the gameplay consist of watching a parade move from location to location, answering various multiple choice questions, and fighting robot enemies I've seen a hundred times.The battle system is another problem. Strength and HP are the same basically, and breaking defense before HP results in better hits on HP. All the characters get maybe a single special move which is kind of lacking in my opinion. There are no magic spells or trinkets to use, it's just simple attack and a single special. You can't even defend.Another problem is that you can't grind in this game. There are no opportunities (in the first 20 hours anyway), to replay battles or trigger random battles to help build your team. The characters are all rather weak (especially the humans), so an opportunity to grind would be nice.The currency in this world is called renown, and it's used to rank up your characters (levelling), buy things in the market (!?), and it's also used to buy supplies for your journey. It's overused for everything and it's easy to run out of it as you start collecting a lot of party members and market items.Yes that's another problem, for some reason we have resource management here to feed all those people in your parade. This is not fun. That's a lot of negatives, this game is really underwhelming.There are many better RPGs out there, (let me suggest some great titles such as Grandia 2, the Final Fantasy Series, Shining Force Series, Phantasy Star Series)  and while this game has some unique features and some very nice graphics, the gameplay is simply not fun.Skip this one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 5
												The Banner Saga is a beautiful story-driven RPG with turn-based combat and I recommend it. The artdesign is nice and although you might consider the drawn characters a little like "for children", that's not the case. The story is sad, you will be confronted with wrong decisions (and you will take them) and their consequences, with death in combat, death by starvation, death and betrayal by any other unexpected event. While the game world is very original and inspired by nordic mythology in the best way possible, it reminded me a little of Game of Thrones with its twists. A huge plus!I didn't find any bugs, the German localization was relatively good and as my first playthrough took me about 15 hours with some potential for another run, the game is value for money.However there is also one thing I disliked: The combat system. And as you spend your time mainly with multiple choice dialogues and turn-based combat, that's a notable flaw. While I do like the fact that your strength is connected to your HP, so your characters deal less damage the more they are wounded (same applies for the enemies), the following points caused some frustration:1) You can let your characters walk according to waypoints which you define in a row, but you cannot give them several orders for movement one after another - if you don't use the waypoint system and you don't send your character immediately to the place you want it, you cannot move him anymore and need to wait until the next turn.2) Only spear fighters can strike diagonally.3) Your characters easily block each other.4) You get an overview how much HP damange you could deal to any enemy in range, but not armour damage. 5) the worst point: The order of action. It is always you-enemy-you-enemy until there is only one enemy or character alive and "pillage" mode is activated. This makes combat quite weird, because first of all it is not based on initiative (like in Heroes 5 for example, where combat was very well done) and it makes more sense for you not to kill an enemy when you managed to weaken him strongly, because if you kill him, the remaining enemies will have a higher action frequency. If you own the game already you surely know what I mean, but for everybody who still didn't purchase it:Combat between a party of 3 (P1,P2,P3) and 3 emenies (E1,E2,E3). The order is: P1,E1,P2,E2,P3,E3. But when you kill an enemy E1 it changes to: P1,E2,P2,E3,P3,E2. So killing a weakened enemy will give you a disadvantage as you cannot choose freely which character to move (unlike chess). You might win the combat, but as one of your enemies will get another turn faster than your team, you might lose a wounded character. Although this way the combat requires its own tactical thinking and is quite challenging, I'd have preferred a combat system based on initiative. That would be more organic. And diagonal strikes, too. And last but not least: I wanted to play through the game on hard mode but found out that then "The Banner Saga" turns into the Dark Souls of turn-based RPGs. If you want to suffer and get absolutely wiped by tons of enemies, well... have fun, but don't be too proud to go back to "normal" :P (However I will try it again, now that I understand the game mechanics. This review was written after 16 hours of playing, directly after finishing the first playthrough, so a higher number of hours will indicate that I went again for the challenge.The negative aspects about combat had a quite strong negative impact on how I enjoyed the game when I played it for the first time - I bought it shortly after release, played it, disliked the combat and abandoned it. However as I am trying to play through my whole steam library I returned to the game and must admit that the great story, screenplay and character design compensate for it perfectly.Therefore I recommend The Banner Saga strongly, if you can get along with the combat system. In any case, don't give up after the first hour, it gets much, much better the more you play :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												This is not meant to be a discouraging review.  I would like to begin about pointing out all the things I found to be positively amazing about this game: story-telling, animation style and drawing style really bring this story to life, and I am a fan of the turn-based tactics.Okay, now to the grit.  This is a very monotonous game in terms of gameplay.  You will see there's a "map" feature where you can see all these places that you have absolutely no control over whether or not you visit any of them.  You are compelled at every step of the way to follow a pre-determined path.  Much like Oregon Trail, you're given random encounters and chances to make decisions that affect gameplay.  This is good!  However, those decisions are largely minor details.  This is not so good. The game is featured in this robust, rich environment that one can hardly ever interact with.  Achievements are unlocked at almost an equally monotonous pace.  At the end of the game, one is left feeling like the story was never truly told.  You don't get to find out what happens after the final boss is "slain".  They really don't even seem to unfold any story about how anything got to be the way it was.  In conclusion, I found this game immensely frustrating.  Because if it straight up sucked - I would have no problem just saying, "this game was no fun to play."  The problem is that it has so much potential -- so much so you wished they took the time to do more with it.  Unfortunately, I picked up this game at $25.  Was this game worth $25?  In so many ways yes - but in so many MORE ways (if one were to judge it simply as a game and not for all the artwork and music that they put into it) NO.

Posted: June 9, 2014
												Only a few hours into this game, and I am very impressed.  This is a true saga, and more of a RPG than many purported stat min-maxing/item gathering games out there.  With an interesting story, a dismal situation where you really feel like you're fleeing and not just powering up and steamrolling enemies.  Multiple factions and constant ethical dilemnas make this very engrossing.  The mechanics of the game pace it more like a story than rush rush kill gather.  The combat is old-school too, so you can still have min-maxing and the abundance of classes (nearly every character is a distinct class) makes every combat interesting.I hope these people make more stories, and I'm glad I picked this up.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												Ever wondered what would happen if the Oregon Trail, Final Fantasy Tactics, and a bunch of Vikings had a baby?The answer is The Banner Saga, and it is amazing. Make decisions as the leaders of two separate caravans as they try to survive while the world around them grows steadily harsher. Make or lose allies based on your choices, and carefully weigh whether you want to level those allies up, earn them equipment, or buy rations to maintain the health and morale of your group as a whole.The Banner Saga is beautiful, interesting, and challenging. This is one of those games I couldn't help bingeplaying all the way through to the end in one night, because this is a game where the player really does have control of so many aspects of how things wind up.Definitely recommended!

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												An absolutely beautiful game inspired by Scandinavian culture and lore from the days of old. The music and art alone are worth giving this game a try. I wholly enjoyed my time playing, watching, and listening to the story unfold. It truly does live up to the word "Saga" as it revolves around a long journey full of peril and the struggle to survive an quickly encroaching threat. What is amazing is that this game's universe contains a very fleshed-out map for the players to peruse. It took me 20 minutes to systematically click on and read about the universe I found myself in. It is made very clear that the game you are playing is only scratching the surface of this world.  Hopefully even more of the land will be visited in the sequel!

												This game is just... a must buy or die game. So must there be anymore information?The music is peaceful yet empowering, it soothes the soul but also raises spirits, the song on it's own is amazing but accompained with the game makes it immensely more fun to play. The little interaction made with the poeple in your parties of why they each have chosen to fight give you more of a reason to defend and look after you caraven. The main story has epic decisions that will greatly impact what you will do and happen to cities, massive populations and more. The battle system in place has you trying to think out your strategies and grealty reward you with renown that can buy supplies for your caravan, promote your character and buy items.The game in all has an excellent story with writing that is made by the gods (that are not dead). Amazing music that makes it worthwhile to also buy the soundtrack. Battles which have you slowly but strategically win with the warriors you have at your disposal. So buy buy buy people and don't look back.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												I really enjoyed this game. It's incredibly immersive, with everything from a gripping story, well-drawn characters, and a superb fictional world. In terms of gameplay, it mixes RPG and Strategy elements, somewhat like the Final Fantasy Tactics series, and the balance works very well.The only thing I don't like is that it's a bit short - it took me about 9 hours to complete on my first play through - and the story ends quite suddenly. The ending doesn't exactly tie up all the loose ends, but hopefully DLC or a sequel will be brought out to solve that. On the whole though, it's fantastic, and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a fun single-player game that will keep you interested from start to finish. I bought it for about £11 because of a 40% off deal and I found it great value for money.

												I really enjoyed this game up to a point. I found the combat mechanics very challenging. The ability to reduce a unit's damage output by reducing it's strength was new and interesting. I had to alter my long-time turn-based strategy mechanics to fit this new style of gameplay. The graphics are amazing. The game looks great, which adds to the story atmosphere. The ending is strange; I don't know if there are multiple endings, but it felt like there should be more to the story. If you enjoy being kicked in the gut when you're down, you'll like this game. You get to make a lot of decisions and it seems like you can never improve your situation; it's a slow spiral to an uncomfortable endpoint.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												An excellent turn-based strategy game.Visually, it is a beautiful game. The art style fits well, and the animations are well done. The "animated painting"-style backgrounds add lots of subtle detail that really shows the team put a lot of effort and thought into the visuals.What audio there is is excellent. I realize that voiceover work is expensive and time-consuming, and that this was funded through Kickstarter, so it's understandable that it's not there in the final product. Would have been nice if it had been possible.The gameplay doesn't stray particularly far from the traditional turn-based strategy standards. Most gameplay elements are intuitive, though I personally would prefer on-hover tooltips in addition to the help menu system as they have implemented it the game. The game is difficult, and would be especially so for players who aren't as familiar with turn-based strategy games, but not overwhelming, and I never got the sense that I was constantly losing outside of the very early stages of the game. The gameplay itself had a sense of progress in terms of how good I felt at the game.The setting is intriguing, and it shows the developers were planning ahead for further games set in this universe, as there is much left unexplored and unexplained. The story itself usually resists the urges of the usual fantasy tropes--especially when it comes to the portrayal of women, and really comes across as a mature endeavor.Overall, I would recommend this game. Visually, it is a work of art, and gameplay-wise, it is a challenging, but not frustrating. The story is deep and engaging.

												There is something about this game that makes it special, and you can feel that just by looking at the screenshots. First impressions are rarely decietful and The Banner Saga turns out to be a pretty good game.Nevertheless it's not the most exciting game ever, if you are hoping to get a pounding heart and adrenaline rushes from playing this game, you probably will be disapointed. content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												One of the best games I've played in a while.  The combat system is simple but not boring, and not too easy (plus you can change the difficulty).  The characters you build, what traits you improve, and how you use them, are important in each battle.  You might feel you perfect the battle system after a while but I ended up getting to the end of the game, and unable to win the last battle.  I was not wanting the game to be over so quickly anyway so I just started again.  Every decision you make will have real consequences - sometimes even ending the game.  And as I saw when starting again, the decisions really do make a difference...it's not a cosmetic feature.  Although there's almost no voice acting, the story is good, the animation is great, the music is fitting, and I found myself enjoying the characters and not wanting to stop playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												For an indie game, from the kickstarter program, this game is amazing.  For games in general, it is great.  It was unique and immersive and ARDUOUS.  Only a kickstarter game could be made to be like this; classic hardcore gamer style RPG, with a focus on story and stressful combat.  You will have to resit the urge to turn down the difficulty in this game more than you ever have before.  I'm ashamed to say i had to dumb it down to easy a couple times, although that may be more the fault of some well reported difficulty spike issues.  In the end, the story is really what makes this game, and all that goes with that (art, music, character's, etc.).  All of this is absolutely top notch, and was more moving for me than just about any game I've played in a good long while.  Not many games have given me those stirring goosebump moments when the right music hits and the right moment (The title screen itself gives you your first glimpse into the inspiring music).  I got about 15 hours out of it, which is not too shabby.  Might want to wait for it to go on sale, which Steam will be sure to do at some point.  However, I would say quite confidently it is well worth the 25 bucks.  I spend more than that in 2 hours at the bar, with no where near the satisfaction.

												I really enjoyed this game. It's incredibly immersive, with everything from a gripping story, well-drawn characters, and a superb fictional world. In terms of gameplay, it mixes RPG and Strategy elements, somewhat like the Final Fantasy Tactics series, and the balance works very well.The only thing I don't like is that it's a bit short - it took me about 9 hours to complete on my first play through - and the story ends quite suddenly. The ending doesn't exactly tie up all the loose ends, but hopefully DLC or a sequel will be brought out to solve that. On the whole though, it's fantastic, and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a fun single-player game that will keep you interested from start to finish. I bought it for about £11 because of a 40% off deal and I found it great value for money.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Amazing story, characters, art, and soundtrack. I HIGHLY recommend this game.The only possible downside: the combat system is intentionally different than your average tactical RPG. Normally you want to gang up on one opponent, move to the next, and so-forth. Here, you have to spread the damage. The game's initiative order works such that one of your characters gets a turn, then one of the enemies... even if there is one enemy left. So, ganging up on one enemy means that the others will go more often. In addition, the amount of life an opponent has left is tied to the damage he does.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												An interesting find among games for the casual videogame player, "The Banner Saga" seems to be a mix of genres that aren’t to common. Part RPG, part turn based tactics, part survival simulator that seems to have nostalgic roots in the Oregon trail series, this game is complex enough for multiple play-throughs yet simple enough for players with an intense daily schedule to pick up, play and run off again on a whim. With a story setting in alignment with harsh Norse legends, the story centers around two perspectives for most of the game. One a war band of ice giants attempting to discover return to their homeland as an old enemy starts spontaneously growing in power and a band or human war refugees trying to outrun the same enemy and find a safe haven. Each group has a bandleader who must make difficult decisions in order to keep their own bands alive and in a feat of excellent imagination, each decision has consequences that can be felt later in ether story perspective or in the efficiency of your fighting strength. It’s very interactive for a game that mostly involves watching over a traveling band of people. The art surrounding this is crisp and beautiful with older hand drawn styled animation television cartoonists would use.The gameplay is divided into three major parts: One is the survival sim. The player watches over their banner caravan as it slowly travels from one destination to the next, encountering obstacles, managing resources to keep people from starving, and setting disputes among your more colorful caravan members. This part has a huge impact on combat when your band must defend itself from an enemy. The second is turn based combat. In chess like fashion, you select certain members of the caravan to defend it by placing each unit on a grid and taking turns to issue them commands. The third part is route customization, choices you make can change the story, therefore battles will change and your fighting units with it.As far as downsides go there was very few; there are a few bugs regarding turn based battles, but nothing anyone with any sort of patience would find hard to ignore and some story decisions seem to get so tangled that it’s possible to miss important plot devices. The ending also seems abrupt and unexplained, your it is hinted that there may be two opposing villainous forces facing off, only to fight a boss that seems unimportant to ether side and the whole game ends…it’s a bit confusing.All in all I recommend “The Banner Saga”.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												One of the first "Indie Games" I've ever bought. And I have to say, without having finished it, this has got to be one of the coolest rpg's I've ever played. The gameplay is pretty much divided between three parts: combat, resource management, and dialogue choices. The combat is turn based, but it's not overcomplicated. It's simple, strategic, tough, but really rewarding when you win. Resource management is essentially how you choose to use the universal currency of the game, "renown," to either buy supplies for your caravan, purchase items for your heroes, or upgrade your heroes' abilities. Like I said, this game is tough, but by far the most agonizing part of this game is the diabolical dialogue choices they give. They all have REAL impact. Your heroes will die or betray you, even if you've spent countless points upgrading their stats. There is no mercy. And because of the game's autosave feature, you can't just reload an earlier save. You have to live with the choices you've made. As noted before, I have not finished this game, but so far I've reached chapter four in roughly ten hours and it has been one of the most unique rpg game I've ever played. Definitely recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												I love this game. The Banner Saga is like people always describe women they are in love with, beautiful inside and out. The art animations and overall feel of this game is stunning. I'm not exaggerating when I say that. I just stopped and stared at the main menu for bit when I first loaded the game. The gorgeous art is also put to good use by the caravan marching motif that dominates the gameplay when not in combat. And the music and sound design subtley accent the whole feel of the thing. The combat mechanics are simple yet incredibly deep. Which is the hallmark of great game design.The balance of breaking your enemies armor or trying to punch through it to damage his health, and thus reduce the damage he can do to your people, is the core of the design. It is a brilliant one. And every design decision accents that concept. Combat is almost entirely skill based, and so it feels like chess. It is extremely rewarding when you start to learn how to really play. And the game let's you learn easily, by doing training battles in camp against randomly generated enemies matched to your party's level.However, this game is also incredibly punishing to mistakes. something as simple moving an ally incorrectly so they cannot attack that turn can lose an entire battle. If an ally goes down they will be at reduced power/health until they can rest, costing valuable supplies to feed your caravan. Being aggresive in major battles can save your troops lives but take party members out of action when you need them most. Being defensive makes combat easier for your party but can cost troops. And troops have to eat so the more you have the more supplys you need to keep them going. And the wrong choice in a dialogue can send a maxed out, and extremely useful, party member off on a tanrum that gets him killed. Long story short: Even on medium this game feels like dancing on a razor's edge. And I love that too, maybe most of all.It is not without it's flaws however. The game only has autosave and it does so constantly. Which sucks when you mis-click. I clicked leave about 30 "days" in just as I saw there was one of the unique side conversations that I'd missed. I went to load and, of course, it had saved right after I left. So I loaded the save right before that, played the one battle to get to where I could do this elusive conversation, and realized that the incredibly awesome items that I'd bought before were replaced by crappy ones in the store. And no, I couldn't just load the later save and not have the conversation because it overwrote that one. Also, and more important in the grand scheme if less personally frustrating, The items, which are a very key component in advancing your parties power, are all over the place in power and usefulness and thier level is not always commensurate. Sometimes that is because of clever use by the player, giving them to the character that can best exploit it's effects... and sometimes not.In summary, this game is beautiful in both it's art and mechanics. If Viking Turn-Based Tactical RPG sounds like something you could ever enjoy, I strongly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												While this game might not be for everyone, and in some ways it's a bit short, I have to say that it's a beautiful, thematic piece.  In addition, there's an almost Oregon Trail-esque feel to it because of the need to manage resources during travel.  Yet, unlike that game, this actually has a plot, and combat, with characters who possess distinct personalities.  It's a choice based game, which is wonderful, and even though many choices don't make a difference in what ultimately happens, they do impact resources, so one has to be careful what one does.  It's sufficient to say that I look forward to trying the sequel if it's half as good as this game.  There is sadness, but that just adds to the beautiful tapestry of this game.  For those who like to play games that aren't just about killing things, I recommend this title.

												This game is, wow it is amazing. Beautiful game overall, seriously, beautiful story, art, soundtrack, gameplay and ambience this game is a must play. The gameplay alone is something I can talk about for easily and hour, with an amazing health system this game plays like a PC fire emblem title with an amazing twist in your health and damage systems. Great story following two caravans, 1 which you follow for more of the game follows the story of Rook the leader of a caravan of clansmen fighters and what we would call giants(varl) is trying to save the world with his daughter.And the other one Hakon who actually is Varl leading another caravan doing pretty much the same thing. The story has a brilliant end, which I won't say. There is a lot more to the story than just that but, you should experience it yourself just trust me on that.The art is amazing I can't say much about it though just look at the damn screenshots and you will believe me.Soundtrack is an amazing orchestra composed by Austin Wintory, and it is also with what I can only describe as Norse vocals and such.The soundtrack only adds to the ambience as you travel through beautiful valleys and mountains with snow falling. Seriously this is probably the best looking game (not graphically in an art standpoint) I have ever played, Bastion taking a close 2nd.The only complaint I have of this game is a very personal one, I am not a very heavy or a very good reader, almost everything is read in this, but when voice acting is available, it is brilliant. Another one is that the split caravans kind of annoyed me mainly because Rooks story is much more interesting than that of Hakon's, but that problem is later fixed you will see.This game in a real standpoint has no problems from what I see, I mean it's a bit hard for some people but it is fair, so that isn't a problem. Seriously one of the most underrated games of 2014 I must give this game a 10/10 I love this game to death. One of my favourites. Seriously in my 10 favourite games of all time.Do I recommend it? HELL YES this game could go for $40 and I would still buy it even though it's only about 8-12 hours of gameplay. BUY IT NOW.

Like in one dilemma, you are asked to wait someone to come but same as your character, you don't know when they will come if they will come at all.The mehAI derpingIgnoring activated abilities, ie Stone WallMove into your range so you can draw first blood.Keen on killing your units thus giving you turn advantage.The badMostly 2 types of battles, either thugs or dredge (stone ppl), and only one fight vs varl (giants). I'm ok with the lack of fight with varl though.Caravan, while being one them of the game (protect your kin), it doesn't impact much on the game. I even tried resting even without food will actually boost your morale, while a dozen people are dying each day you rest.EDIT: Bad morale causes worse events to happen so staving/not resting does have impact.More on The Caravan: Let them starve thread[stoicstudio.com]TIPS: Specialize armor breakers to 3/4 armor breakStay out enemy range and wait them come and draw first blood. The flow is armor breakers break dredge's armor, then high HP weaken their HP and damage by attacking. As long as you keep dredge's HP lower than your armor, you are fine.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												What is Banner Saga?  Banner Saga is a combination of multiple choice style adventure game, resource management game, and turn based tactical combat game.  The original, Norse-based world is rich and intriguing and the writing, which dominates the non-combat parts of the game, is very well done.The real start of the show is the combat system.  It's very innovative and very different from anything I have ever seen.  A unit's hit points is also it damage, so if your unit takes damage, it won't be doing much of it own and units with a lot of hit points  you should tread very carefully around until you have whittled them down some.  Armor subtracts directly from potential damage, but you can choose to attack the armor instead, which is independant of your hit points.  Choosing when to attack the armor and when to attack the hitpoints is a key part of your strategy.Another different aspect is that you always take a turn with one of your units, followed by the enemy, no matter how many units each have with the exception of the last unit left standing.  This is one thing I've seen throwing a lot of people off.  Turn based games train you to focus on one enemy at a time, whittle him down, then turn on the next.  Trying to do this is not effective.  Instead, you'll want to injure all the enemies so that they can no longer do enough damage to hurt you, then take them all down quickly.  It's a very different approach and one that works quite well.If you're up for a tactical combat game with a deep combat system and a rich fantasy world, then this game is for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												A fun turn base squad game with some annoyingly text adventure elements in its meta game.The Banner Saga plays like two games in one, first there is the part where you manage your army in the meta game on the world map, and second is the part where you controls units in turn base squad combat.  This format isn't new, and in fact it has been done repeatedly in recent years by games like X-Com and Xenonauts to name two.  While the game's format isn't new, it does a few things differently, which works some times, and doesn't other times.Am not going to go into too much detail about how the game plays, since the format is well known, instead am going to focus on what it does differently (for better or worst). To start off, in the TBS section of the game, your units have a default willpower value that increase as they level up.  They can use their willpower to move further, use an ability, or just do more damage. Willpower is finite resource as your units do not generate it during combat. Instead you get 1 willpower, which you can give to any of your units, for every enemy you defeat.  This extra resource management add a layer to the combat section of the game that it needs. The combat overall is decent, but without this extra element it would be unremarkable in any way.The other two elements that The Banner Saga does differently happen in its meta portion of the game.  First, there is a supply, i.e. rations. During most of the game, you are leading your caravan across the map from point A to B.  And during this time you have to keep your caravan feed, otherwise you'll start to lose troops and your morale will drop. And the bigger your caravan, the more supply you'll need to feed it on a daily bases. So having more troops for war, isn't always a good thing, especially if you don't have the supply to feed them.  This resource management makes sense and actually is kind of fun to deal with. The second thing, however, is rather annoying. Normally text adventure elements are fun. But not in this case, since there are quite a few choices that will results in a unit dying or leaving your group. This wouldn't be so bad, except that for the most part, it seems totally arbitrary. I remember a section of the game where I told one of my units to start a fire, in order to create a distraction, and after it was done, that named character vanished. No real reason was given, and the only thing that was certain, was that they were gone.  And this is nearly game breaking since you spend a large portion of the game leveling up these characters, so to lose one in what feels like random chance is infuriating.Overall, the game is fun. It does a few cools things, and one really annoying thing. But in the end, I would still recommend it to other people.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												I highly recommend this game for those that love story, art, and strategy. The combat system is awesome. It's easy to learn, but a little difficult to master. Once you find that nice new strategy or trick to get through fights more effectivly, you feel a great sense of success and accomplishment. While the combat is great, the story and the art is where it's at. The landscapes are beautifully drawn and there are a ton of little details in the artwork that have stories of their own. The story of the game itself had me thinking of something from The Song of Ice and Fire series. This game gets you attached to characters and if you aren't carefull, or sometimes just to pull a George R.R. Martin, you'll have those characters violently ripped from you in a way that makes you feel guilty for not saving them. The game is full of moments that make you feel happy, depressed, relieved, exited, and afraid. Highest of fives to the developers of this game. They did an amazing job, completely worth the money. And if you want a trial, download their free multiplayer game "The Banner Saga: Factions". While it doesn't give you the amazing elements of the story, it lets you try out the combat and get a feel for the game. The Banner Saga is, once again, well worth your money.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												From a gripping story, to characters that feel real, The Banner Saga is an enormous feat of brilliance. Masterfully written, an art style filled with heart and soul, and gameplay that will leave you sweating, this game brings “saga” to it’s truest sense in both scale and experience. And what a saga it is.With an opening that states “The Gods are Dead” you can tell that this is a harsh and unforgiving world, and you’ve been thrusted into the middle of it, with your clansmen at your side as you travel from settlement to settlement more often than not just trying to survive.The gameplay is tactical and turn based, similar to XCOM and Shadowrun Returns, so before buying I’d suggest looking into it to be sure it is something you consider fun. If you are unsure I’d suggest letting this be your first! Though, even if the gameplay is not your cup of tea, if you like well told stories with great characters you might want to play it solely for that reason. Aside from a VERY abrupt ending the story and progression is golden. As you journey across the land the game feels very Organ Trail-ish as you watch your banner wave against the wind. Though, dying from dysentery is not a thing, so you can put that fear to rest if the mention of “Organ” gives you flashbacks.Being funded by Kickstarter, the budget for this game did not allow for it to be fully voiced acted aside from a handful of moments where a few main characters will speak, but with the soundtrack by Austin Wintory (Journey) you will hardly mind. The soundtrack alone is worth the price of this game.The experience refuses to leave my mind even days after completion. The Banner Saga has left me breathless and is one of those games that is both amazing and shows the power of what a well crafted game feels and looks like. I cannot suggest this game strongly enough!P.S. This game could also be called, “The Banner Saga, or,♥♥♥♥♥♥Continues to Get Real even when you think the♥♥♥♥♥♥has Reached it’s Realest Levels.”

Not to mention there will be times of frustration, the kind you get from watching Game of Thrones.Anyway...I can't really find anything negative to say about The Banner Saga, although at the end I was left wanting for more. It is short in my opinion and it could use some more features, like bigger battles and more RPG elements such as conversations.I for one hope to see more of this in the future!

												So far I've only played it a little bit, but It's a novel that you play. THIS GAME IS FANTASTIC! I normally don't play turn-based games like this, the closest I had played before this would be the classic D&D games, but the combat is easier to understand, and its sort of like chess where each piece has a range to move in, its own abilities, and a person you know from the story instead of a wooden pawn! Tutorials are well written, and easy to understand. I feel like I'm going to log some good hours, with multiple playthroughs. The Banner Saga is probably one of the greatest games I have ever played to date. Rich story, history, characters who have old friends and thier own personalities, beautiful artwork and locations, a giant (no pun intended XD) map with information about every treeline, mountain range, pool of water and landmark. 10/10, buy this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												I bought "the Banner Saga" because I was impressed by the combat mechanics in the earlier multiplayer game under the same name. As expected, the in-game battles were satisfying but what I did not expect was that it turned out to be one of the best RPG games I have played in a long time. It is a short game that can be finished within 6 hours. The graphics were strickly 2D (pretty nonetheless!) and there were no animations apart from some combat moves. There wasn't even much of expression change or voice acting for the characters but somehow you still felt strongly attached when good/bad things happened to them. The atmosphere created strong immersion and the story was short but gripping. The choices you made along the way had real consequences, some were immediate, while others were only revealed much later. Throughout the game, you would be asked to make many hard choices about which you often felt emotional. The journey was exhausting and full of twists and turns. Although I felt that the game ended prematurely (Spoiler: what about the "darkness"?), the ending was actually quite moving.If I have to use one sentence to sum up my impression of the game it will be: "the Banner Saga" doesn't do a whole lot but what it does offer, they were done very well.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												This is an amazing work of art, for starters. To keep it brief as can be, it's Oregon Trail in terms of "Watch something move across a horizon while waiting for♥♥♥♥♥♥to go wrong that needs your attention".It isn't as ruthless and esoteric as the problems you would face in Oregon Trail, but it doesn't pull its punches. People will die, it will be your fault, and you will struggle with the guilt and shame to the very end. "Could I have done better? Could I have saved so many people's lives?" is a question that lingers with me after completion.That's a good point to say the game is brief. It's part 1 of a trilogy. I had no idea until a google search pulled up that information. In regards to a first act this is quite the package. It ends so abruptly, but it couldn't end on a more painful and lingering note that demands you look forward to sequels.Aside from the scenarioes requesting your tense attention, there are several tactics-RPG style combat episodes. Enough to not feel like the game is void of tactic content, but also scattered enough to feel it does not take the role of being a tactics game first, before good story telling. The tactics depth in this game may not be as diverse as titles like Disgaea in terms of units and customization, however it is a brilliantly done experience. You'll find yourself forced to pace out a battle rather than simply focus-firing down targets in quick succession. Balancing weakening your opponents to prevent more pain dealt to yours, and preparing them for the decisive blow to end them- and most importantly the When.8/10. If this game was delivered as the whole package, it would easily deserve a 10/10 for its remarkable content and storytelling, especially with the agency you have within to feel the guilt and consequences continue to burn down through the course of your adventure. The gameplay, the story, and visual/audio art comes together into an experience that could not have been delivered better, save for the whole deal.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												The Banner Saga is a Norse mythos inspired story with mixed elements of Oregon Trail and turn-based strategy.  For much of it you are switching between two groups travelling through lands being overrun with giant monsters called Dredge and you can lead as the type to fight on the front lines or as a tactical advisor with many fights being avoidable. My initial impressions were it was a strong story with interesting travel choices and somewhat weak combat, but the more I played the more I realized there were quite a few layers of strategy to employ well beyond simply trying to beat down your opponents.The story is stupendously engaging, and even knowing one possible outcome I had to go right back in and do it again - with less screw ups! Even though you are constantly strained, on the run, and it is overall rather dour, there are moments which remind you there can be glimmers of light in even the darkest of times. I felt for the characters who were largely a ragtag band doing all they could to survive as their world fell apart around them.Even with its simpler game play, the art and audio fit great, and there's nothing like suddenly noticing the panorama is filled with skulking monsters bearing down on you. The soundtrack was a great addition to my playlist unlike anything I had before.Overall, it's challenging (especially on hard) and I've never been so engaged by a game where I was constantly on the edge of losing and if you remotely enjoy random event games or turn-based strategy then TBS is a must.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												I would have very likely overlooked this game completely if not for its promotion on EpicBattleAxe.com. That is my major bias out there for all to see. But another bias I have is a love for turn-based RPG titles that first bloomed with the original Jagged Alliance. Even after reading reviews, watching videos and listening to a lengthy discussion of the title, I admit to being unsure as to what sort of game to expect. The gorgeous art style and the fact that it is a turn-based RPG are the only two things I really knew before purchasing the title. Nonetheless, I was almost immediately impressed and addicted soon after. The Banner Saga is a minimalistic title that some may more bluntly call simplistic. This would be a fair criticism but the game presented a satisfying challenge throughout and most importantly, encouraged me (the player) to live with the decisions I made. This is where the simplicity ends and the nuanced and often dark morality of the title plays out. There aren't really any good or bad decisions to make and I was careful to police myself in accepting the consequences of my actions. This is something that is encouraged with recording progress being restricted to an autosave feature. Many of the design choices that may superficially seem unsophisticated became sensible after experiencing them. This is true of everything from the combat to the progression system. What was most important to me was that every little choice truly seemed to matter whether immediately or much later in the game. This certainly isn't a title for everyone but fans turn-based games and especially RPGs are certainly in for a unique experience at the very least.I eagerly anticipate the sequel.

												To be honest, I was kind of disappointed with banner saga. The begining looked wonderful, and the art style is beyond my expectations. content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												This game is very good at what it sets out to do.  It delivers an interesting story and thought provoking setting, encased in beautiful 2D animation.  I've played through it several times and I can stand by the statement that it is a very polished, and enjoyable experience.However, in my opinion there are 2 main faults of the game.  Without spoiling the ending, I will warn anyone reading this who hasn't bought the game that this game is not finished.  It is the first part of a trilogy.  The ending is shockingly sudden and does not resolve anything.  This would not bother me except for the fact that this game's Steam page does not indicate this in any way.  If they wanted to be accurate they should mark it as Banner Saga part 1 or they should say something in the description.  The other complaint that I have is that the ending is an A or B choice.  The choices you make along the way to the end do radically affect your journey, although they could have doubled down on that as well.  However, at the end you have to make a simple decision, and you have no further control over the ending.  I recommend this game to RPG fans, with those two disclaimers in mind.   If you want to know more about the ending before making your choice, there's no shortage of forum discussions on the topic.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												KING CAN SUCK MY-*Ahem*"The Banner Saga" is what I'd describe as being a "Low Fantasy-Viking Epic-SRPG-Multiple Choice Exam."The campaign puts you in control of one of two caravans (each with their own respective units) which are either fleeing or trying to fight back against an invasion of the mysterious, warlike, and seemingly inorganic Dredge. The perspective flips between the two caravans at several points throughout the story which should keep most players engaged should they grow bored with the story of one caravan.The battles are pretty much standard fare. They take place on a square map and make use of a grid upon which units move. The major deviation from the norm that I noticed is that your units have TWO "health bars:" Armor and Strength. Armor functions as a mitigator to damage against Strength. Also, Strength and Health are effectively one and the same. As a unit takes damage to its health/strength, they deal lesser amounts of damage and come closer to being knocked out (permadeath for individual characters IS present, but only through choices made in the story.)As your caravan travels, they expend the supplies which are needed to keep your caravan from dying of starvation. You can fairly easily maintain your supply count by spending "Renown," the game's currency which you gain from story choices, winning battles, and killing enemies. However, renown is also used to upgrade units and to purchase equipment. So juggling the effectiveness of your units with the wellbeing of your caravan can be a bit tricky.All in all, I found the "The Banner Saga" to be fairly challenging and I would recommend it to any gamers who're fond of RPGs and strategy games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												The Banner Sage seems like it was meant to be a well done graphic novel or movie, and somewhere along the way they decided to make it into a game. But it falls far short of being engaging or fun. They've certainly built a beautiful and well-populated world with a rich map and lots of back story. But in the end your choices don't seem much to matter and the chess style combat is boring. I was woo'd by the graphics and some of the reviews into buying this game, but it just isn't fun. While the game kicks off with sweeping landscapes and cinematics, it quickly falls flat as you spend the next ten minutes reading text-only dialogue that seems to have been written by a college freshman. And once you hit combat, you quickly realize why this game is a dud. Unlike successful turn-based games like Civilization or XCOM, where you manipulate your armies and make a series of choices in a turn, in Banner Sage you will tediously take turns moving a single soldier and then waiting for the opponent to move one soldier in an ill-defined "initiative" order. So you conceivably could move your hero, and then have to wait six or so turns before you can move him again, and the characters lack the well-defined individuality of a Dungeons and Dragons or other RPG instead boasting only armor and strength characteristics, so instead of a stratgeic chess game or an engaging RPG, The Banner Saga ends up as a tedious combination of The Oregon Trail and backgammon.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												I've always loved Fire Emblem and Final Fantasy Tactics while growing up, and seeing this game during the steam sale, I decided to give it a shot, as the general layout of the game looked decent, and the story seemed to be solid based on the reviews. It has been amazing this far, and I love the choices available to be made along the way, even if I don't realize the consequences. I enjoy choosing dialogue that matches what I personally feel, and though some of the choices lead to loss (sadly I lost two strong characters in my party), it does force me to be careful with my choices, regarding strategy and character upgrading, lest I stack one character with everything and lose him or her later on. It reminds me of permadeath in Fire Emblem, as I always feel I'm weighing options carefully every time a choice comes up in case I lose one of my party due to a twist in the plot.Battle wise, I'm finally getting used to the armor/strength system, very different from say, maxing out your general in fire emblem and never taking damage with him in the front lines. Every character can be fragile, and I've had several close battles where I've temporaily forgotten the slight intricacies of the Banner Saga that trip me up (allies can't move through allies, choosing armor vs strength dmg).Overall, I highly recommend this game, and I'm definitely moving on to multiplayer once I finish going through the rest of the 1 player story; I can't wait to see what happens next.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												95% of this game is beautiful. The writing is great, the art is gorgeous. They do a fantastic job of just letting you play the game. You make a choice, you deal with the consequences. You're totally immersed. Only a few other games (Walking Dead) have made me feel regret for choices I've made. Not in a 'oh I played the game wrong, and I regret that' sort of way. But more like in a 'I wonder if...' sort of way. Looking wistfully back down the road, thinking about the path you didn't take, the person you hurt, the hard choice you had to make, but knowing you have to press on.And then they throw all that beauty out the window on the final battle. Turns out, you should have been min/max'ing the entire time. Turns out you are going to be railroaded into a very specific strategy with very specific characters. Oh you wanted to play the story your way and chose not to use Allette so she's still level 1? That sure does suck for you! Because you MUST use her in the final battle. Through the game, the combat was challenging, I never finished a fight without a few knock-outs on my side. I even lost a few. But choices you made on the battle field affected the story. It felt like a struggle, but one that you were getting through. You never restarted or replayed a battle, you just made due with the consequences of your good or bad decisions. I loved that! Which made the bizarre try-hard 1337zor final battle all the more upsetting. I still can't beat it. Not with the character selection I ended up with, the choices I made in the game set me up *terribly* for the final battle. So...what? Just restart and play it again, this time with the final battle in mind? To me that just completely negates everything that I loved about the game in the first place.I would still recommend the game. It's beautiful. With these two caveats: Level up Rook and Allette, and put all your points in Armor-break.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Going into this game, I wasn't 100 percent sure of what to expect. The trailers seened vague, but the art and turn-based strategy combat lured me in. I did not expect to enjoy this game as much as I did.To describe the game simply, it is like Fire Emblem combined with Oregon Trail. The combat involves switching between you and your opponent everytime either of you move your unit. There are definately some unique factors that you must consider before leveling a certain stat or choosing characters to battle. You also couldn't just do one thing over an over again. You couldn't smack their strength directly every single time, sometimes you had to take out some armor, or use a skill. Probably one of the more frustrating parts of this combat was that once you moved a character, you couldn't cancel it, even if you didn't take an action after that. It led to some unfortunate battles involving one character getting in the way of all of my party, or getting mercilessly slaughtered. Almost all battles made me fear what could happen. The enemies nicely develop at the level of your team, so no battles are entirely a stomp. Overall though, the combat was engaging and fulfilling.The second part of the gameplay was the travelling. You travel with caravans filled with Fighters, Clansmen, Varl, and Supplies. You have to always think out your choices and they often have big effects on what happens to your group. You always have to think out whether or not you should buy more supplies here, or if you should rest and waste a day's worth of supplies, but raise morale for better combat. You are often rewarded by thinking out your choices, but sometimes, just playing the nice guy all the time just won't cut it. You may grow tiresome of having to watch your group move all the time, but the artwork was so beautiful, and those periods of time could give you time to sort out your thoughts on what your next move was.The gameplay isn't the only part of it though. This game has some of the most captivating art of any game I've played. The gorgeous, epic landscapes and style of drawing were just so visually appealing. At the same time, it could remind you of the bleak hopelessness that faced you, and inspire you. The soundtrack was also great. It fit the viking theme just right, but would never be overwhelming.As for the story, it's quite interesting. Although it may seem straightforward at first, the gradual learning of details and character development leads you to truly wonder about your previous predispositions. You really develop some connections with certain characters, but some others remain stale and mysterious. I won't spoil anything, so I'll move on.Now the game isn't without its flaws. There have been times when I just stared at the text on my moniter and just said "What the ♥♥♥♥." Certain events just seem to happen with no plot build-up or reason. It was like the writers just suddenly decided something needs to happen. Although it keeps the game interesting, it leaves you angry because it makes it seem like your choices were just meaningless and that they have no impact on the outcomes of the game. I also wish that combat was a little touched up, as some things can be frustrating.Overall, I found the game to be deeply enjoyable, and changed how I view and rate other games. The Banner Saga just implemented so many things that affected the gaming experience. I do agree though, that the game is a little pricy. I managed to grab it on sale for around $15.00, and I don't regret my decision. Take it how you will. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good story, character development, and strategy. 9/10.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Only Kickstarter could have allowed for something this creative.In an age of next gen technology and the a rush to make more games melt your graphics card while trying to achieve surreal effects, The Banner Saga reminds you that at the end of the day, it is all about the experience.Anyone with a love for Norse mythology will see how it has inspired this world, but Stoic has put in enough effort to give it a life of its own. The world is peeled away and revealed a bit at a time, allowing you to learn how to play the game and discover much more interesting developments. It is the end of the world and TBS does not let you forget it. Beautiful, throaty vocals provide a very emotional soundtrack. There is a nostalgic quality to the alien vocals, filled with sadness and rare surges of inspiration in connection with the main story points. The game is filled with stunning backgrounds and still images, which might not inspire some players to dive in, but the story is really brought forth through text and dialogue, fleshing out characters, while leaving enough to the imagination.TBS's main strength lies in its replayability. Different characters might die, and some will have no involvement in the plot at all. And this game is HARD! The decisions you have to make will leave you questioning what is the right course of action for your group, or for you yourself as a player. What do you feel comfortable doing, who you can trust, if you should risk another fight or run while you still have a chance. For such a simplistic interface, TBS poses very deep and interesting questions.The only flaw with this game is the ending. And it is an important flaw. Poor character builds will result in you have a very frustrating end boss fight. My first play through required hours for me to win and I hated it with time. It left such a sour taste in my mouth that I had to wait a while before replaying, and yes, a great experience from the beginning, loved the battles and challenges, until I reached the end again. If you have anger problems stay away from this game, or like me, it might make your blood pump pure rage and wonder if that pain in your head is what happens when neurons decide to implode. I would love for people to buy this, but not on the strength of this game alone, but for what Stoic will accomplish with this trilogy. An beautiful animated cinematic opens the game, and I couldn't help but wish that there had been more moments like that and more voiced characters. The Banner Saga is a very rare treat for the imagination and one where I really can't wait to see what happens next.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Overall it's a good game. Story is in depth, art is amazing. My onyl complaint is the combat system. It's an alternating turn system, so no matter how many guys are on one side or who is winning each team gets a turn after the other. It really makes the game much more difficult than it needs to be. It feels to me like instead of designing good AI that can give you a challenge it just rigs it to cheat. For example, you start off outnumbered. Kill a few but the computer always gets a turn after you, so what ends up happening is you're winning and they have one unit left but because they always get a turn that one unit the enemy has ends up killing 3 of your guys (which injures them crippling you in future fights) when you realistically should have the advantage and should be able to easily dispatch them. Like how it would be in real life.. In theory it sounds like it would add challenge, and it does, but comes off more like a rigged fight. It becomes really infuriating when this happens when the AI has a ranged unit left, because they hit hard. So they snipe your guys and then run away. I hope they fix this in future games. Otherwise great game. Feels like a fantasy, strategy Oregon trail.

												Sorry to say that bue The Banner Saga is a disappointment to me. As much as I like tactical turn based combat and the impressive 2d art style, the lack proper voice overs and sparse music breaks the game for me. There are voice overs but there incredibly rare (a line here and a line there, minimal at best) and the music while beeing fine is also used too little. The result is a game that for the most part is dead silent. Sitting there in front of the monitor reading the countless story related diaglogs is very tedious. I have no problem with reading books but reading from monitors is quite tiring for the eyes.I just don't get why a game that was so well funded on kickstartet is not fully voiced. There is no graphics engine to speak of, no 3d-models or textures. It's all hand drawn 2d and that is good. But why did they not take the money and time and have it fully voiced? There are speakers there, just far far to rarely used.Edit: I have to edit my review and have to correct the score from 'no' to 'hell no'. I played through the entire game fairly easily on normal difficulty but the final fight is impossible for me to win. I simply don't have the right characters properly skilled. You can misdevelop your party without even knowing ending up in the final fight you can no longer win. I would need to start the entire game over developing my party just for that final fight. That is such a stupid design that I'm lost for words how such crap could come ex-BioWare-devs. Banner Saga ist my pesonal favorite for disappointment of the yeat.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												Although comparable to Final Fantasy Tactics or Fire Emblem, both of which are games I enjoy immensely, the Banner Saga surpasses the two by combining realism and fantasy in a way that makes it a completely unique tactical RPG.How the player sees and interacts with the world of the Banner Saga, that's the fantastic aspect of this game.Yes, there are people that can wield lightning. There are also gigantic humanoids with horns. ...and moving statue-things that threaten the world as it is known. The artistic and musical portrayal of these details, the stylistic choices in regards with character design and interface, made the narrative blend seamlessly with gameplay.The Banner Saga's realism shows in the limitations emphasized in the gameplay. Each playable character is unique and has its own predefined capabilities. They can gain levels and improve, but only to a certain point. The player's choice of which characters he uses becomes more crucial because of this. In addition to that, time constraints and logistical pressures add a sense of urgency and weight to the story and the choices made by the player.As fun as FE was because of it, you can't just train your characters until they become completely over-powered. You don't have the time nor the option. In spite of the endless possibilities that FF Tactics provided with its class-system, you can't change a person's job on a whim. Unlike what many optimists may have you believe, individual people aren't pieces of clay to be molded into any shape or form.TL;DR The Banner Saga doesn't leave everything up to the player. This game is clear about what it wants to convey and how it wants to convey it. Did I ever wish I had more control over a situation when I played it? Dear lord, yes. That didn't stop me from enjoying the fact that my decisions mattered.

												Awesome and punishing at the same time, just keeps you coming back for more! The music and theme of the story complement each other perfectly and make for a very enjoyable experience.I have only two complaints, firstly the combat can be a little too slow, whilst its not an action orientated game it could do with a little polish to make it feel smoother. Second, I felt that the choices you made that affected the army didn't make as much of a difference as you were led to believe; If you mastered the party combat, it didn't matter if you made all the wrong choices and were left with a decimated army. This made me feel like it wasn't important to try and save your army.Those two point aside, its beautifully crafted and the narrative between the characters is compelling and pulls you in, (making you want to know more and explore as much of the history as they will tease you with) permeated with morally grey choices that are explored through the dialog, hugely affecting who stays in the party and the course your journey takes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Biggest gripes:1. No manual save, which seems at odds with the game's claim of empowering choice to determine the storyline.2. Characters don't die in battle, but they can die from Story dialog choices. If you want to check the other options, you likely have about 30 minutes or so of work to get back to where you were from the previous autosave/s.3. The actual turn-based RTS portion is atrocious. Each side alternates a turn for each unit in order, but if you have 6 people on the field and your opponent has 2, they get to move their characters 3x for every time your individual character moves. If those last 2 units left are heavy hitters then expect to lose at least 1-2 units before you put them down. I was expecting something like X-Com or Fire Emblem and it ended up being Chess without the ability to determine what piece you want to move.It's very pretty, but it's not fun to play.
