Posted: September 10, 2014
												this game is very atmospheric, has a great story and for the $10 i paid, i enjoyed it.however, this game's combat is trash. i have no problem with the tactical turn based style. the problem is that in order for that style to work you have to create a system where there is ONE set of rules, and everyone must abide by it, friend or foe.this game does not do that. your enemies can straight up cheat. they are not bound by anything even resembling the same rules you are, it turns the combat into a tedious chore to see the next cutscene, at best, and at worst nearly impossible.also, the supply system is more needless faff that adds nothing to the game, but lets it pretend it's SODEEP because your choices can cause you to lose supplies. of course, it's mostly meaningless, as clansmen are worthless and you can just run from battle when you encounter it in the campaign screen. it just feels like needless padding.that said, i still enjoyed the game. in easy mode it's about 6 hours long, and in harder modes it's padded out by fake difficulty as your enemies cheat harder and harder, forcing you to redo the tedious♥♥♥♥♥battles.don't pay more than $10 for this game.

I had lost people along my journey, both improtant and not so, but I kept pushing on.  Until I was unable to do so, the game just could not be beat and I refused to turn down the difficulty.  However, it is truly an incredible game filled with an incredible art style and supported by superb animations.  It bestows upon you a captivating story that you don't want to end.  It has given me characters that when they died, literally made me shout "NOOOO!" at my screen.  The choices the game gives you could range from catastrophic to harmless, and I found every time I made a choice, even if it was a bad one, that I wouldn't change it, that's how I thought to best handle the situations and if that caused horrible repercussions, so be it.So long as you don't play as I do, you'll have a captivating and fun experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Link to my Let's Play of The Banner Saga: http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLH76bElZ7XJMc2R6ybE2k3t01ItssJNheBetween The Banner Saga and The Banner Saga: Factions, I've probably put WAY too much time into this game... and I've loved every minute of it. They have taken your classic turn based strategy tactical game and wraped it in a layer of Oregon Trail and topped with a brilliantly told epic saga based around classic viking-esque lore.Total length: Roughly 10 hour or so storyline.The combat differs from a game like XCOM wherein you'd get your turn where you move all of your units and then let the enemy take a turn moving all of their units. In The Banner Saga you trade off on each unit movement. The Order they're moved in is based on how you organize your units prior to batter. This very miniscule difference makes for a pretty spectacular change in how combat is paced. Look at it this way, if you're getting slaughtered and the enemy has 5 units to your 2. You get to move your units 2-3 times before one of their units gets a second turn. It can really help turn the tide IF you're very smart about it but it isnt enough that it feels too powerful. The enemy also gets this advantage while outnumbered and can make setting up traps and cornering/surrounds units a solid strategy to make quick work of them. The Banner Saga is single player only... If you want Multiplayer go download The Banner Saga: Factions here on steam. It's free to play and has miniscule micro transactions for basic stuff like unit color variations or small boosts to the amount of renown (experience) you get in battle. The game does solid work of balancing your opponents as well. So if you're curious about this game but not quite convinced... go download Factions and give the combat a shot at least. Cheers!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Had a great time playing through this last weekend! Definitely want to do another playthrough,Games like this should definitely be supported, and I think that one should play this game, period.Some may find it too short for $25, but it would be a certain must buy at 50% off or lower.If you're on the fence, I say pick it up when it's on sale. Personally, I'm getting my money's worth out of it.It's definitely not easy, but in a game about vikings dealing with the end of the world, that seems appropriate. With A LOT of effort, I managed to get a caravan of over 500 people to Boersgard without losing them to low morale and starvation, and it actually felt like an achievement. It's the vibrant characters that got me invested and made me try and save the ones I care about, forcing myself into harder situations involving having mostly level 1 characters until the last chapter of the game.The world and art are beautiful and unique in a genre saturated with elves and dwarves, and Austin Wintory's soundtrack gives me chills. The elements of Icelandic culture and storytelling tropes have been woven into the setting and narrative excellently and make the game feel like a saga, an incomplete one though.My one gripe would be that the ending is that it's tone felt much more like the second act than the first, however that tone, while strange was unarguably new and fresh to me. With so much left unresolved in anticipation of a sequel, I feel like Stoic has a lot of responsibility to consumers to ensure the trilogy is concluded, and I hope to see them overcome their legal battle with King over the use of "saga" in their title. As long as this is ensured, I think any problems fans might have with the ending will be forgotten in context of the entire trilogy as a whole, and it is a good thing that the ending made me want more in that sense.This hopefully will also resolve what I feel is not enough variation on what is a unique ad interesting combat system, with a lot of depth and potential to develop in the single player campaign. In the sequel I would hope to see scenarios that add more of a twist to the mechanics than placement, as well as more boss battle scenarios. It would be interesting to see battles where you're defending a specific position, or have to escape an immortal Sundr by confining its movement. A good example of this variation would be half life, which introduced mechanics to players early on, and spent the rest of the game putting players in scenarios where the player's current strategies were challenged. Does the player always use a shotgun to kill this enemy type? Put them in a room with explosive barrels. Half life did have the benefit over Banner Saga of a longer campaign Ultimately I feel like games that do what Banner Saga does right are too few and far between, especially because I feel that larger studios are unwilling to take risks anymore. So while the game has areas that it needs to improve on, I want the studio to get the support and opportunities it needs to meet those needs and be a better game, because I thoroughly enjoyed it and want to see it succeed

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												My one-time playthrough on Normal difficulty (no reloading), took me about 9 hours.Without diving into too much, here's a quick review.Storyline: great. Characters can (and will) die, and you really feel the loss of each character. Personally, I got more enjoyment out of the Banner Saga's storyline when I compared it to reading a book from the Game of Throne series: Main characters may die, but the story goes on. Graphics: The 2d art style is great. Characters are well drawn, and the art style is really fantastic. The character animations in battle were fluid and superbly animated by some really talented artists. The closest parellel i can draw would be if the animators from old-school Disney cartoons (Pocahontas, Hunchback of Notre Dame) were asked to draw something that was nitty gritty and Viking-themed... Only quibble: An in-game cutscene tries to convey the sense of scale on a certain "Big S" of gargantuan proportions, but fell flat, and felt like a poorly made sequence made Flash way back in 2005. Gameplay: great. On Normal difficulty, the AI puts up quite a challenge. You'll be outnumbered frequently. You definitely need to learn and use your characters' special skills to get an edge.Music and Sound: Not much in-game voice; the few sparse sentences are sufficient. The music, however, is really great. The Viking (Celtic?) themed music is evocative and haunting.  Overall, the Banner Saga's story was engrossing enought to keep me glued for two marathon gaming sessions lasting almost five hours each, and I'm interested on how the storyline will turn out in the sequels.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Writing this review I am conflicted, The Banner Saga is a good game but I was not aware of a few things in it that had I known may have changed my choice to buy it.First despite a beautiful opening cutscene they never use that style again all game, the art will be the same style but there will be no other fully animated cutscenes, not even for the climax. instead you get images with maybe two bits here and there that flow in the breeze while text tells you things. that hurt the style and emotional feel immensely.Second is that this is not the whole story, the game ends on what feels like a big chapter but wraps nothing up, it seems like they intend another part to come out but I was not warned at all that the story was incomplete which leaves me in a sour mood since I thought I bought a FULL story not part of one.Third was that the game has many choices which feel good but can kill characters or take them away for no provided reason at anytime and with no way to know it will happen, this is frustrating when paired with the fact that you do not control when the game saves at all so fixing a sudden character death means hours of replaying.Do not get me wrong this is a great game, the style is nice, the story wonderful, the characters fun and engaging and the combat while not for everyone is one of the more unique and fun styles I have seen (Except for the final boss who like in many games just plain changes the rules of combat) but it feels like they cut corners in important places and did not make certain things like the fact the story is not done yet clear enough.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												A game of atmosphere and tone, above all else. The Gods are dead, the sun has stopped in the sky, and now the golem-like dredge are on the warpath, marking the dawn of a Third Great War of which the scale might well mark the end of the world.You play great heroes in this game, but this is not their story: this is a tale of a father and his daughter, caught leading a long train of refugees in desperate flight across the known world. This is the tale of those who would slip into the cracks and be forgotten in such tumultuous times, were it not for the bravery and heroism of a precious handful of normal folks caught far out of their depth.With an excellent soundtrack by Austin Wintory and traditional rotoscoped animation, the game really shines. The somewhat spare gameplay makes the choices you, the player, makes feel all the more important, and the square grid combat reveals a surprising depth of nuance and strategy--but one that isn't too deep to master in a playthrough or two. Some very gripping plot twists and turns keep you invested all the way through this first of (hopefully) many from Stoic Studio.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												While this game might not be for everyone, and in some ways it's a bit short, I have to say that it's a beautiful, thematic piece.  In addition, there's an almost Oregon Trail-esque feel to it because of the need to manage resources during travel.  Yet, unlike that game, this actually has a plot, and combat, with characters who possess distinct personalities.  It's a choice based game, which is wonderful, and even though many choices don't make a difference in what ultimately happens, they do impact resources, so one has to be careful what one does.  It's sufficient to say that I look forward to trying the sequel if it's half as good as this game.  There is sadness, but that just adds to the beautiful tapestry of this game.  For those who like to play games that aren't just about killing things, I recommend this title.

Posted: November 22, 2015
												This game is, wow it is amazing. Beautiful game overall, seriously, beautiful story, art, soundtrack, gameplay and ambience this game is a must play. The gameplay alone is something I can talk about for easily and hour, with an amazing health system this game plays like a PC fire emblem title with an amazing twist in your health and damage systems. Great story following two caravans, 1 which you follow for more of the game follows the story of Rook the leader of a caravan of clansmen fighters and what we would call giants(varl) is trying to save the world with his daughter.And the other one Hakon who actually is Varl leading another caravan doing pretty much the same thing. The story has a brilliant end, which I won't say. There is a lot more to the story than just that but, you should experience it yourself just trust me on that.The art is amazing I can't say much about it though just look at the damn screenshots and you will believe me.Soundtrack is an amazing orchestra composed by Austin Wintory, and it is also with what I can only describe as Norse vocals and such.The soundtrack only adds to the ambience as you travel through beautiful valleys and mountains with snow falling. Seriously this is probably the best looking game (not graphically in an art standpoint) I have ever played, Bastion taking a close 2nd.The only complaint I have of this game is a very personal one, I am not a very heavy or a very good reader, almost everything is read in this, but when voice acting is available, it is brilliant. Another one is that the split caravans kind of annoyed me mainly because Rooks story is much more interesting than that of Hakon's, but that problem is later fixed you will see.This game in a real standpoint has no problems from what I see, I mean it's a bit hard for some people but it is fair, so that isn't a problem. Seriously one of the most underrated games of 2014 I must give this game a 10/10 I love this game to death. One of my favourites. Seriously in my 10 favourite games of all time.Do I recommend it? HELL YES this game could go for $40 and I would still buy it even though it's only about 8-12 hours of gameplay. BUY IT NOW.

												This kickstarter game is the first chapter of a trilogy, and is quite fantastic.Set in a Norse inspired world, you follow two groups of humans and giant-like vargs as they try to reach safety from the swarming monsters. Part of the game you are fighting in a grid-based tactical roleplaying game, the other is watching your caravan travel past beautiful scenery while being forced to make decisions that could be good or bad, but generally have a long term affect that could either aid you or bite you in the rear.It's beautiful, the combat is decent, the writing is superb (though most of the dialog in-game is text only), and the choices are interesting and makes me wonder what would have happened if I went a different route. All in all a good buy, though it isn't the longest of game. Buy, especially when on sale, as it is a bit too pricey at the moment.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												From a gripping story, to characters that feel real, The Banner Saga is an enormous feat of brilliance. Masterfully written, an art style filled with heart and soul, and gameplay that will leave you sweating, this game brings “saga” to it’s truest sense in both scale and experience. And what a saga it is.With an opening that states “The Gods are Dead” you can tell that this is a harsh and unforgiving world, and you’ve been thrusted into the middle of it, with your clansmen at your side as you travel from settlement to settlement more often than not just trying to survive.The gameplay is tactical and turn based, similar to XCOM and Shadowrun Returns, so before buying I’d suggest looking into it to be sure it is something you consider fun. If you are unsure I’d suggest letting this be your first! Though, even if the gameplay is not your cup of tea, if you like well told stories with great characters you might want to play it solely for that reason. Aside from a VERY abrupt ending the story and progression is golden. As you journey across the land the game feels very Organ Trail-ish as you watch your banner wave against the wind. Though, dying from dysentery is not a thing, so you can put that fear to rest if the mention of “Organ” gives you flashbacks.Being funded by Kickstarter, the budget for this game did not allow for it to be fully voiced acted aside from a handful of moments where a few main characters will speak, but with the soundtrack by Austin Wintory (Journey) you will hardly mind. The soundtrack alone is worth the price of this game.The experience refuses to leave my mind even days after completion. The Banner Saga has left me breathless and is one of those games that is both amazing and shows the power of what a well crafted game feels and looks like. I cannot suggest this game strongly enough!P.S. This game could also be called, “The Banner Saga, or,♥♥♥♥♥♥Continues to Get Real even when you think the♥♥♥♥♥♥has Reached it’s Realest Levels.”

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												8/10This game is like a cross between Oregon Trail and Might & Magic: Heroes. You traverse beautiful 2D landscapes in Oregon Trail fashion (stopping for scripted events along the way to make important decisions as well as managing your resources). The battle sequences play out much like Might & Magic: Heroes or similar games (turn based RPG/Strategy).There is very little spoken dialogue so you will have to be prepared to do a lot of reading. Most of the decisions you make effect the game in significant ways so reading all the text and selecting your answers carefully are a must. After the first hour or two of play the characters and story really started to grow on me. If you think you’d enjoy this game, you probably will; it’s extremely well made and a decently long adventure for the price. If you hate reading or simply like to zone out while playing games this is not a good choice; it requires 100% of your attention.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Banner Saga is a turn-based tactical combat game that is guaranteed to enthrall you with all its Viking seriousness. Combat mechanics are simple. You take turns and you attack either STRENGTH or ARMOR.You start off as a small band of Varls, powerful horned giants mowing down puny humans that stand in your way, with the entire story becoming more and more epic as your band of follower grows and new characters are added to the cast. Use your kills (translated into renown) to upgrade your team members. The trick here is always to have an even mix of bleeders (strength damagers) and breakers (those that specialize in attacking armor so your bleeders can have an easier time). You'll make hard choices... choices that will kill off your characters or alter how the ending goes. The art is classic, a refreshing crisp clear feel that stand in its own way against the super-realistic graphics espoused by most third or first person shooters and platformers we see nowadays. I don't know about most people, but I FELL IN LOVE when I reached my first Godstone.The only sin that this game has done is its way too short, and there are too little items, I suppose... but the Kickstarter somehow mentioned that this is just the first part of this Saga, and I know Viking Sagas have to be much longer than this. STOIC deserve a good pat on the shoulder for this game that redefines the turn-based genre and storytelling. Just make the second part so we can continue dealing with the Jormungand lookalike.

												In a nutshell, It's a Final Fantasy Tactics, Fire Emblem, or Tactics Ogre for the masses. The gameplay in combat is relatively simple and thus approachable, but the story is as compelling, involving, and dark as those of the epics mentioned above. And in essence, this focus on narrative, art, and music, relegating gameplay to making simple choices reminiscent of those found in Oregon Trail and engaging in light tactical combat may be the game's greatest strength and weakness. I pre-ordered mine from GameFly for $14.00 and am glad to support this flawed but tremendous three-man effort.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												The Banner Saga is an absolutely stunning Strategy RPG. From a technical standpoint, the visual style is magnificent; whether you're looking at the each character's design as they engage in dialogue or the passing vista as you journey in you caravan, you will not be disappointed. The use of rotoscoping in the animated cutscenes and the actual gameplay was a very good choice and enhances the charm of this Indie title. The music suits this game as well. Thanks to the composer who worked on Journey, you are treated to aural goodness during battles and travelling.The story is quite engaging with the player taking mulitple viewpoints of the situation from different characters. Without spoiling too much, you play as a leader of a caravan moving from various settlements attempting to escape an ancient foe. However, you will soon find out that life on the road can be quite harrowing and decisions must be made so that survival is ensured each day. That's another thing: the decisions made in this game aren't typical black/white/red/blue choices; they are considerably gray and deal more in how you choose to lead your flock.Congratulations to Stoic for this great game (I've played through it twice now!) and I look forward to future installments.

Although you can reload an autosave, I wouldn't recommend doing this, as it will ruin the experience of making hard decisions)- appreciate hand-drawn graphics

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												The Banner Saga is greatly inspired by Norse Mythology and does well to capture that viking feel to it. I thoroughly enjoyed the art style of this game, that old cartoon look was very appealing to me. The gameplay was challenging with a turn based combat system and caravan style out of combat system I often found myself carefully constructing my strategies before taking any action (Which I seldom do in strategy games these days since you can normally brute-force your way through things). The choices you make in the game are rough and small, seemingly insignificant choices you make near the beginning of the game can and will affect you later on.There were a few things I disliked, first being the voice acting. The game begins its first cutscene fully voiced but that's it, the rest of the game is purely text. Budget concerns would make sense but if they were to not voice the entire game it wouldn't have taken much effort simply to just take out that one set of dialogue. Secondly, and I will be brief to avoid spoilers...the story just stops when things get intense which was a killer for me because I fell in love with the story and wanted closure. There are rumors for the next Banner Saga game and I hope they made enough money to continue development because this is a story I do not want to have left unfinished.7/10 (Average: Definitely worth your money and a playthrough or two)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												If you don't know much about this game and just jump to the reviews, here you go. This is a turn based strategy game with meaningful choices that feel similar to a choose your own adventure. It is set in a viking styled fantasy setting, with humans and giants with horns called varl as the two dominant races, fighting against the evil dredge. This game is the first of three parts of the Banner Saga story. The game has a fairly steep learning curve to truly excel at fights, as many fights that seem to be a cakewalk at the beginning can turn into a bloodbath for your party, resulting in injuries that can linger into the next fight if not taken care of. The system of two health bars, one armor and one health *and* attack is pretty unqiue and can take some time to wrap your head around to take advantage of, as well as with the way turns are done. However, it is not something so bad that you have to throw on easy to get by, normal is definitely managable and I can't wait to try it on hard. Also the experience earned in battle, renown, is also treated as your money, similar to Dark Souls. However, there are some nuances.  The story (thus far) has been exciting and made me care about the party characters. When I made a decision that ended up resulting in a character's death, I felt crushed. Sure, I could save scum and reload and change my choice, but that defeats the purpose of the choices. If you play it, dare I use the word, correctly and without loading saves to pick the perfect choice (not always applicable), the game feels similar to FTL if you've ever played that. You can't always be the friendliest guy or else it can be bad for your and your people. While I personally enjoy it, it's not for everyone. There is definitely some dark to this world and story. However, there are some faults. As previously mentioned, the way that the turns are handled in combat can lead to some... interesting things in combat, such as an enemy character going twice or even three times to your characters once, purely because there are only two enemy units remaining. Due to this, it is better to simply hurt enemy units down to a weak state rather than outright killing them to prevent stronger enemy units from getting more turns. Also previously mentioned are the nuances of the renown system. To level up a unit, they must have acquired a set number of kills in battle. Unfortunately, some units are better set to weaken enemies to let others strike the killing blow, which naturally leaves them weaker in level unless you specifically farm kills with those units. Not a huge problem, but something that can be annoying to deal with.  Overall the game gets my recommendation, and if I hate to rate it I'd give it a solid B+. It is definitely worth the price (moreso if you get it on sale), and certainly a good game, with some room for improvements which will hopefully find some way to work around for the other two parts. If you want to give the combat a spin, you can try The Banner Saga: Factions which is the free PVP version of the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I really wanted to love this game. I really did. I pushed through one play through, that is all this game is getting from me. I'd be more upset if I hadn't picked this game up for only 10 bucks. The art, great. The music, great. The story, I didn't know what to expect. It is a good story, sad for sure. Nothing epic at all. The game ends on a flat note leading into the upcoming second game. The leveling system is terrible. The only way to level your team is with kills, well kinda. In order to promote a unit, that unit needs to get the last hit on a bad guy. Then you have to spend the only resource in the game, renowned in order to get points (2 per level) to spend to make your unit more powerful. That is obtuse enough, but it gets worse. That same resource is what you also must spend on food to keep your people from starving to death. The game has little replay value as you are railroaded the whole time. The world map has no reason to be in the game as it is not used for anything. There will be a good, neutral, and bad out come to many of the random encounters that pop up as you wait to get from place to place. Given enough time you could find what answer A B or C is best. So those encounters aren't choices, they are only consequences. The UI is a bit odd at times, you can't delete your last played game. If you start over, the save gets pushed to a new profile that is ambiguous at times. This is another in a long string of games that has come out lately from indie dev types that has been a let down. This was a Kick Starter backed progect. The goal was 100k, they picked up 700K. 7x as much cash as they were looking for. Along with the multiplayer packs that can be bought... I just can't see where that money went. Clearly they dropped a very large sum on the music, and that is great. But what is better? A game that is better than a 7/10 experience at best. I will keep a lookout for The Banner Saga 2, but my expectations will be twice as high.

												Sorry to say that bue The Banner Saga is a disappointment to me. As much as I like tactical turn based combat and the impressive 2d art style, the lack proper voice overs and sparse music breaks the game for me. There are voice overs but there incredibly rare (a line here and a line there, minimal at best) and the music while beeing fine is also used too little. The result is a game that for the most part is dead silent. Sitting there in front of the monitor reading the countless story related diaglogs is very tedious. I have no problem with reading books but reading from monitors is quite tiring for the eyes.I just don't get why a game that was so well funded on kickstartet is not fully voiced. There is no graphics engine to speak of, no 3d-models or textures. It's all hand drawn 2d and that is good. But why did they not take the money and time and have it fully voiced? There are speakers there, just far far to rarely used.Edit: I have to edit my review and have to correct the score from 'no' to 'hell no'. I played through the entire game fairly easily on normal difficulty but the final fight is impossible for me to win. I simply don't have the right characters properly skilled. You can misdevelop your party without even knowing ending up in the final fight you can no longer win. I would need to start the entire game over developing my party just for that final fight. That is such a stupid design that I'm lost for words how such crap could come ex-BioWare-devs. Banner Saga ist my pesonal favorite for disappointment of the yeat.

												With most games I buy, I wonder in the back of my head if it was worth the purchase. Did I really get my money's worth for this experience? Was the price tag justified? content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												A masteful, powerful, challenging and rewarding tactical role-playing game. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys turn-based strategy games and anyone who enjoys a good story. Where to begin? I guess I will start first on the battle mechanics. The armor-health/strength system, willpower and exertion points, and the ordered, one-move-per-turn system was a hurdle to me (I've only experienced the HP/MP/Atk/Def... system) and challenged me to rethink my strategies. But although it took me a little while to get used to, it's actually a really fun and rewarding system that above all, after a little thought, makes a whole lot of sense. This dynamic made me think twice about sending my heavy-hitters to the frontline and made the defensive characters all the more invaluable. In this game, not only do enemies block movement but so do allies (with one or two exceptions). This results in carelessly causing a wasted turn or a character's death, or, if taken advantage of, a clever block to cut off an enemy's path. You'll need to use these strategies and think carefully about moves because one mistake can cost you the whole battle. The game says that itself (in the Training Room), "Your enemies are stronger than you. You need to outwit them." Each battle the enemy has an advantage in stats or in number. I love the artwork. It's beautiful. I wish I had the words to aptly describe it. All I can say is that there's a lot to appreciate. Same thing with the music. Put the volume up and you will feel epic.The storyline and setting is great. But I would say it is more mature-themed, along the lines of Game of Thrones. The characters all stick out in their own way. It captured my attention and my imagination. Maybe that's why more than once I spent solid minutes agonizing over which decision to make, on who to trust, on what to give up and what was more important, and even when the decision was made, what if I chose something else..? This game has a big focus on decisions and its consequences and does a great job. TL;DR: mature, inspired by Game of Thrones. fun, rewarding battle system. engaging story with decisions that matter. beautiful artwork, great music. Must try.This game deserves its praise. I really would love to see more.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Alright, this game is amazing in a way that I can honestly say I haven't really come across before.It is also brutal, annoying, and at times depressing, but this is in part why it is so amazing.  Most games that offer you some kind of choice make it clear what the result of your choices are going to be, and even if they don't, there are often multiple ways around the problem (save scumming or similar tactics).  Banner Saga fights that trend, both with its save system, but also, and perhaps more importantly, by separating the consequenecs of your choices from the moment in which you make the choice.  Honestly, at times, it feels almost like you are one of the Starks in the Game of Thrones, with people dying without you having much control over it, but this is why the game is SO GOOD.  It gives you power to affect the story, but it doesn't make that story happy, easy, and most importantly, it doesn't make it simple.This is the kind of game I want to see more of, something that doesn't hold the hand of the player, a game that can actually make me feel base on MY decisions.Oh, and just for the record, the art is awesome, the combat is deceptively simple (look close enough and there is a TON of depth), but for me, it is that journey, that awesome bane of my existence for the last however many hours, that really makes this game.Go play it, now.

												Update 01/17/2014: Finished the game after 13 hours.  Hopefully they will add more.  It kind of leaves the story dangling other than that and the previous issues game is awesome.01/15/2014 - So far this game rocks!  Graphic style is amazing.  I love all the detail.  Turn based strategy with some RPG elements.  If you liked games like final fantasy tactics or xcom series you will love this.  You earn renown for making "right" decisions and in battle.  There are a couple different types of resources in the game.  Soldiers are broken up into two groups either Val or fighters there are also clan members but I don't know what if any good they do so far.  One story line just has you trying to keep your clan alive so maybe if you run out you lose?  Renown ends up being the currency that is used to buy items or supplies.  Supplies are used on your travels and if you run out there is starvation and even death.  Great blend of storytelling, battle and decisions.  You also get a fair amount of warriors to use in your personal battles.  Drawbacks: Had a game crash a couple hours in but too early to tell if that will be an issue.  No subtitles which I like because of the amount of noise that can be present at my house.  Also the save game is only auto save this kind of sucks.  I had a game crash after a couple battles and will need to replay if you are going to make it autosave at least autosave more often.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												The best description I read for this game was: "Game of Thrones meets Dinsey and Vikings". That tells a lot about The Banner Saga. It is a rpg set in a well-made viking world, with disney-like art, full of different (and really hard) choices to make.The game has, basically, three main features: (1) a good storyline, in which you follow different characters and make your choices on how the story goes;(2) a viking caravan to maintain, in which you have to manage supplies, morale, number of clansman and fighters;(3) a turn-based strategy combat (like Final Fantasy Tatics), with different classes, skills, level-up and items.The combat system is so enjoyable that they have an on-line version of it, called The Banner Saga - Factions (free to play).The only bad thing I found for this game is that it feels really short (aprx 10 hours). It claims for its sequels.So, in general, the game is so enjoyable that the only bad thing is that it ends too soon.ps: if you're in doubt if it is worth to pay for it, try the free-version (The Banner Saga - Factions) first as a test =)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												Character damage is based on his HP and each side's turn is over after only one of his character moves.  This means the optimal strategy is to get an opposing character down to 1 hp rather than kill them.  Playing optimal strategy ends up being very annoying because of this.  Instead of applying rational strategy like most other strategy games you spend a lot of time trying to figure out how to best keep all enemy characters just barely alive.  It is counter intuitive and just plain annoying to do.A problem with this game is that you just end up staring at long cut scenes which cannot be skipped.  There isn't much to look at and a few times they go on for minutes.  It is just your caravan walking toward a hill or whatever.  Really feels like it wasn't game tested... surely somoene would have suggested to skip these.When starting a battle you often have the choice of how many opponents you will face.  The battles are completely random and there is no information to predict which option to choose.  The exact same numbers of army sizes can be given but the number of enemies you face could be double.  The problem with this is that many fights are going to be too easy, yet if you set the difficultly to hard then some become pretty much impossible.  It is just unpredictable and pointless.  Worse, you can't even manipulate the game to make it a reasonable challenge each time - often you cannot save between each fight.  So you end up spending 10 minutes mowing down a super easy fight and the very next one is impossible because you chose all the hard options... then you have to redo the easy one.I faced a total of just a few different enemy types after maybe 40 battles.  Human melee characters that are mostly the same, the armored enemies with a big and small version for melee, and a ranged version of them.  The difference in strategy between fighting these characters is extremely limited... after about 15 minutes you'll have it figured out and be bored.tldr: The game play sucks - I've played many free flash games with better game play than this.  Overall it is just a frustrating experience.  If you wanted a slowly told story with politics and moral choices to be made... then I guess you could set it to medium mode and get through the game, though.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												This is a REALLY great game, the voice acting (abeit minimal) is superb for am indie game, and the soundtrack is great, complementing the story and environment greatly. Not to mention a great storyline combined with meaningful player choices, this makes for an intense 2-D old school turn base RPG.However, the ONLY downside is the notoriously frustrating combat mechanics.This game is RELENTLESS in terms of combat, and if you're a beginner I would strongly recommend starting out in normal or even easy mode. The reason why combat is so hard is mainly because of 1 simple reason, you deal LESSER damage as your health decreases. This inherently means that the longer the battle drags on, the more disadvantage you're in. Combine with the fact that the A.I is smart enough to ignore your tank and go straight for your DPS(almost all the time), be prepared for a frustrating game.But however, if you enjoy a little challenge and have a few hours to waste, I would recommend picking this game up, especially if its on discount, if not just for the music and story.

												One of the most beautiful games I've ever played. The soundtrack is absolutely amazing and I'm a fan of the art style they used. The game is very story-centric with aspects of making VERY tough decisions that often don't have clear answers to them. While I wouldn't call the tactical battle style unique, it certainly felt different from similar games. Fighting never felt like a chore, which I enjoyed. Each character feels different, both from a story aspect and a stats point of view.I have a few complaints, however. During gameplay you must make decisions about random story elements, and while I enjoy that several have very dire consequences (such as characters dying), it felt silly that these people could be okay after falling in battle several times, only to dissappear with one wrong prompt. I really wish the character portraits were animated more during talking scenes, as they feel slightly awkward. Also, the story ends very abruptly (I know they are planning for more games) but I didn't understand some of the plotlines shown within the game, so there's that.

												The game is very pretty. I like the music and the atmosphere. The story is interesting and the choices you make actually impact the storyline. The battle mechanics are a little annoying (at least to me), though. The battlefield looks like a chessboard, so you basically move your pieces about.  Some races are bigger than others so it's easy to get confused because it's difficult to see (for example) how many open spaces are behind a big piece. Since it's not really 3D you can't rotate the battlefield (which might feel more natural). Another remedy may be to just make the big pieces somewhat transparent if the potential path of a player's piece was behind it.You can't really have too many different strategies in battle. Basically, battle strategy is:1) Maim everything.2) Try to keep your characters healthy.3) Once you maim all the enemies significantly you can then proceed to dispatch them all. I really wanted to like the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												The Banner Saga is a truly fantastic game. It is a tactical RPG set in fantasy world inspired bu Norse mythology. The first thing that you will notice about this game is its very unique, and beautiful artstyle. The striking artstyle reminds me a lot of classic Disney animated films such as The Black Cauldron, and its the first time I have seen it used for a long time in a video game.The Banner Saga's grid-based tactical combat is challenging and very enjoyable, but most of the game will be spent in between the combat sections, traveling across the land. During this journey your main concern is keeping your clan alive and well, through conserving supplies, maintaining morale, and making tough decisions that will often have major consequences; good or bad. The strength of the game however, is in its worldbuilding and enthralling story. A huge portion of your time playing the game will be spent reading the brilliantly written dialogue and narration, so expect to be reading a lot. When you are victorious in battle you will receive 'renown', the game's currency, which you will spend on supplies, making decisions, and equipment that can upgrade your party members. This renown system is very unforgiving however, as you will probably spend it on items, decisions, or  supplies, and then later on realise you needed that renown for a crucial decision that could have dire consequences. The story is fantastic, but a cliffhanger ending left me feeling slightly unsatisfied, although a good sequel would remedy this. Overall, The Banner Saga has very few flaws at all, and should definitely be experienced, if only for its rich story, and stunning aesthetic. 8.5/10Wonderful. A one of a kind experience, that's worth it even at full price.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 10
												In games, as in any medium, genuine innovation is rare.  This is not, in itself, something that should surprise anyone. As well following from a kind of  general law of reality (I'm thinking of Spinoza's eloquently expressed truism that "all things excellent are as difficult as they are rare."), commerical art -- and what art, today, isn't commercial? -- is subject to all sorts of exigencies that ultimately add up to incentives to follow the apparently tried and true and to avoid the road not taken like a hospital that only doles out flesh-eating viruses and bankrputcies. After all, if you're investing the kind of time and money that goes into a AAA game or a Hollywood film, why wouldn't you try to take as few risks as possible in the hope that you can thereby ensure a return on your (often vast) investment?One reason, of course, is that consumers are capricious and paradoxical in ways that (thankfully!) can be counted on to continually confound people who think they've found the magic forumla for the next mega-hit. Thus, on the one hand, people clearly like (and are wont to buy) things that are like other things that they like. The studio exec. nows this. At the same time, however, when we remember what made us first fall in love with a certain genre (or with a place, a pasttime, a person)  often what we remember most fondly is not that 'this met with our pre-existing desires', but that this encounter, *educated our desires*, made us into a certain kind of desiring-being.  It's the difference, ultimately, between finding an itch that we never knew we had (a sudden awakening of inhoate desire) as opposed to coming back for our umpteenth compulsive stcratch. To the corproate exec. types this is infuriating: consumers want (and will demand) that their tastes should be catered for and indulged to an inch of their lives...right up to the point that we feel that we're being pandered to at which point, we start to feel that we're being treated like drug addicts, that the dealers are cutitng our stuff with random crap that we never wanted and that actually, thank you very much, we prefer the desperate thrill of having stumbled across an undiscovered country rather than being served up the same crap day after day like a child...It's with all this in mind, that I should say  that The Banner Saga is not only an excellent game, but it's the best thing to have happened to rpg and strategy games for about a decade. What exactly is so good about it? Well, if you've seen the screenshots and the trailer, I'm hoping that I won't need to sell you on the art-style and thus it's extraordinarily beautiful, hand-crafted retro-charm. I could also add that the game makes many allusions to what looks like a unique and intricate lore that is, at the time of the game's release, still only minimally fleshed out. In addition, the story is compelling, the characters (though tending towards they archetypal) are generally intriguing and the turn-based combat has considerable depth. All of this, however, could be said about any number of games. So what makes TBS so different?If I had to try and put isolate what makes the game so brilliant and so surprising, I would start by saying that as well as the sense of something new (an original IP, a distinct lore, a distinctive art-style) in a market whose governing principle is: "you want more of the same, don't you?", what really makes the game stand out is  the way that its rpg and resource management mechanics (as well as the games fundmaental *difficulty*) are integrated with and contribute to the tone of the game's narrative and its wider world. To explain, TBS is, at its core, a narrative of desperation. It is a story of flight, of exile, of trying to survive and to keep the people you love alive under circumstances so dire as to be almost hopeless.  In TBS, it's an axiom that people (a lot of people) are going to die, even and espeically if you are motivated by nothing more than trying to save as many people as you posisbly can. What is so satisfying about the way that the game manages to connect this  narrative-thematic dimension with the core gameplay. Granted, a skilled strategists might find they get through the game with fewer losses than people who are less adroit, sneaky, determined or just prone to look up strategy-guides. For me, however, the real beauty of TBS is attested by how few times I found myself reloading my save game. This may seem odd (and it's not entirely true -- I did reload a few times to try and avoid certain consequences of my actions). Nonetheless, the game constantly reinforces the way that because your choices  do have ramifications (a desideratum on many gaming wishlists, especially among rpg fans), you cannot both ask that htese  consequences exist and that they should be in your control. Put differently: the game makes it seem not only difficult, but out of the spirit of things to try and 'optimise a set of outcomes' or 'to get the good ending'. As a result of this, every decision you make in the game seems weighty, just as every fight seems like (and irrespective of how much you've levelled up your characters) like it might just be your last. Disaster awaits around every corner. Acting on principle will sometimes lead to disastrous consequences, but so might a cynical pragmatism. The effect is that your partaking in something real, that you're not so much living out a fantasy where everything turns out wonderfully as much as you are a lead character in a tragedy: like you're roleplaying the entire cast of one of Shakespeare's history plays.Overall, what I really loved about this game was the way that it used (relatively simple) mechanics, decision trees, resource management and fairly difficult turn-based combat, to enforce the sense that my characters were fighting for their lives. I felt bruised and battered playing this game. I winced everytime a character got hit. I felt something akin to the shock and grief that my characters must have felt when a loyal companion who'd gone through hell with the party, suddenly disappeared forever not in the midst of a heroic sacrifice but out of a random occurrence or worse through one of the numerous unintended consequences of one of my carefully thought out decisions.  In fact, even the way that I ultimately kind of *sucked* at the game (e.g. being less than masterful at resource management), contributed (a rare thing) to my enjoyment of it, in the sense that it exacerbated the sense that I, like the protagonists, was heavily burdened with responsibilities that I did not know whether I could handle: that I was letting down the people I was trying to help, that I was  vacillating between letting people starve and letting them getting picked off by monsters, that I could and (continually *did*) fail by both virtue and vice, idelaism and pragmatism, trust and distrust, boldness and caution. I'm scribbling too much, but for now, I'll just say everyone (especially fans of crpgs, turn-based strategy or resource management should get this), as should anyone (designers, anyone?) thinking about the Holy Grail of the integration of narrative and ludic elements. A minor masterpiece, I can easily imagine this one playing a prominent role in classes on game design, especially where "ludic-narrative integration" (pretentious as the phrase may be) gets discussed.TL;DR: Gut-wrenching. Extraordinary integration of gameplay elemetns to contribute to the overall brooding, tragic, 'unforseen consequences' atmoshpere.

												I liked it, but I feel it's been overhyped. The first thing you need to know is that this is essentially Chapter 1 of 3, and the story won't feel complete if you don't play the other chapters (haven't played 2 yet). Otherwise : PROS: Nice caravan system. Choice and consequence. You do have some control over how your character treats others they encounter along the way, and which characters can stick around with you. Not full control, which means some characters... are better left out. Thankfully, it's not stupidly obvious which ones that is, nor is it unrecoverable or rage-quit inducing if you let them tag along anyways. To get back on topic, this is handled well. Risk, if you like that sort of thing. It's perfectly possible to lose your best follower to some story event (I did). It's also perfectly possible to still win. Lore. This is an interesting world with interesting races, characters, etc. The story, overall. Pretty epic stuff going on there. Interesting turn-based combat system. Not your typical combat system either. Hps are used for damage, and it works because of the way armor works. Also you have to spread out your damage because each side gets  a turn in which they play a single unit, and you don't want to give high strength or undamaged units more turns (Ie: if you have 4 dudes and so do the ennemy, and you take one out, then each remaining dude plays once every 3 turn instead of once every 4. If you had instead damaged 2 units then they would have been a lot less dangerous each time their turns came up). It's refreshingly different. I wouldn't want this in every turn-based game but in this one it works. Art style. It's pretty neat. CONS: The ending. I won't say more to avoid spoilers. Except no epilogue. WTF. Managing supplies vs morale vs renown hardly seems to have mattered. Maybe I was just good at it? *shrugs* Didn't feel that way though. Was often in weak morale with no food and no renown (as I purchased a lvl 5 item before i realized how that worked. Protip : don't!). The story diverges into what I assume is the core of the sequel/trilogy's story quite quickly, which means this chapter's story is not as focused as it could have been. This is probably for the best of the overall trilogy, but it contributes to making the ending suck. Fairly short. I played about 12 hours. Overall I recommed this game as it is fairly different, and the story is engaging.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												Oh wow. I have just finished my first play through of The Banner Saga. It is passed midnight, I have to be up early tomorrow but I just couldn't stop playing. Tired tomorrow? Still worth it! But you must forgive me if this review seems a little hysterical. It is rather late but I just had to get my thoughts down while it is still fresh.I feel I must break down my review into categories to help me better explain just why I loved this game.First and foremost: Visuals I cannot lie that the distinct art style is what first drew me to this title. It is just breathtaking. Every scene, every character is beautifully drawn that I just could not bear to look away. Even during combat the locations and characters maintained their style. As the caravan journeys across the lands you see magnificent Godstones, carved homages to the dead Gods, the detail is amazing. The artists truly put a lot of love and effort into this game, and it shows. If they ever decided to make an animated feature film for the lore of this series I would ecstatically buy it! Seriously if you are a fan of art and animation this title should be picked up for that alone! The music I was lucky to pick this game up when it was on sale so I decided to upgrade and get the soundtrack as well. I am so glad I did. If you think the art is beautiful wait until you hear the beautiful music, composed by Austin Wintory. It adds such a beautiful ambiance to each scene. Giving you a sense of dread, comfort and awe as you pass each village and mountain. I found it never took over the scenes to the point of distraction though so never fear, it is not the type of soundtrack that you find painfully distracting while looking for the mute button. Combat Now it’s time for full disclosure. I have not played many strategy games, I played a little diablo back in the day, games like total war and Pillars of Eternity (another amazing title! Go check it out!) So I cannot say with absolute certainty that this is a sophisticated, complex strategic combat system, however I found that on normal difficulty the game was very fun and fairly easy to complete. If you are new to this style of game, this title is not intimidating and a good introduction into strategy.Player choice Now this I loved. I adore RPGs that give you decent choice. Especially if you can never be certain if the choice is the ‘right’ one. Do you let these random men into your caravan or send them away? Do you stop and help a person or be on your way? Do you side with person A? Or Person B?  Just what are the consequences? I made a decision on day 3 in game, seemed like a fair choice at the time, All seems well until sometime around day 90 that the consequences finally played out. Each choice has weight to it and no decision should be made lightly, sometimes even the obvious choice may not be the right one.  Who lives? Who dies? Well that depends on you doesnt it?Levelling and resources Now this is a balancing act! Levelling and resources use ‘renown’. Resources keep your people alive, Levelling keeps you alive in battle, winning battles gives you renown. Do you level up your character? Or wait to buy more supplies so your people and soldiers don’t starve to death? Each has their consequences but I found it fun to try and manage it all.Lore and characters I adored the characters in this game! The lore was just enthralling. I found myself wanting to read everything and learn as much as I could about the dead Gods and the Varl. It really is beautiful and interesting so I advise you to pay attention!This game is a solid 9½/10. Why does it lose half a point? Well there is one thing that annoyed me. The final boss fight. Don’t worry this is a spoiler free review. All I can say is that there was a tremendous difficulty spike. It angered me so much at one point I was tempted to lower the difficulty. Luckily I persevered and managed to finish the game without doing so. So don’t give up! But this was the only thing that bothered me in over 12 hours of gameplay.All in all I had a wonderful time, I heartily recommend this beautiful, enthralling game. I can’t wait for the sequel to be released! 9½/10 Stars!

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Viewing it strictly as a video game it is, loosely, a turn based strategy game with some other stuff wrapped around it and it's kind of fun. If you instead view it as an immerse story telling experience wherein your primary job is to manage a caravan of refugees fleeing from the end of the world across a bleak Norse mythology inspired world where you occasionally have to play a turn based strategy minigame, it is fantastic. The Banner Saga is probably the best video game I've ever played in terms of its ability to set a tone which it does through music, writing, artwork, and game play. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												To be entirely honest, when I saw this appear on the steam store a few weeks ago, I blindly bought it because I saw vikings, which is pretty juvenile in and of itself. I literally had no idea what to expect when I purchased it, and did no research up until its release. Let me say this; I was utterly floored by what I have experienced. This game is the perfect mix of epic story telling (the world that you become engulfed in, the characters that you invest your emotions into) and old school turn-based fighting (which doesn't really get boring because once you learn to strategize it gets interesting). It might not be game of the year, but it comes damn well close. If you like epic story, and you can handle the turn based fighting mechanics, this is a 100% reccomendation. I have fallen in love here, and I simply cannot wait for more from this studio either pertaining to this game (into a series perhaps?) or a new IC.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												To say this game is amazing is an understatement. Banner saga is punishing and unforgiving in both combat and choices you make through out the journey. The game is a mix between managing a carvan (people, supplies, morale and difficult choices) and grid tactical combat. The games enviroment aswell as the story kept me very engaged and attached to the characters, each choice i made brought me closer to them and made it that much harder to decide how to proceed through events. The combat is very deep and nothing feels more satisfying than surviving an encounter while your enemy lays there in pieces. The game is much like dark souls in terms of char. progression... your form of currency is renown which is either used to buy important supplies and food for your army to live and be free from sickness or used to upgrade your hero oh and you can use it to buy better items for your heros, choosing which to spend it on is never easy. All in all this game has a deep combat system, an engaging viking/human struggle story to tell and a nasty difficulty which will have you come back again and again A++

												Wow, this was an absolutely fantastic game.  The music and art direction are stellar.  The designers have done a great job mixing a relatively tight tactics experience into a wider battle.  Your small tactical decisions have a significant impact on how many fighters you risk overall.  Throughout the game you feel your decisions make a difference.  This is a story you live, not a simple exercise in min/maxing units.The story and the decisions you make have an impact on the journey, and an arduous one it is.  I laughed, I cried, I loved this game.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Great turned based RPG at an affordable price.  The hand drawn art is really great, voice acting superb.  The only thing I would say, is that it is a bit on "rails", there is no explorable world, so if that is a must for you, then I'd steer clear.  Other than that, it has a lot of options and forked paths, it is like a "choose your own adventure, turn based RPG".  Similar to Oregon Trail, you go and an issue comes up, and you have to choose how to deal with it.  The RPG elements are nice, and there is a ton of tactical decisions in combat, do you want to attack the armor to allow your next character to do more damage, or take off what strength you can now to lower their strength below your own armor value.  Ranged, Melee, tanks, I only have a few hours in so this is just my first impression.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												This game has an astonishing art, some very good music and a great atmosphere in general. The jewel of this game is the combat system for sure. It's not as intense as, for example, new XCOM games, more slow-paced, but still very (and I mean very) satisfying. It has some rather unique ideas too. Although the main idea of the caravan is not new under the hood - the feeling of going for the very long adventure, always struggling against the odds, always on the brink of starvation, facing betrayler here and there makes the story of the game very engaging. All of the story is served as text - a well written text. This may be a problem for some people, but in the end of the day it's like reading a nice book with incredibly beautiful pictures in it. People say it has about 12 hours of content, I was able to squeeze something around 16, but I was taking part in almost every battle I could, trying to save more lives. And this is actually my only complaint - I was a bit tired of the game's mechanics in the end.The best indie I've played to this date, you should definitely try it. But man, the art is SOOO DAMN GOOD!

												An absolutely beautiful game inspired by Scandinavian culture and lore from the days of old. The music and art alone are worth giving this game a try. I wholly enjoyed my time playing, watching, and listening to the story unfold. It truly does live up to the word "Saga" as it revolves around a long journey full of peril and the struggle to survive an quickly encroaching threat. What is amazing is that this game's universe contains a very fleshed-out map for the players to peruse. It took me 20 minutes to systematically click on and read about the universe I found myself in. It is made very clear that the game you are playing is only scratching the surface of this world.  Hopefully even more of the land will be visited in the sequel!

Don't get me wrong; I enjoyed the game, but I would recommend buying it on sale if you get the chance.I also had some trouble getting it to work the first time I played it; the game kept crashing whenever I tried to play. I eventually got the issue sorted out, but it's just something to consider if you're thinking about buying it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												Fans of the "tactics" genre will love this game, which is set in a world inspired by Norse myth. You're sucked in immediately by the gorgeous art and design. Then you stay for the intricate combat and for the Oregon Trail-style survival game between fights. Make no mistake about the "survival" part: all games are hardcore mode (no rolling back to old saves, except at the very end of the game), bad things happen a lot, and story decisions usually have to be made on the spot, with no option to go back or put them off till later. That said, this adds a compelling immersion and gravity to the gameplay, which you really don't find in a lot of RPGs. (If minmaxing is your idea of "role-playing," you won't like this game.) Another interesting feature is that no matter what you choose, the game constantly progresses forward -- there is no way to "lose" the game, there are just different consequences. This is not a beginner's game (unless the beginner has thick skin) -- the difficulty curve is steep, and the game doesn't give you a lot in the way of tutorials or handholding. It's also a little on the short side, which may be a pro or a con depending on whether you like replays. Having played a lot of these games, I really appreciated the depth of gameplay and the story immersion. Saves will carry forward into Banner Saga 2, so grab it now!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												The Banna saga is a beautiful Stylized game that takes turn based mechanics from other influential games and puts its own unique spin on them. Visuals/GraphicsThe Style of graphics that this game uses are very beautiful with cut scenes that really showcase their full potential and gameplay that integrates them nicely. The style of these graphics (Coupled with the gameplay) should make this game easy to run on most PCs whilst still being quite amazing. Sound/Atmosphere The music that strikes up sometimes when the wagon is trundling across the countryside is beautiful with a nordic feel to it that adds immensly to the games atmosphere. The gameplay sounds are also very sharp which complements the combat. GameplayI enjoyed the turnbased gameplay in the Banner Saga as it is an interesting take on turnbased combat but i also felt that more could have been added to it because it can get repetitive and easy to master quite quickly (I am going to do a Hard difficulty walkthrough and see how this changes things). The parts of the game that revolve around the characters which includes levelling up abilities and buying items is interesting and gives the game somewhat more longevity but it would also benefit by being fleshed out further. StoryThe Story in this game is amazing with decisions actually changing some parts of the game such as who lives or dies and even the ending quiet drastically. This is exciting as in your first playthrough you come to learn that most characters could be killed and this lends the story some intrigue. This mechanic can also be seen as annoying as you can spend time levelling characters up and investing resources into them only to have them killed suddenly and this has been an issue for many people playing the game. My time in The Banner Saga was enjoyable and i felt engrossed in the story and character development ! This game costs 20USD as of now and i would not reccommend picking this game up unless it is on sale as it is relatively short (My own playthrough was just over 7 hours). I can reccomend this game as a solid title that will be enjoyed by people interested in turn based games or strong story driven games. 7.5/10 Solid Title.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												Excellent tactics game. The game follows several characters with their allies and followers as they traverse through a norse-inspired fantasy land where it seems that Ragnarok is coming. The battles are done on a tactical grid and have extremely little randomness to them (if a unit is too weak to straight up punch through armor you have a chance of still doing 1 damage), so battles can be planned out well. There are several different stats that you can increase as the characters level up, and each seems to be approximately equivalent in power to the others. When not in battles, you lead a band of followers and need to make tough decisions and need to balance the ability to buy enough supplies to go on with the ability to get your allies trained and get them new items. There are also many decisions that will have consequences, even if what they are may not be immediately evident.

												I cannot recommend this game enough. It's beautiful, and in more ways than just the art. Quick fly decisions that have long lasting impact on your parties are plentiful, similar to Oregon Trail.As a strategy fan, I'm digging the combat. No random dice. No luck of the draw. You either win because you're a better strategist than the AI or you fail because you didn't capitalize on your best assets. Considering how fed up I am with RNG determining games, it's a refreshing and welcome change of pace.It's also a Kickstarter success story and I hope you all support the hell out of this title so we can show AAA game designers huge budgets for sloppily rehashed ideas is not what gamers want.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												An RPG with turn-based tactical combat and lots of tough decisions and moral dilemmas, old-Bioware-style. Casual gamers who just want to play for the story will find an enjoyable, high-fantasy epic inspired by Norse mythology and culture.Plenty of interesting characters, but many of them can die in the story based on your decisions. Perma-death can also occur if you lose certain scripted battles, which adds some XCOM-Ironman tension.Hardcore gamers who want to master the combat will find that the mechanics are like a fusion between Devil Survivor + Dofus + Fire Emblem. Turns are always alternated between yourself and the opponent, and because damage and hitpoints both come from the same stat, you must always find a way to protect your damage dealers from harm -- otherwise the battle might become unwinnable because no one is able to deal damage. Basic, common-sensical turn-based tactics still apply here, but you must learn several new tricks (such as leaving near-dead enemies alive to obstruct stronger enemies from reaching you).Overall, an enjoyable game for the combat, story, and tough in-game decisions. However, beware of the final boss battle: on Normal/Hard difficulty, it's an absolutely unfun and frustrating fight that will seriously test your patience.

												I really wanted to recommend this game. There were just too many negatives from my perspective to recommend it. Here are the "I would like to recommend the game BUT..."Most importantly, there was just simply too much waiting on the caravan to travel from one place to another where you're just watching... well... the caravan travel from one place to another. That really killed most of the enrapturement (sp?) about the story for me; it detaches you from the continuity of the story's most-appealing drama.Another 'but' to a lesser extent, is the fact that some elements either don't work, such as the morale (spent the larger portion of the end of the game with the lowest morale possible with no effect), or are counter-productive, such the use for renown to purchase supplies AND upgrade the characters with. Eventually, I felt that I had to trade off one for the other.There were some other minor nuisances but they're not worth mentioning.The good news is that the story was riveting (albeit a little on the short side - It only took me ~20 hours to finish the game on normal and that includes the battles and the meaninglessly arbitrary zombieing as I helplessly watched the caravan trudge their way across one terrain after another) and the battle system was somewhat engaging but was significantly redundant - the final boss battle was far too easy . I still hear myself yelling inside my own head "THAT's IT!!!???"I hope some of these issues are addressed in the sequel coz I really wanna love this game.

												I thought this was a beautiful game to play and thoroughly enjoyed how it willed me to continue on, even after making bad decisions. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												First, I'll start by stating the obvious.  The graphical design, battle animations, and music are absolutley amazing!  I felt like I was engaged in a movie (in a good way) as well as playing a game.  I only crashed once while playing this game, so I'd say it's stable. If you are looking for an action packed game, then this is NOT for you.  I would say this is a casual, relaxing game at best.  All you need is a mouse to point and click.  TBS is as linear as a game can be.There is a very detailed map in the game that feels wasted.   Every nook and cranny has detailed lore about it, but you're not going to explore over half of it, which is a shame.There are 3 races in the game.  Humans, Varl and Dredge.  I feel like they could have done more with the Dredge.  There are about 4 or 5 different looking dedge sculpts, then each of those has a couple colour variations of the same sculpt.  So after a few battles with them, it can get a bit tedious fighting the same enemies over and over again.The reknown system is both your XP and currency.  You gain it from killing enemies, or through the decisions you make throughout your travels.  It can get very frustrating when you have to make a choice of starving your army or promoting or buying items.  I really wish they would have put gold or silver in the game to buy items and supplies.You get 1 reknown for killing an enemy, no matter how big or how small.  It would be nice to be rewarded a bit more for killing larger enemies.Also, your characters only get a reknown towards their promotion if they get the killing blow on an enemy.  I'm still trying to figure out if I like this or not, because it definitely adds strategy to the game, if you are trying to level up a certain character.  The downside is you could have a character make some really critical strikes that help your teamates, but if they don't get that last shot to kill the enemy they will stay a low rank and die easily as you progress.Combat is simplistic.  Hit their strength or armor.  There are no tactics such as flanking or backstabbing, which really makes the battles feel tedious as you progess through.  I think they can do a lot more with this system to spice it up rather than just rushing forward and hoping you kill them before they kill you.On to the caravan sequences.  As you travel town to town you will get dialog options that will help, harm, or do nothing based on your dialog choices.  You will lose caravan followers, supplies, and even playable characters (used in battles).   A lot of people feel like this is just a pointless guessing game, as some logical choices harm you and some bad choices help you, but not always.... so in a way they are right, it is a guessing game, but there were a lot of times when I was really surpised by the outcome, good or bad, it gave the game some depth for me and really brought me into some dark times (people starving, poor morale, people unhappy with my choices and leaving), but Iwas fine with that.  It really playied into the dark depressing atmosphere of the game, and because my main characters were not natural leaders, the guessing part really made sense to me.  It made me appreciate those choices that worked out in my favor that much more!All in all, I recommend this game!  I really enjoyed it and felt like I got my moneys worth.   It was a breath of fresh air from the games I usually play. Yes, there are some things they can improve on and I'm sure they will if they make another installment.  I give it a 7.5/10
