content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
At first glance......I thought this game to be one of the same over-simplified turn-based combat-driven games I've been avoiding since that genre (and my interest in it) peaked along with the rise of Gameboys. I've become rather disinterested in comparing shallowly described classes and carefully coordinating important story battles such that my opponents are always outmatched before combat even begins. I'm particularly bored with the fantastical colors and purple-teal magical glows that have illuminated far too many games since Warcraft made the scheme popular, each new level bringing bigger and brighter spells until the screen resembles a cosplay rave party. More of my discomfort comes from the tedious line-by-line conversations with innumerable boring, lifeless mouthpieces for plotlines.Drawn to Norse mythology and anyone willing to give it the credit it deserves in our modern creative landscape, I set aside my defensive suspicions and took a second glance, a third, and eventually an eleventillionth. This is a spectacularly well made game that knows exactly who it is and what it was meant to be, systematically ignoring every expectation in favor of its own designs. I find myself at a loss to compare it because there is no reason to do so. Simply put, this is the Banner Saga.A list, if you need one:Though numerous, classes are barely more than labels to help you recall the character of each member of your party. They are unchangable memory sinks for behaviors in combat and a helpful tool for describing the titles within the cultures of the two main races.The heart and soul of the northern mythologies is as clear and chilling in this saga as the harsh landscapes they emerged from. Your characters march onward through the blistering blizzards that blanket the earth in snow, the cool breezes that chase across green fields, and the dark shadows cast by craggy mountains even as troubles press endlessly upon them from all sides. As their hopes freeze, hidden strengths unthaw, bringing forth the selfless valor that once fueled one of the fiercest cultures in human history.Banner Saga is ten parts story and ten parts gameplay--out of ten. Rather than being set loose to interview town after town, progressing from quest to quest and moving freely between to train your party, Banner Saga permanently aligns the two in a single, linear journey that winds its way towards and away from harm with each new decision you make. Along the way you face both internal and external threats, each delivered with the utmost forwardness such that you immediately recognize and accept the costs of your actions and move on, even at the cost of your own party (as opposed to abusing your saves). There is as much story within your own party as there is in your travels and you are free to choose your own way forward even if circumstances often influence your inevitable direction.To die is to have lived. At first you will watch as your party grows, meeting each individual and initiating your search into their past and into their motives. Many of them will be taken from you long before you get a chance to truly know them and others will submit or rebel, dramatically altering the composition of your band until you come to realizethat there is no time to understand them all.The visuals in this game are inspired. Hand drawn and uniquely detailed characters lend an incredible depth to conversations and the shifting glances, blinks, and blowing winds keep the otherwise still images from appearing as static thumbnails. The parallaxed landscapes provide a smooth, easy transition between the more sketched out locations in the game and a true sense of scale that holds up against the immensities of the world.The map of the world provided for this game is incredibly detailed and intuitive to use. Quick, short descriptions reveal how the world came to be the way it is and the first few times you peruse it you'll find yourself digging deeper into the lands around you until your curiosity is sated. I'm fairly sure there's a considerable amount beyond the scope of the game itself even.If you close your eyes and listen to the music, you'll almost certainly feel the snowflakes melting gently on your nose and lightly dusting your shoulders and hair as a cool wind passes you by.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												If you don't want to read all of this here's the short of it: I love this game. Plain and simple. It's stunningly gorgeous, extremely well animated, and the story is very compelling and moving. It has it's flaws, but I don't find these flaws severe enough to keep myself or anyone from playing this game. It's basically Fire Emblem crossed with Oregon Trail. If thatsounds good to you then, by all means, buy this game. You'll have a blast. Now that that's out of the way, let me explain the shortcomings of this game that I've experienced. There are, by my reckoning, two major problems. One is the options menu. The other appears to be a mild stability issue which may or may not affect you.  In the course of my sessions I've found that during extended periods of gameplay it tends to suddenly go into a window and become unresponsive. Effectively leaving me no choice but to force quit via the task manager. Otherwise it runs very smoothly with no drops in frame-rate.Secondly, the options menu is practically non-existent. You can, somewhat, adjust sound by clicking on some icons that don't  really explain themselves very well or switch from full-screen to windowed--and that's about it. Granted, the game was set up so well that I didn't feel like I needed to change anything in the options menu. But still, it's nice to have a wide array of options.Aside from the options menu and the fact that it seems to crash from being played for too long--it's a fantastic game!  I have thoroughly enjoyed my time with the Banner Saga. The only thing that I think could make it better, aside from fixing the flaws mentioned above, would be to add more content--new character classes, more story/quests etc. I especially wish that all the cutscenes could have been animated like the opening one. But it's understandable that they could not maintain that throughout. I have some minor issues with how the story ended. It seems like they may be trying for a sequel at some point since a lot of questions were left unanswered. Hopefully Stoic was successful enough with this that they can expand upon the story and world with future releases.All in all, I had a lot of fun with it. If you love strategy games then you'll love this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												I just finished TBS, the first game I've finished in 2014. Helps that it was short, I'm thinking no more than 6-8 hours of actual, non-experimentation, non-reloading last checkpoint play time. This is one of the games I Kickstarted back when that was a thing (meaning before I figured out that it really wasn't worth it). No regrets through, well worth the KS$.The game looks and sounds great. The visuals (Eyvind Earle-inspired) and music (Austin Wintory) are major parts of what drew me to TBS in the first place. The game universe, billed as a Viking fantasy, is competent. There's nothing groundbreaking about the story or characters, but they serve the purpose.Gameplay is hit/miss. I'm a TBS (turn-based strategy of course) fan, but the oversimplified systems of TBS (The Banner Saga, of course) leave me wanting more options. Even the Gold Box TSR games had more combat choices than this. The initiative and action mechanisms leave a lot to be desired, as units don't have fixed speeds. It's always a he-goes-you-go deal, so if you mop up weak units early you're left with more powerful units acting more often. This leaves you with a counterintuitive strategy of weakening units without killing them. I'm also torn on the health-as-attack-power thing, but that much I can live with. Last glaring thing for me is the lack of any way to influence movement. Short of a couple of minor abilities that address threat, AI units can waltz around your melee units and go right for ranged. Nothing you can do to stop them.The overland mechanisms are brutal, but if you've played King of Dragon Pass that's nothing new. The game has one currency, caller Renown, which is gained by killing enemies. Renown is used to level characters, buy items and buy supplies that keeps your army alive while travelling overland. You're probably not going to be able to afford any items, unless you're willing to lose people to starvation (events generally cost you supplies as you travel) or you're going to show restraint when levelling your characters (which can backfire if a toon you've invested a lot or resources in gets auto-killed in an event). Still, this is a thing you can get used to compared to the combat.The save system can be confusing, but the game seems to save frequently on its own. You can't seem to manually save, but on hitting Load you can see that it's got three checkpoint saves. Not too bad. The system options are sparse for a PC game in 2014 - no volume controls, no graphics options. Again, nothing too bad. What I wanted most was Steam Cloud save capability, but it's not there. All mostly quality of life stuff here, which may be upgraded when the second chapter ships.Word of warning - this is the first part of a planned trilogy, so the ending kind of feels exactly like that. There's a major event/battle, but a lot of loose ends remain to lead into chapter two. If you were ok with the ending of The Fellowship of the Ring (old school) or The Hunger Games (new school), you'll be fine. :)Overall though I'm satisfied with the game. This is my third KS'd game to deliver (FTL and Shadowrun Returns were my first two) and so far all three are winners in my book. This actually kind of feels like Shadowrun Returns in terms of heft/depth/scope. I recommend TBS to anyone who's into the genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												I hesitated for quite some time before deciding to recommend this game. Here's why.1) The game claims that every decision will be meaningful, and superficially, they are. The game provides you with nowhere near enough currency (renown) to upgrade every party member, purchase items, or maintain your supplies. Therefore, you must choose carefully where to spend your renown. However, there's no way to keep most characters from dying during a dialogue/decision. Even if they are fully upgraded, if a decisions outcome is that they will die, then there's nothing you can do except return to an earlier save. Also, the number of people in your caravan has little to no effect, except in a couple of decisions, so you may as well let them starve. Items can't be sold either, so there's little reason to invest in most of them. All this just left me feeling that there was no point to anything I was doing, as the game would arbitrarily take things from me regardless. 2) The combat definitely takes some getting used to. You are forced between choosing to attack your foes armour, to deal more damage later, or their health/strength, represented by a single number, which means you can get them closer to death as well as reduce your enemy's damage when they attack. As nuanced as this makes the battles, there is never any terrain to hide behind, put archers on, or bottleneck the enemy with, so it still becomes a matter of taking your highest strength party members and trying to get the first hit on any opponent strong enough to break through your armor. There's no perma-death from battles, as far as I could tell, only a few days of recovery from being felled, so you may as well bring the same six characters until the game cheapshots them in the unknowable outcome of a dialogue or decision.3) It's very short, on the easiest difficulty it took me under 10 hours to reach the credits. It may take longer if you play on harder difficulties, but I feel the almost random nature of the consequences would make the experience futile. If you just masterfully won a battle with your last fit character at the hardest difficulty, what would you feel when a minute later when that character dies? Or half your party leaves because the plot said they would? Or because you picked the 'wrong' option, even though there was no indication what it might lead to? Better perhaps, to play on easier difficulties, where you at least feel like you can make a useful impact on the condition of your caravan.So why then, would I recommend a game which blindsides you at every turn, makes you feel like you have no meaningful agency as a player, and seems clearly designed to depress you? Because by doing those three things (and with it's incredibly beautiful rotoscoped graphic style and haunting music) it oozes the atmosphere it needs to provide an engaging story and world. If winning combat meant anything significant except less time injured, you'd have no reason to try and avoid it through your decisions. If you could keep everyone alive, you'd only pick the options which kept them so. If there was enough currency to upgrade everyone, you'd never have to worry about any single character being taken from you as you'd have a better replacement.This may be a game you will find little to no joy in, but I feel like that's what it had to be to really capture the futility and helplessness so core to it's story. I cannot help but wonder if it might have been better as an animated film/mini-series, or whether that would only have reduced the thematic power of the story. Who knows?What I can say, is that if you can approach the game as it wants to be approached (i.e. without imagining that you can 'win' or that your decisions can be 'right' instead of just 'yours'), there is definitely something worthwhile there.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
Love it. Looking forward to the next in the series.The gameplay is fun and interesting. The story is epic. The characters are interesting and tend to cause you to get upset when bad things happen to them. The normal difficulty level is not harsh (no game overs) but not a breeze, either. Next playthrough I'll try on hard, and go for some more of the challenge achievements.The combat mechanics resemble those from other turn-based tactics games. I appreciate that this game was tuned such that every single stat point matters, and such that all stats are equally important. There is no "never put points into that" stat, and your choices simply must reflect your strategy. The game also has a little bit of chess heritage in it. In between battles, the game is a lot like Oregon Trail, and even has some easter-egg references to that. You encounter a variety of story events and have to decide how to handle each thing that comes up in your caravan. Depending on what you choose, you might gain or lose allies, fight extra battles or avoid them, acquire special items, gain or lose caravan population or morale, etc. I'm not sure what degree of randomness applies to these events after my first playthrough.I found that I struggled with combat earlier in the game, despite already being familiar with the mechanics from Factions, but as I leveled my heroes and had more choices to fill my lineup with, things got easier on average. I managed to lose a couple of battles and was too weak to take on some of the optional ones, so next playthrough I'll have to be a bit more careful to unlock a few of the achievements. On the other hand, the caravan-management seemed overly easy-breezy at first, but then got very difficult towards the end. It was never clear to me whether or not I shoud stock up on supplies or if what I had was plenty to get me to the next place to buy some (or if they would be cheaper or more expensive). At any rate, I think I spent too much renown on supplies early on which cost me hero levels, and then didn't have any renown left to spend when the supplies were cheapest and then finally ran out in the final stretches of the journey, losing morale and most of the population of the caravan before the end. At that point in the game it wasn't clear whether it would have been advantageous to have an army with me or not, as those numbers didn't seem to come into play in the story events any more anyway.Some of the events are "wars" where your caravan population are weighed against the hordes of dredge somehow, but I was never able to tell what effect these numbers had on the outcomes, or what the results would be of the various options for approach that you have to choose from. In my game, either I charged in with my team of heroes and fought a normal-looking battle against some dredge, or I chose some other option and we were defeated and lost population.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												Firstly I will say this game is utterly beautiful. The characters, the environment, and music(which is not played enough) are all very reminiscent of the old classic Disney movies. That being said the story is actually pretty good, even if the ending leaves you bit unfulfilled. The game still weaves a pretty good story, and really make the player feel the decisions that they make. I'm assuming that Stoic is seeing how the game does first before they continue this saga. The combat is much like any other Strategy RPG. The only grip about it, is that instead of one side going first or characters going in different orders based on stats, the turns go back and forth regardless. For instance player moves one unit, computer moves one unit and so forth. This system feels very odd to me, as the computer can easily gang up on 1 person because you have to alternate before you can get that character to safety. Once again that's my biggest gripe is on the combat. Rather than use a full team of characters it easier to have just 4 players that are your strongest and use them. Overall the game is great even if it feels like a slow bleed. The game is bleak, and most of the time you are simply struggling to survive. Game runs about 12 hours, will the intent of playing through a few times to see all different decisions.

												I really liked the banner saga. The Banner Saga has beautiful rotoscoped animation, and an immersive world that feels like you are set out on an Epic journey. It's norse viking world was a refreshing break from more stereotypical fantasy genre games. The game struck all the right chords in its landscape design. It evokes a sense of awe as your caravan comes upon the towering stone monuments, marches through chilling frozen wastes and descends into the smoking husks of destroyed cities. The decision making process in the game added another element to the game, as your caravan and characters depend on you to make the right decisions for their survival. If you make the wrong decision someone might die. I wish the game was longer, and can't wait for an expansion. I'd like to see a longer story line and more features, even if they were as simple as letting you explore the various rest houses found in the game, and conversing with locals there. More voice acting is something i would like to see as well.The turn based combat, is very good, i really liked the smooth animation here as well. One thing I would like to see in an expansion is more variance on the number of enemies encountered. I was almost consistantly outnumbered and fighting uneven battles never in my favor. It would have been nice every once in a while to get the jump on someone for a chance to pillage their supplies.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												A very different tactical RPG that I have ever previously played. The art, storytelling and music were things that I really did like, especially because the storyline choices that you make during the game could have consequences through-out the story (main characters can die!).  For people who have played Kingdom of Dragon Pass, the possible reward/atrocity depending on what you choose from that game is very similar to this one, at least in during the storyline portion of the game.There were a few things that I did not like. The combat was fun, but I found it slightly unbalanced in favour to the enemies that you fought against. I also found the renown that you gain (XP, but used for buying items and supplies as well) was in short supply, and at end-game in my 1st playthrough I hadn't fully leveled up my characters. Finally, the game seemed pretty short for the $24.99 that I had to pay to play the game, especially considering the ending of the game  just seemed to be geared up for a sequel (there were a lot of unresolved plot issues). All-in-all, I still found it to be a good game with great storyline and music. For people who like a story driven game, or tactical RPG's, I would recommend this game. However, I would recommend to pick it up on sale because the normal asking price is not worth it for such a short game... unless you are someone who likes multiple playthroughs with different stories each time. 7.5/10

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												I couldn't recommend this game enough. The story and art are largely what will make this one of the best games I've beaten in recent memory. Your decisions matter, your journey matters, and ultimately it feels like the game mechanics actually work to represent the story mechanics well enough. That being said, there are no elevation changes, cover systems, advanced intitiative mechanics, and some scenarios in the game seem too pushed instead of chosen. What I do like is the utility of the strength stat, that armor break is never influenced by a character fatigued in battle, that target square abilities are not abusive, that on HARD mode the game really shows a sense of exhaustion between combat, that losing combat is acceptable, battle decisions and war mechanics, the give and take of travel, that items are limited one per character, that Renown is used both for bolstering forces but also supplying the caravan, and generally I enjoy the tightness of the system to limit having super powered units. There is no Orlandu, and no solo Ramza. There is only the cold, unabiding, and godless lands.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												Great music, amazing art style, and brilliant story-driven gameplay. Its not a game I would usually choose to play, but the survival element and migration aspect was very appealing. You really get a sense that the land and everyone in it are experiencing a great calamity and with the encounters you experience on your journey, there is a sense of urgency and survival. My complaints are the length of the game and the price. The game is pretty short, and you think you can level up more characters before the end but thats not the case, I ended up with medium level characters for the last boss because I spread the points a bit to liberally. I had focused on a few characters, but replaying a new game you know you can ditch and forget some characters over others, mainly picking characters for their ability over anything else. The game does have replay value, and its fun to know what you will do next time knowing what happens, but after that your only left with multiplayer, or maybe replaying it to find out alternatives to minor narratives along the game. The current price is a bit much, but not too far from what I would expect to pay for a quality (if not short) game like this. Its a very good game, and very enjoyable and does a great job at sucking you into the world (wait till you see the map, all that lore!). Hopefully Stoic will make the next game in this trilogy a bit longer, but apart from that its a winning gameplay formula and style.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												In all the ways a game utilizes already established forms of art, the Banner Saga excels.  The visuals are stunning in their detail, beauty, and style evoking the legacy of Eyvind Earle.  The music evokes the mood and setting quite deftly.  The narrative itself perfectly balances world-threatening-menace endemic to fantasy storytelling and more intimate plotlines focusing around the theme of family.Mechanically the game is novel.  The complexity of the combat emerges from simple mechanics, and (refreshingly) cannot be gamed by grinding.  In this way I would say that the experience of combat is well curated.There are also larger scale 'war' battles.  These consist of giving the size of the respective forces, and letting the character pick from a variety of tactical options.  Most of these options (i.e., 'charge,' 'formations,' etc) result in playing out a regular battle with the option to go a second round to earn greater rewards.  The biggest flaw in this aspect of the game is that it isn't made particularly clear what effect the various options actually have.The other mechanical aspect of the game involves managing a caravan of refugees as they treck agross the games gorgeously detailed world.  This basically involves managing food by purchasing it in town and gaining (or losing) it in events in the world and managing morale by deciding when to make camp and rest.  Most of the events in the game are sort of choose-your-own-adventure dialogue puzzles.  Unlike, say, BioWare games there are definitely wrong answers in dialogue and saying or doing the wrong thing can result in losing valuable party members or resources.The pacing of the game is slow and plodding, but for me this actually added to the experience.  The pacing evokes the slog, misery, and dread that must be experienced by the Banner Saga's Protagonists.The Banner Saga has my hearty recommendation.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												great art great music great story lots of things about the banner saga are simply great. The setting feels vibrant and alive and the score by Austin Wintory (same guy who did the OST for Journey) perfectly complements and builds on the atmosphere. The story takes place in a viking like world in the midst of an apocalypse. The sun has stopped, the Gods are dead, hordes of long forgotten foes pour out of the north and serpent the size of mountains rips apart the earth itself. In the face of this, bands of humans an giant horned varl struggle to stay alive and it is your job to guide them through this. Gameplay wise, the banner saga plays like the Oregon trail, you manage your caravans resources and make descisions that may gain or lose party members, with grid-based battles. The sheer challenge of the battles and the constant struggle to maintain morale and food supplies helps to create of feeling of desperation  and futility further building upon the 'end of the world' theme of the game. One of the only problems that i personally had with the game is that some seemingly trivial choises would end up losing you a unit and this felt cheap, more dumb luck then an actual costly mistake.Overall this is a must-play for any fan of turn based stategy games or anyone who justs wants a good story in a beautiful. immersive world. 9.5/10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I gathered the caravan and head out, leaving behind a ruined town. Smoke still smoldering from the recent infighting while refugees continued pouring in, threatening to implode the city like a rotten bloated frog.As we reach the hill side, a scout called out. "Dredges!! On our tail!"I look beyond the sea of people, spotting shadows. It can't be dredges, I thought. Too small.As they drew closer, it was that traitorous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that almost killed us. "Form ranks! Caravan press on!".The group drew closer, weapons readied. Their leader however, walked past his lapdogs and addressed me like old friends. "Friend, I surrender", he said. "Take me prisoner. And let us escape the dredges"Without a word, I slowly drew my bow. My daughter cried out from behind. "No! You can't!"Someday, you'd understand. But for now, I'll do what had to be done. I glanced at my trusted friend. He gave me the barest nod.The traitor stood unflinchingly even as I slowly nock an arrow. And shot the insane ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ through his unwavering left eye.I heard her collapse. SobbingWithout another look, I turned for the caravans. Let's press on.10/10 would shoot him again.OR maybe I'll kill him the moment I meet him. Who knows? That's for another saga to tell.

												This game trades freedom of exploration in exchange for offering you some very tough choices. So many bad situations to navigate through and so many ways things can go wrong... and you really want them to not go wrong. Caution is not always the best choice and losing people always sucks. I am torn; I want to play the game again and try to do better, but I also kinda never want to play it again because I reaped exactly what I sowed.If you like games with tough moral choices, this is one to get. If you hate linear RPGs without the ability to explore environments, this may not be for you... though the choices you can make keep it from feeling linear. It's so easy to wonder what would have happened if you chose differently. And the game offers you a lot of beauty on its linear path. It's gorgeous.I backed this on Kickstarter. They took forever to finish it. I took forever to get around to playing it. And it's turned out to be one of the best Kickstarter game investments I've made.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												I hardly ever think about making reviews, but this game was pure perfection for me. "The Banner Saga" is an extraordinary mixture of storytelling and strategic turn-based fights. The world is inspired by Norse mythology and the plot is really challenging. Many times I found myself stuck with an impossible choice to make, very often the characters had to suffer for my naive nature. It amazes me still how mature this game was story wise despite the graphics imitating animated movies. The battles were challenging at times, even on Normal difficulty, however as a big fun of turn-based mechanics I can't complain much. I like challenging games even if they tend to frustrate you sometimes. The whole award and character leveling system was interesting but also demanding, as the player needs to choose carefully since the same currency is spent on upgrading your heroes as well as supplying your caravan.Finally - the caravan. Never before was travelling from point A to point B this entartaining in-game. No fast travel, no skip button, the player observes the army marching forward with banners put up high in the air and sometimes I caught myself counting the days or looking forward in hope to see a village (especially when I was running low on supplies). As in life though, sometimes you may find things you'd rather not see in your journey and pay a high price for your good intentions.This game is a unique experience, definitely worth a try in my opinion.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												A game that feels like it is a lot more than it is, which is of course a bad thing, but it's a good game none the less. The art style is wonderful, the lore of the world is a brilliant parallel to Nordic mythology, but sadly, for all the choices the game gives you, it's still very linear, which is very fine for the first playthrough, but outside of making your life easier on successive plays, or unlocking achievements, it doesn't really warrant extra playthroughs in my book.Now, don't get me wrong, I absolutely love character based stories, and this game features several interesting and diverse characters, set in a seemingly rich world of vikings, varls, dredge, and ancient history. I say seemingly, because this first installment is too short to give you an actual view of the world as a whole, but rather, you get glimpses into the mythology of the world, and the local settlements. Of course, this is meant as a series, so I am sure much more of this world will be revealed in the subsequent games, so don't take that as too much of a criticism. Graphics wise, the game is quite a thing of beauty, and the style is very deliberately "raw". The handdrawn landscapes are marvelous, and the game's artstyle was something I personally fell in love with. Even the animations are top notch quality, and there seems to be weight in the sprites as they get hit and move around. Gameplay is kind of retro, but in the good way. Think Fire Emblem, Shining Force, etc, turn based, grid combat. It's well balanced, and in my playthrough, even the most hopeless battle was winnable, hard fought as though it may have been. There are some unique mechanics, such as how health, damage and armor is calculated, adjecency effects, as well as abilities that lets you manipulate the position of the enemy characters, and much more. And the music/sound? I wish I could've gone into some greater detail with it, but it's been a long time since I played this, and I recall it being good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Banner saga is the first part of a trilogy. The game itself is turn-based strategy with an unfamiliar turning mechanic and rather bland battlefield. The story involves the end of the world, the pantheon of dead gods, giants, men, and a race of stone golem called Dredge. It's surprisingly rich, deep, tragic, and captivating story. You will have to make hard choices, your men will die, and your family and friends will see the calamity that will change the north forever. However, the turn-based design is a bit bland. Sure, the AI evolves and add more units over time and battle can take plac when you are not ready. It's the stage design that really dumb things down. Basically you have just one type of map, a plain old board with no obstacle, no destructible enviroment whatsover. You will see some background change depends on where the fight is taking place but that's pretty much all the game has to offer. (well, to be perfectly clear, you have one unique map with a few obstacles. I have no idea why developer didn't add more).The game compensates mentioned flaw with Varl units, big giants that take 4 spaces on the board. They serve as tanks and obstacle for both player and AI alike. You will grow fond of them soon since they are the only thing that stand between your range units and horde of Dredge that can one shot them with a swing of an axe. TheRPG element exists in term of character customization which is quie limited. You get to assign two point of attribute for each levelup and you get just 5 level to max plus one slot for artifact. Too little for my taste.Pro:    Great story with choices that will be carried over to the next game. Great artwork. Good character design.Cons:  Bland board design. Limited customization.Do I like it? Yes.  7.5/10

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												This game is fantastic. Visually it is unique and beautiful, with wonderfully drawn characters and beautiful landscapes. In no other game have I seen parallax effects used so well. Its gameplay is a refreshingly different take on the tactics genre that is simple, but challenging and interesting. It has a fantastic story and believable dialogue that kept me intrigued and pulled me into their hopeless, end-of-the-world saga in a way only Game of Thrones or The Road have.In short, It's a brilliantly crafted cross between Final Fantasy Tactics and Oregon Trail that gave me an exciting 15 hours worth of gameplay. If that sounds up your alley then I encourage you to buy it now instead of waiting for the sale price (if it ever does go on sale!). I found it to be worth every penny and can't wait for further projects from Stoic.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												The Banner Saga is such a refreshing game on so many levels, the influences are very noticable, but it all feels remarably fresh. The visuals are stunning at times and it's one of those games that really made me wish I was an artist. This fatasy world Stoic has created is something remarkable and, as far as I know, new to video games. There are no dwarves, elves or other things you might expect from the 'fantasy' genre, but rather something entirely new. Gameplay to me was the weakest part, it is engaging and fun to play, and weak for this game is still very strong, but I felt myself wanting to finish a battle quick just to see where the story went. It's very easy to sink many hours into this game. Be warned though while it clocks in at around a 10 hour or so play through, this is the first part of a larger series, so don't expect a full conclusion. There is only one major issue I had and that was that I wish more of it was voice acted, most of the cutscenes are, but the rest is just text. Even though I got over that very quickly, it would have added so much to the game in my personal opinion. If you are like me and have always wanted a hand drawn Disney style Viking themed dark fantasy RPG that plays like the love child of Fire Emblem and The Organ Trail, then this game is for you.

												Beautifully crafted game; art and music is wonderful. The battles are a bit monotonous, but the storyline more than makes up for it. Which is perhaps a lot of storytelling, including graphics and music, but very little "game" compared to the 100+ hours worth of entertainment I get from the other games I play. But all in all an experience you shouldn't miss out on.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												This is a great game with a very interesting combination of genres. It has elements that remind me a lot of games like Oregon Trail, Walking Dead Game, Heroes of Might & Magic/King's Bounty, and FTL.It has the wagon-train travel aspects of Oregon Trail where you have to travel unerringly in a straight line from one destination to the next, managing supplies along the way. The decision making and roleplaying situations that occur along the way invoke the Walking Dead game, where you have to choose your allies and the choices you make can come back to haunt you. The tough, tactical, turn-based combat is reminiscent of the fights from Heroes/KB. Mix all this in with risk/reward events that pop up during your journey that will have you celebrating when something goes right or crying when it doesn't, ala FTL.Just note that this is the first chapter of a series, so it has a bit of an abrupt ending just when things start getting really interesting.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												The Banner Saga is a very engrossing game, with powerful narrative and a real sense that every choice you make will have unforseen consequences down the line. The world is very rich and teems with backstory, giving a real sense of epic-ness. Unfortunately, it's also very short, and ends rather abruptly, leaving many important plot-points unexplained. Apparantly there are to be sequels at some later date, but after only ten hours of playtime, it left me feeling unsatisfied and a little cheated. The story is a good one, but it is unfinished in a very big way. Rather than feeling like the first volume in a trilogy, it feels more like a prologue, like a demo that only shows you a hint of what is to come in the full game. Unfortunately, this is the full game.All in all, it is a stunningly beautiful game with gorgeous artwork, a good soundtrack, excellent gameplay, and a heroic saga as a storyline. That said, the saga is utterly incomplete, leaving a profound sense of WTF upon the suddenly (and unexpectedly) rolling credits. I will recommend this game, with the caveat that there is no closure at the end.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Kickstarter works! A wonderful and atmospheric game with an interesting, well written and winding narrative. The choices you have to make hurt and come back to bite you. If I have a small gripe it's that the choices aren't always that well explained, and I felt I avoided some options because I had no idea what they entailed.The combat is well balanced and fun, and most importantly never gets boring. I looked forward to each encounter so I could try out new strategies and abilities. The upgrade system is also interesting, making you sometimes choose between spending resources on upgrading your warriors or feeding your people.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Ten years ago I would have stayed the hell away from turn-based strategy games (including tactical rpgs). But I seem to have grown wiser and more open-minded. Or maybe the games have gotten better. One half of a dozen and six of the other.As for the Banner Saga itself, while I didn't back it on Kickstarter (because I found out about it too late), the concept of fantasy vikings battling each other intrigued me.Now I have the finished product in hand and I can only say... money well spent!Yes, the game's hand-drawn backgrounds and animation cutscenes don't have a prayer against current generation graphic engines, but I don't mind that. It gives the game a unique charm. And, as it has been said before, as long as the gameplay is organic and intuitive, the rest of the game can look like §$%&! and people will still play it. Fortunately the Banner Saga has really amazing artwork. One example that comes to mind is that you can always see the main characters in your caravan walking at the front. And the gameplay is what I just said, organic and intuitive. Nothing seems tacked on or out of place, although the strategic battles could have used a bit more finetuning. But this is just my nitpicking and by no means a dealbreaker.So in short, yes, I do recommend this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												This game is a stunner! That cannot be stated enough as you huff it up mountain landscapes that give a real sense of how dire times have become but you're always on the edge to see what's coming up over the crest of that hill. The gameplay is something not often found in that it's lovingly drawn 2 dimensional characters are given 3 dimensional personalities and you find yourself wanting to both slap and warm to many, just to try and put a smile on someones face!Combat finds you in a battle field and you can't help but look it over to give a picture of what the place you're fighting in feels like, adding continuity to the story. The character animations are given from every angle and every character has their own unique style and blend to lend you in the fight against...whoever happens to be hungry, brave, stupid, ignorant, irritating or evil enough to risk it. Having said this, fighting is not the only way to solve problems in this game and you will find yourself making complex decisions as you assume command and control of what happens to your caravan, friends and family.Decision making in the game can be incredibly tense, both active and passively, but sometimes it does feel like many of the options would lead to the same result (unless you pick the extreme option to just pummel someone in the face). Some character animations are lacking during cut scenes, but the strong story filled with twists and b*♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at every turn it's hard to fault.Overall this game is an excellent and uplifting stratergy game that leaves it's mark on the genre and I would recommend buying it!

												A magnificent game that should please fans of RPGs and strategy games alike.When I first began playing this I became hooked; I was addicted to this game s if it were nicotine. The strategy and RPG elements are both very well done. The game is incredibly immersive and the visuals are breathtaking. Be careful of who you trust but also realise that you could make the wrong choice by not trusting someone.

												This game is amazing.  You should consider it with a grain of salt because a lot of gamers will not be able to get over the slower paced meticulous nature of gameplay; however, if you have lamented the industry's lack of story driven content, this is the game.  The single most engaging story I've ever played, better than skyrim.  It's like a viking-oregon trail mixed with a choose your path novel and chess. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												This is one of the best games I've played in the last couple of years.That said, this is not a game for everyone. It is a combination of a complex turn-based tactical strategy, played on small board (you literally need to plan for 6 turns ahead if you want to play on Hard), rpg and text-based "tribe" management game, somewhat reminiscent of King of Dragon Pass. It is "forgiving" to a player, in a sense that you can play it through even if you make bad decisions, lose a lot of people, etc. But if your goal is to actually keep your people alive and try to do the best you can, it's unforgiving - and that's one of its best points. It's easy to play it; it's hard to play it so that your people would still be alive when the game is over. :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												The Banner Saga is an amazing game.  In it, you travel in a caravan full ofsurvivers of the onslaught of the monsterous dredge, who are the main enemies of the game.As you travel, you must make sure morale stays high and there is enough food for everyone.  When you're not traveling, you're fighting.  Combat is in a  grid-based strategy format.  You must take out armor to really damage enemies.  Combat is simple yet difficult.  If a unit falls, they are wounded for a few days (in game) and are less effective.  As for story, the Gods are dead, and you are a simple farmer trying to lead survivers to safety, and you take on large armies of enemies along the way.  Overall I enjoyed the story, but at times it seemed held loosely together.  I was often bored of the story, which is never a good sign.  However, the ending was perfect, and it leaves me waiting for part two.  The score was composed by Austin Wintory of Journey fame, and he absolutly nails it.  Last thing, the art is beutiful.  The hand drawn style really fits the game's theme and gameplay.  The screenshots above are a testement to that.I would reccomend this game to anyone, even if you are not familier with strategy games.  This is the type of game that will make you a fan.Story:4Gameplay:5Overall:9-Great

												Bottom line is this game is quality and for any respecting PC gamer you should own this title.  Music excellent, ambiance deep and overflowing, art simply breathtaking, but how about the gameplay you ask.   The gameplay itself is 75% turn based top down combat game and 25 percent choose your own adventure.  It all works seamlessly and will kick your butt if you don’t learn from your mistakes.  I would say the game is similar to portal in that its feature packed goodness but short.   Gripes you ask, well length is a bit short clocking in at about 10 hours and towards the end the combat will get just a hair tedious.  Oh and did I mention the ending, it’s not an ending.   It ends on a cliffhanger and is clearly meant to be part of a series.  However considering the price (under 30 dollars) the terrific quality and the fact there is some replay ( I immediately replayed 2 more times) it’s worth every penny.  My Score 85/100 Great

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												The Banner Saga is an amazing game.  In it, you travel in a caravan full ofsurvivers of the onslaught of the monsterous dredge, who are the main enemies of the game.As you travel, you must make sure morale stays high and there is enough food for everyone.  When you're not traveling, you're fighting.  Combat is in a  grid-based strategy format.  You must take out armor to really damage enemies.  Combat is simple yet difficult.  If a unit falls, they are wounded for a few days (in game) and are less effective.  As for story, the Gods are dead, and you are a simple farmer trying to lead survivers to safety, and you take on large armies of enemies along the way.  Overall I enjoyed the story, but at times it seemed held loosely together.  I was often bored of the story, which is never a good sign.  However, the ending was perfect, and it leaves me waiting for part two.  The score was composed by Austin Wintory of Journey fame, and he absolutly nails it.  Last thing, the art is beutiful.  The hand drawn style really fits the game's theme and gameplay.  The screenshots above are a testement to that.I would reccomend this game to anyone, even if you are not familier with strategy games.  This is the type of game that will make you a fan.Story:4Gameplay:5Overall:9-Great

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Bottom line is this game is quality and for any respecting PC gamer you should own this title.  Music excellent, ambiance deep and overflowing, art simply breathtaking, but how about the gameplay you ask.   The gameplay itself is 75% turn based top down combat game and 25 percent choose your own adventure.  It all works seamlessly and will kick your butt if you don’t learn from your mistakes.  I would say the game is similar to portal in that its feature packed goodness but short.   Gripes you ask, well length is a bit short clocking in at about 10 hours and towards the end the combat will get just a hair tedious.  Oh and did I mention the ending, it’s not an ending.   It ends on a cliffhanger and is clearly meant to be part of a series.  However considering the price (under 30 dollars) the terrific quality and the fact there is some replay ( I immediately replayed 2 more times) it’s worth every penny.  My Score 85/100 Great

												Fanal Fantasy Tactics meets a choose your own adventure book. The art is a fabulous rotoscoped Dan Bluth-esc / early Disney style that catches your eye like an arrow that missed your knee.The really hooking part of the game is the resource management where buying supplies or ranking up characters can adversely affect your gameplay; every victory is a viceral badge of reknown and the battles can be utterly unforgiving but so rewarding upon sucess. The choices are very heavy, and a bad descion can loose you your favourite warrior in the blink of an eye.Any RPG fan needs to consider this game as it is very original, in a very un-original way. There are no clever game mechanics, no novelty minigames, just a brutal combat system where a single move can swing the battle at any given moment.I give this a stunning 9/10...And i'm not even a big rpg fan!  Want to waste a whole weekend on £18.99. Grab this game.

												Fun game!  It's like nothing I have played before so it is hard for me to draw a comparison.  The story is good and the combat, though simple mechanically is load with possible combo's of abilities if you care to explore them.  The game is very linear, so you aren't in control of the story. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												The Banner Saga does what it wants to do. It weaves together some of the strongest world-building in recent years with a good core game mechanic and a fantastically varied roster of characters and a well-written story. Sure, it has flaws, but none of them glaring. There is nothing fundamentally wrong with the game's combat system, for example, but it does appear in need of a bit of fine-tuning. I will not spend any more time discussing the gameplay and art assets themselves here - other people have done so, and better than I can do it. Instead, I want to discuss some points that have turned other reviewers off, because it would be a shame if they scared away somebody who would truly enjoy this game.A fellow reviewer wrote that to his dissatisfaction, the player cannot play "good or bad characters". Another reviewer was very disappointed with the "disjoint between decision and results". If you want to play a "good or bad" character, or if you want the choices you do to make sense in a moralistic superhero-world kind of sense - where altruism will always pay off and bad deeds are always punished - then this game is not for you.If, on the other hand, you realize that a game that always rewards you for being altruistic essentially does not give you a choice; it is parenting you - this game is for you. If you consider the "good-evil o'meters" from games like Mass Effect to be stifling, oversimplified and condescending of your ability to comprehend your own choices - this game is for you.And just like Game of Thrones, this harsh and often "unfair" world gets under your skin and stays with you - even as you curse making a decision that had disasterous implications for your success, it pulls you in. If you enjoyed the bittersweet sense of loss when a soldier died in XCOM, this game is - by all the gods - very much for you.

Where you recognise evil, speak out against it, and give no truces to your enemies.― Old Norse ProverbI don't like games like 'caravan' too much, but Banner Saga is really solid and full-climate product.After 18h (2 full runs):PROS+ Norse mythology inspiration+ interesting (little apocalyptic) story+ 2D drawing+ decisions have consequences+ fine heroesCONS- sometimes little too hard/too unfair battles- useless archers- sometimes small problem with team/equipment roster (bug, but we can load)- items are not very well-balancedSubjective rate: A- (apart from minor bugs, which we can live and play, BS does a really good impression. The game can create attachment to the caravan, to each of its members individually and all together. And the finale - sad but beautiful at the same time. I look forward to sequel.)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												This game is proof that game development has matured to the point where games like this can happen. It's a complex story game with stunning visuals, beautiful original soundtrack and incredible turn-based combat, where your choices really matter. There is no going back once you've made a decision (watch out for mistakes). It even has great replay value, which is something I didn't expect from a story-telling game. Mind you, this game is HARD. Given my previous experience having beaten turn-based strategy games on hard mode (such as xcom, civilization, shadowrunner, etc.) I thought I could just jump in on hard mode... I was wrong. I made a run for it and I basically failed, so I had to play it in normal to adjust to the pace. This game is  already quite challenging as it is. Now that I've beaten it on normal, maybe I'll try beating it again on normal before I can aim for hard mode. Conclusion: I expected this game to be great and it exceeded my expectations. Bought it on sale, but would pay full price for it. Buy it! You won't be dissappointed. This game is a work of art.

Posted: January 18, 2014
												This game has one of the most appealing artwork among recent (and event older) games. This is of course pretty obvious. But not only this point makes the game stand out. The game is full of tenuous, arrow-sharp content, which is placed in such a way that it has the ability to drag the player in the chilly and dangerous atmosphere of the game, full of dangers, precipices and sudden turns. The battle system is strongly reminiscent of asian tactical RPGs like Final Fantasy Tactics and Disgaea, but with what seems a western RPG touch. In between battles you talk, you make descisions, you role play. And your descisions matter.Overall it is a very nice game. So if you like the games with an athmosphere and some kind of subtle feel, this game is worth to check out.

Posted: January 18, 2014
 The Banner Saga is great and if you like trurn based strategy RPG then read not further and buy this game! Do it!!  Now!!!  Still here? Than let me tell you a bit about  The Banner Sage (TBS) .GameplayTBS core is its gameplay. It is fun and challanging and the combination of Strength and Health in one Stat makes the fighting pretty complex. Each unit also has an Armor Stat. Damage equals your Strength minus the enemys Armor, as you take damage you loose Strength and by this you do less damage on your next move. So you have always to decide if you weaken an enemy by attaking his Strength directly or if you lower his Armor so that another unit can deal mor damage.TBS offers a nice range of different classes for your units, each with his own special ablility. The classes are ranging from tanks to fast and versatile units to archers. The Story The heart of TBS is its story. You are provided with a huge Universe overflowing with lore. Each of your characters has its own backstory and motives and I enjoyed their interaction quite a lot. At its core TBS story is about Family and the ones your are responsible for and how far you are willing to go for them. It is about concequences of choice and dealing with loose.As you progress through the Story you are faced with decisions and your choice will affect your experience. Presntation The Soul of TBS is its presantation. The artstyle andt the animation is gourgues and the Soundtrack is fantastic. It is just to sad that there are quite a few passages where no music at all is used.All in all as said above TBS is a very good game! It is a bit minimalistic in some places (cutscenes and story presantation) but in a good way, resampling the charme of oldschool videogames

content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												I finally picked this up on a sale because it's been popping up in my recommendations view nearly every single day, as well as being critically acclaimed and recommended by so many others.What I expected going into it was a fairly linear adventure with tactical combat and story where your choices on how to proceed was of outmost importance.And now that I've completed it....Ehh...Alright, ok, I guess in a sense I got pretty much exactly what I expected, but at the same time.... not really.But, before we go any further.....----SPOILER WARNING!----The following alludes to events in the game without going into specifics. If you want to go into the game knowing absolutely nothing about what will happen, do NOT continue reading.You have been warned.The game is excellently made, with wonderful graphics and engaging characters you grow to care about. You emphasize with their dilemmas, and are torn whenever you have to resolve them.However, this only lasts for about one third of the game before you start to see a pattern, and upon passing the half-point you realize the truth.This game is unhappy. That's the best word I can use to describe it. It is unhappy in the extreme. You will feel that everything you do is wrong, and that there really is no way out that is even slightly hopeful. By the time I reached the finale I just wanted the game to END already so I could get it all over with and do something else, because each and every choice I was presented with was hollow... the world tempted me with hope I knew by this point I could not have, because everything was going to suck no matter what anyway. It was a frustrating feeling, knowing that choice was more or less an illusion, and one that actively punished you arbitrarily by killing off characters you spent points levelling up due to a plot decision you made much earlier in the game, and deleting the items they wore in the process.I managed to scrape by, but I find it absolutely feasable that you could hopelessly screw yourself to the point where the game would be more or less unbeatable simply by investing in the wrong characters. Perhaps this too was an illusion, and if so, good job in making me think my choces mattered in at least one thing.Honestly, I wish I could give this game a neutral rating, because I cannot really recommend it, and yet it's not really a bad game at all.This game absolutely achives what it sets out to do, and in a very engaging and beautiful manner. The graphics are nothing short of gorgeous at times, and the music sets the desired tone perfectly. The tactical combat is a little weak, but does its job despite being hampered by the story choice system.All that said, I have absolutely no desire whatsoever to play the sequel. I don't even care what happens to the characters anymore, because I'm sure many of them will just die horribly in some engaging and tragic manner I cannot look away from, thinking I could've saved them when In reality I could not.If you're a sucker for punishment dressed up in one of the most engaging and pretty dresses ever, play this game. If not, look for something else.I'm erring on the side of positivity and giving the game the thumbs up, but this is the kind of game I'm both glad I played and regretting it at the same time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												The Banner Saga: a very ambitious game that delivers.... more or less.Before I get to discuss the problems I have to say that the graphics/artworks are beautiful and  the soundtrack is gorgeous .Now let's get to the meat of the game:-The game is advertised as a game based on every decision that you take....and that is more or less true. Some of your choices affect the game that is true but not by very much except from like 2 of them. Also the game is not afraid to take decisions without asking you. For example: in the beginning I chose to level up a character because I liked his stats and skills and I said "well if I level up this guy I will crush my enemies in no time" . Well quess what: THE GAME DECIDES THAT THEY HAVE TO LEAVE AND RIGHT AFTER I SPENT MY LEVEL POINTS ON THEM. You don't get to see them until the final  battle and you don't get a character with similar attributes anywhere in the game . So in the final battle you get them right, but they are already low level by the  standard of that time.  What the hell?-For a game praised for the importance of your choices the game is quite linear. The game will switch most of the time between 2 groups of people whenever the story wants. Which makes it a bit harder to follow the plot.-The gameplay consists of a turn based combat strategy game. It's refreshing and unique but is also  so basic and you will get bored in a few battles. It is also sometimes punishing and unforgiving.Overall the game is good but not what people make it out to be . I give it a 6-7/10 . It's enjoyable but gets tedious by the end of the game.

												Spoiler FREE review.The visuals and music are beautiful and so it's the concept. But gameplay?First let's get to the core of the game,The Turn Based Combat System!:The turns are like a chess board game, let me use an example:Le's say you have 4 guys and your oponent has 8.This means that each of your guys will get to move at least 2 times by the time your oponent has managed to move it's entire team, this is ofcourse if you didnt slay any of them. If you did then, things can get reversed until you reach pillage mode.When you reduce your foes numbers to just one, you will go into "PILLAGE MODE!" To put it simple It just sounds cool and the turn mode becomes like those of any Fire Emblem Games. Meaning everyone gets one turn per round, including your opponent. This can help you set up the kill for the hero that needs to level up, or simply for the next wave of enemies.It is an interesting concept but could had been done more justice.The enemy will automatically go next - even if it just moved in the previous turn - and will do what this game does best, search for your weakest guy and try to bring it down.I understand that this was so that if you had 5 guys left and your oponent just one it wouldnt get to move every time your oponent does, otherwise it would be crazy!But anyways, do you get a reward for pillaging? Do you get to burn stuff? No, you dont, Unlike real life Pillaging.In real life the last unit would flee, do a last stand or surrender . Not search for the weakest and going on a programmed kamikaze mode. But this is what this game does.I often wonder if the programmer or the “Creative director” ever bothered on playing fire emblem or final fantasy tactics or doing some research on other strategic war games.And talking about the  A.I. of your enemies, It is ridiculou! It’s like you are fighting terminators that know exactly every specific movement that you will take and that will ALWAYS have more bonuses than you and will charge at your weakest unit no matter if other units are closer to them.They are like Kamikazes that will search for your weakest guy no matter if it's behind a giant maze. So get ready for an intense challenge.The Story and Writting ELEMENTS! choose your dialogue wisely:First and Foremost be aware that every dialogue you choose can mean the life or death of one of your heroes. Even at the very beggining of the game. So unless you want to save it, you will have to redo the battle all over again and explore for the proper dialogue option. Sometimes it is often the most cliche one the one that saves it.However it appears that at some point the programmer or writter got aware of this "save scamming" as they like to call it. And very early on the game you get a choice and you will take consequences near the end of the game depending on that choice.An extensive dialogue tree will be presented and no matter your choice of dialogue or any other thing that you have done in this game, you will loose at least 3 characters that may be some of your strongest ones.Meaning you wont be exploring their relationships anymore and you will be heavily outmanned when you get to the last combats.This was Lazily implemented and poorly written, many players consider it BS yet the programmers think its cool and even compare it to The Game of Thrones Death of Ned Stark. Which doesnt make sense because that is the predetermined story, it is very well written and its not an option just to screw the honest players.Suffice it to say that if you want to save them, you will have to restart the game or edit the game save files.The Renown!Renown it's the currency and blood of the game. With it you level up, improve your skills, purchase items and most importantly get FOOD!It is extremely scarse you can only get it after battles or after certian actions so be very greedy on it, unless you have to level heroes or purchase food supplies.But why food?:In this game you are the leader of a caravan, as each day passes your people will consume food "supplies" and if you start running out of it then the morale will go low and they may ended up dying out of starvation. You have the option to set a camp and rest in order to improve morale, and morale helps you A LOT when it comes to battles.Items can be found and obtained after war simulated battles or visiting places and interacting with them. Others can be purchased with Renown. I personally didnt like that Renown and currency where the same thing in this game, because you either have to choose wether to level up your character or purchase food or a cool item. The tutorial it’s extremely basic and leaves you to learn the new abilities by yourself. The game doesnt like rewarding you and it's always trying to make you miserable or frustrated.In Short, the game doesnt like to reward you but will try in a constant basis to screw you and make you miserable. Maybe it wants you to understand how frustrated the main heroes of this story feel, I dont know.Visuals and looks:Bloody Gorgeous, reminds you a lot from the Sleeping Beauty and all those animated movies from old disney and  the knight and medieval movies Like Ivanhoe. Even if it's Norse Mythology based.Definitly the selling point of this game. The art and coloring it's just pure eye candy and even sometimes eye protein too. You can spend a good amount of time just examining screens, horizons, forests and even the battle scenarios.The music it's really beautiful too, and sometimes very inspiring.If you are a hardcore Turn Based Strategy Game Player that loves to play It's Fire Emblems in hard mode. Then you are on for one hell of a ride! If you are just going to enjoy the ride, I suggest you to play it on easy unless you are up for some frustrating times or a real challenge.Thank you for reading through this sincere review, as always no boot licking.

Posted: May 14, 2016
												Likes - Animation and art are beautiful, and somewhat nostalgic. Gameplay is simple, but fun.Dislikes - Too much dialog for a strategy game; cutscenes can be a bit much. No on the fly save gasme so prepare to leave it running if you need to step away for a while.
